headline.main: NASA Urged To Give Pluto A Priority In Exploration

stories.snippet: A mission to Pluto, which has been on and off NASA's docket for years, should be a top priority in exploring the solar system over the next decade, a federal advisory committee said today.    Exploring Pluto and some of the thousands of similar...
stories.lead_paragraph: A mission to Pluto, which has been on and off NASA's docket for years, should be a top priority in exploring the solar system over the next decade, a federal advisory committee said today. Exploring Pluto and some of the thousands of similar frozen objects that also lie beyond the orbit of Neptune would open a new chapter in learning about the solar system and its origins, said the advisory panel, the Space Studies Board of the National Research Council.

stories.abstract: Correction of Dec 4 article about repair mission to Hubble Space Telescope, regarding erroneous date mentioned

headline.main: Correction: For the Record

stories.snippet: An article in Science Times yesterday about a repair mission to the Hubble Space Telescope misstated the year of a previous mission. Cmdr. Scott Altman and Michael J. Massimino were on a Hubble mission in 2002, not 2003.
stories.lead_paragraph: An article in Science Times yesterday about a repair mission to the Hubble Space Telescope misstated the year of a previous mission. Cmdr. Scott Altman and Michael J. Massimino were on a Hubble mission in 2002, not 2003.

stories.abstract: NASA pushes back date for final mission to Hubble Space Telescope by space shuttle Atlantis to allow more time for preparations; also postpones supply mission of shuttle Discovery to International Space Station (S)

headline.main: Hubble Mission Is Moved Back

stories.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration set Oct. 8 as the date for the final mission to the Hubble Space Telescope. A crew of seven aboard the space shuttle Atlantis was to repair and upgrade the 18-year-old telescope at the end of August,...
stories.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration set Oct. 8 as the date for the final mission to the Hubble Space Telescope. A crew of seven aboard the space shuttle Atlantis was to repair and upgrade the 18-year-old telescope at the end of August, but the mission was delayed because more time was needed to build fuel tanks for the shuttle flight and a potential rescue mission. The agency also rescheduled a supply mission to the International Space Station to Nov. 10 from Oct. 16. The shuttle Discovery is scheduled for launching on May 31 to deliver and install the Japanese laboratory Kibo at the space station.

stories.abstract: Thomas Wright letter holds that bureaucratic fear of shuttle program failure is main factor in NASA's reluctance to support mission to Hubble Space Telescope

headline.main: A Space Agency for the Faint of Heart

stories.snippet: To the Editor:    Pioneering is never safe, because it is never routine.    Sean O'Keefe, the NASA administrator, is concerned that ''schedule pressure'' to launch a space shuttle to repair the Hubble would compromise safety (Op-Ed, March 14). A...
stories.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Pioneering is never safe, because it is never routine. Sean O'Keefe, the NASA administrator, is concerned that ''schedule pressure'' to launch a space shuttle to repair the Hubble would compromise safety (Op-Ed, March 14). A Hubble mission would not be a case of discounting safety in favor of commercial pressure, but a race to save the most productive effort of the entire space program.

stories.abstract: Editorial assails NASA for canceling planned servicing mission to Hubble Space Telescope that would have upgraded its instruments and extended its life past end of decade; notes that decision makes it likely that telescope will run out of battery power by about 2007; urges Congress to prevent premature loss of Hubble; contends that it is being sacrificed to make way for Pres Bush's grand new plans to send astronauts to Moon and Mars in future years; maintains that once shuttles are deemed safe enough to resume flying, flight to Hubble will be no more risky than flights to space station; asserts that science still to be done on Hubble is far more important than anything likely to be accomplished on space station

headline.main: Premature Death for the Hubble

stories.snippet: By all accounts the Hubble Space Telescope is one of the most productive scientific instruments in history. Orbiting high above the distorting effects of Earth's atmosphere, it has peered far out into space and back toward the beginnings of time,...
stories.lead_paragraph: By all accounts the Hubble Space Telescope is one of the most productive scientific instruments in history. Orbiting high above the distorting effects of Earth's atmosphere, it has peered far out into space and back toward the beginnings of time, producing images of startling clarity. It has detected extremely faint objects that can't be seen from the Earth, calibrated the age and expansion rate of the universe, detected supermassive black holes in the cores of galaxies and generally helped revolutionize our understanding of the universe. A distinguished panel of astronomers judged that Hubble ''has arguably had a greater impact on astronomy than any instrument since the original astronomical telescope of Galileo.'' Yet now, just as Hubble was scheduled for a major rejuvenation, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has consigned it to slow death. The agency has canceled a planned servicing mission that would have upgraded Hubble's instruments and extended its life past the end of the decade, making it likely that the telescope will run out of battery power and functioning gyroscopes by about 2007. Congress needs to prevent the premature loss of this valuable instrument.

stories.abstract: Editorial contends that NASA administrator Sean O'Keefe seems to be digging in his heels against any effort to overturn his cancellation of next shuttle servicing mission to Hubble Space Telescope; maintains that his reluctance makes it imperative that Congress insist on full-scale analysis of risks and benefits of servicing Hubble, and that National Academy of Sciences refuse to undertake anything less

headline.main: Astronomical Exaggerations

stories.snippet: Sean O'Keefe, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, seems to be digging in his heels against any effort to overturn his cancellation of the next shuttle servicing mission to the Hubble Space Telescope, thereby sentencing...
stories.lead_paragraph: Sean O'Keefe, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, seems to be digging in his heels against any effort to overturn his cancellation of the next shuttle servicing mission to the Hubble Space Telescope, thereby sentencing this extraordinary scientific instrument to a probable death in 2007. Under pressure this week, Mr. O'Keefe agreed to solicit advice from the National Academy of Sciences, but made it clear that there is little chance he will reverse course. He wants the academy to focus on ways to extend Hubble's usefulness that do not require a visit by astronauts. The administrator's reluctance makes it imperative that Congress insist on a full-scale analysis of the risks and benefits of servicing the Hubble, and that the academy refuse to undertake anything less. The premature termination of such a valuable scientific instrument is too important a decision to be left solely to an administrator who announced the cancellation without warning in January and has yet to justify the decision adequately.

stories.abstract: Crew on board International Space Station for last five months is eager for return home on May 3 now that replacement crew has arrived; crewmen--Capt Kenneth D Bowersox and Dr Donald R Pettit of US and Nikolai M Budarin, Russian flight engineer--will return in Russian Soyuz spacecraft that was their emergency lifeboat (M)

headline.main: Station's Crew Eager for Trip Back to Earth This Weekend

stories.snippet: The crewmen who have manned the International Space Station for five months said today that they would miss it but were eager to head home now that their replacements had arrived.    The crew of two Americans -- Capt. Kenneth D. Bowersox of the Navy,...
stories.lead_paragraph: The crewmen who have manned the International Space Station for five months said today that they would miss it but were eager to head home now that their replacements had arrived. The crew of two Americans -- Capt. Kenneth D. Bowersox of the Navy, the station commander, and Dr. Donald R. Pettit, science officer -- and a Russian flight engineer, Nikolai M. Budarin, is to return to Earth this weekend after an extended stay caused by the Columbia accident.

stories.abstract: Russian Soyuz capsule that ferried three astronauts from International Space Station back to Earth lands 260 miles short of its intended target in steppes of Kazakhstan, after technical malfunction or piloting error during its fiery descent; faulty re-entry prompts confused two-and-half hour search for it and heightens anxiety over what is, for now, only way to carry astronauts to and from space station because of grounding of American space shuttles after Columbia disaster on Feb 1; three crew members are in good health; they have been aboard space station since Nov 25; they are American astronauts Capt Kenneth D Bowersox and Dr Donald R Pettit and Russian Nikolai M Budarin; map (M)

headline.main: Soyuz Lands Off Course After Error Or a Glitch

stories.snippet: The Russian Soyuz capsule that ferried three astronauts from the International Space Station back to Earth today landed about 260 miles short of its intended target in the steppes of Kazakhstan, officials said, after a technical malfunction or...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Russian Soyuz capsule that ferried three astronauts from the International Space Station back to Earth today landed about 260 miles short of its intended target in the steppes of Kazakhstan, officials said, after a technical malfunction or piloting error during its fiery descent. The capsule's faulty re-entry prompted a confused two-and-a-half-hour search for it and heightened anxiety over what is, for now, the only way to carry astronauts to and from the space station because of the grounding of the American space shuttles after the Columbia disaster on Feb. 1.

stories.abstract: Destruction of space shuttle Columbia and grounding of shuttle fleet deal heavy blow to effort to expand International Space Station; NASA has several options for retrieving three astronauts now aboard space station, two Americans, Capt Kenneth D Bowersox and Dr Donald R Pettit, and Russian flight engineer, Nikolai M Budarin (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE SPACE STATION
headline.main: Delays Expected in Expanding Orbiting Laboratory, and Perhaps in Retrieving 3 Astronauts

stories.snippet: The destruction of the space shuttle Columbia came just as NASA and its 15 international partners were preparing for a major expansion of the International Space Station, and it has dealt a heavy blow to that effort, experts and agency officials said...
stories.lead_paragraph: The destruction of the space shuttle Columbia came just as NASA and its 15 international partners were preparing for a major expansion of the International Space Station, and it has dealt a heavy blow to that effort, experts and agency officials said yesterday. Most recent shuttle missions -- but not the one that broke apart yesterday -- were to ferry astronauts to and from the space station and to deliver and install parts.

stories.abstract: Two-person relief crew, American Dr Edward T Lu and Russian Yuri I Malenchenko, arrive at International Space Station and three-person crew, Americans Kenneth D Bowersox and Dr Donald R Pettit and Russian Nikolai M Budarin, prepare to depart after more than five months in space; Columbia shuttle disaster, which has suspended flights during crash investigation, necessitated pared down crew and halted construction efforts; mission will require smaller crew to conserve supplies, which are dwindling since shuttle suspension, to perform more routine station maintenance and operations and perform limited 200 hours of research; there are no expansion projects planned; current three-man crew will return to earth in Soyuz rescue capsule in first ever American astronaut landing outside of US scheduled for Kazakhstan; photo (M)

headline.main: 2-Man Crew, With Modified Duties, Reaches Space Station

stories.snippet: The pared-down relief crew arrived at the International Space Station today, just two men who will work to keep the massive project running in place until American space shuttles fly again and construction can resume.    Duties of this two-man crew...
stories.lead_paragraph: The pared-down relief crew arrived at the International Space Station today, just two men who will work to keep the massive project running in place until American space shuttles fly again and construction can resume. Duties of this two-man crew will differ greatly from those of its three-member predecessors: as a result of the grounding of the American shuttle fleet after the loss of the Columbia on Feb. 1, space station building has come to a halt and normal supply lines are choked. The new crew will have less time for research and will have to pay extra attention to food, water and other consumables, which are in increasingly short supply without regular shuttle visits.

stories.abstract: Soyuz space capsule crewmen Russian Nikolai M Budarin and Americans Capt Kenneth D Bowersox and Dr Donald R Pettit meet with news media, Moscow; shrug off concerns about their steep plunge to Earth in malfunctioning spaceship and off-target landing; Russian Space Agency has set up panel to probe flawed re-entry; photo (M)

headline.main: Soyuz Crew Shrugs Off Rocky Plunge From Space

stories.snippet: Offering a multinational display of right-stuff bravura, the three-man crew of the Soyuz space capsule met the news media today and shrugged off the notion that their steep plunge to Earth in a malfunctioning spaceship last Sunday was riskier than...
stories.lead_paragraph: Offering a multinational display of right-stuff bravura, the three-man crew of the Soyuz space capsule met the news media today and shrugged off the notion that their steep plunge to Earth in a malfunctioning spaceship last Sunday was riskier than any other weekend drive. The astronauts, two Americans and a Russian, clad in identical blue coveralls, spent 40 minutes talking about the sweet smell of Kazakhstan earth after five and a half months in space, the strangeness of slithering out of their capsule with muscles that had forgotten gravity and the joy of seeing their wives.

stories.abstract: New type of jet engine, afer more than four decades of promise and speculation, is about to power a small experimental plane at speeds previously reserved for rockets; early next month, unpiloted, hypersonic plane called X-43A is to be shot to edge of space on nose of rocket before cutting loose for short dash on its own off the Pacific Coast at almost 5,000 miles per hour, seven times speed of sound; photos (L)

headline.main: Test of Revolutionary Jet Promises to Transform Flight

stories.snippet: After more than four decades of promise and speculation, a new type of jet engine is about to power a small experimental plane at speeds previously reserved for rockets.    Early next month, the unpiloted plane called X-43A is to be shot to the edge...
stories.lead_paragraph: After more than four decades of promise and speculation, a new type of jet engine is about to power a small experimental plane at speeds previously reserved for rockets. Early next month, the unpiloted plane called X-43A is to be shot to the edge of space on the nose of a rocket before cutting loose for a short dash on its own off the Pacific Coast at almost 5,000 miles per hour, seven times the speed of sound.

stories.abstract: NASA announces experimental X-43 pilotless plane broke world speed record for atmospheric engine, briefly flying 4,780 miles per hour, or seven times the speed of sound; aircraft is hybrid of jet and rocket; was dropped from wing of modified B-52 bomber and boosted by rocket to nearly 100,000 feet, where it flew for ten seconds before falling into Pacific Ocean (S)

headline.main: Jet Breaks Speed Record

stories.snippet: An experimental X-43 pilotless plane on Saturday broke the world speed record for an atmospheric engine, briefly flying 4,780 miles an hour, seven times the speed of sound, NASA said.    The hypersonic aircraft, a cross between a jet and a rocket,...
stories.lead_paragraph: An experimental X-43 pilotless plane on Saturday broke the world speed record for an atmospheric engine, briefly flying 4,780 miles an hour, seven times the speed of sound, NASA said. The hypersonic aircraft, a cross between a jet and a rocket, was dropped from the wing of a modified B-52 bomber and boosted by an auxiliary rocket to an altitude of nearly 100,000 feet . It then flew on its own for 10 seconds before plunging into the Pacific Ocean, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said.

stories.abstract: NASA plans to try to set world speed record for jets with flight of pilotless vehicle that culminates decades-long research program into hypersonic flight; craft, X-43A, is powered by rocket booster dropped from modified -52 bomber; it is expected to go almost 7,000 miles an hour, 10 times speed of sound (M)

headline.main: Pilotless Jet Will Attempt Speed Record

stories.snippet: NASA plans to try to set a world speed record for jets with the flight of a pilotless vehicle that culminates a decades-long research program into hypersonic flight.
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA plans to try to set a world speed record for jets on Monday with the flight of a pilotless vehicle that culminates a decades-long research program into hypersonic flight. The craft, the X-43A, is powered by a rocket booster dropped from a modified B-52 bomber. In a short dash above the Pacific, it is to use its experimental scramjet engine, which is expected to push the craft to almost 7,000 miles an hour, or 10 times the speed of sound.

stories.abstract: Small, pilotless NASA aircraft sets speed record for jet planes when it dashes out over Pacific Ocean at almost 10 times speed of sound; craft, X-43A, reaches speed of about 6,600 miles per hour during its short test flight before executing series of high-speed maneuvers on its way down to the sea (S)

headline.main: NASA Jet Sets Record For Speed

stories.snippet: A tiny pilotless NASA jet soared above the Pacific Ocean on Tuesday at nearly 10 times the speed of sound, almost 7,000 miles an hour, thanks to a radical new engine technology.
stories.lead_paragraph: A small, pilotless NASA aircraft set a speed record for jet planes on Tuesday when it dashed out over the Pacific Ocean at almost 10 times the speed of sound, project officials announced. The craft, the X-43A, reached a speed of about 6,600 miles an hour during the short test flight of its experimental scramjet engine before executing a series of high-speed maneuvers on its way down to the sea.

stories.abstract: X-43A, NASA's experimental unmanned jet, is being readied for 10-second dash at edge of space on March 27 that could see it reach speed of 5,000 miles per hour, seven times speed of sound, in testing concept of scramjet engine; it would become first nonrocket, air-breathing plane to reach hypersonic speeds if testing is successful; engineers say scramjet engine could lead to sending payloads into space much more cheaply or to aircraft that could whisk people to any point in world within two hours; flight will be held 40,000 feet above Navy's Pacific test range off California coast; diagram shows how scramjet engine differs from conventional jet engine (M)

headline.main: NASA Seeks New Frontier in Jet Engines

stories.snippet: It is to last just 10 seconds, but researchers say this brief firing of a new kind of jet engine could be the first step toward revolutionizing high-speed air and space travel.    An experimental unmanned jet called the X-43A is being readied for a...
stories.lead_paragraph: It is to last just 10 seconds, but researchers say this brief firing of a new kind of jet engine could be the first step toward revolutionizing high-speed air and space travel. An experimental unmanned jet called the X-43A is being readied for a dash at the edge of space on Saturday that could see it reach a speed of 5,000 miles per hour, seven times the speed of sound, in testing the concept of a scramjet engine.

stories.abstract: Board investigating destruction of space shuttle Columbia warns that, before shuttles return to flight, NASA must develop better ways to inspect aging fleet and have photos taken by outside agencies during every mission; chairman Harold W Gehman Jr hopes interim report will enhance safety; Admr Sean O'Keefe says agency is already moving to comply (M)

headline.main: Investigators Propose Changes Before the Next Shuttle Flight

stories.snippet: Before space shuttles return to flight, NASA needs to develop better ways to inspect its aging fleet and ensure that pictures by outside agencies are taken on every mission, the independent board investigating the loss of the shuttle Columbia said...

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ with MATTHEW L. WALD

stories.lead_paragraph: Before space shuttles return to flight, NASA needs to develop better ways to inspect its aging fleet and ensure that pictures by outside agencies are taken on every mission, the independent board investigating the loss of the shuttle Columbia said today. The preliminary recommendations, the first to be formally issued by the Columbia accident investigation board, will be part of a final report to be issued this summer.

stories.abstract: Letter from Paul Hill, lead flight director for NASA's Return to Flight mission, comments on space shuttle risks (July 9 article)

headline.main: Space Shuttle Risks

stories.snippet: To the Editor:    As lead flight director for NASA's Return to Flight mission, I wish to respond to ''NASA Rescue Plan Is Reported to Have High Risk of Failure'' (news article, July 9).
stories.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As lead flight director for NASA's Return to Flight mission, I wish to respond to ''NASA Rescue Plan Is Reported to Have High Risk of Failure'' (news article, July 9).

stories.abstract: Pentagon concludes that Marines' V-22 Osprey is ready to return to flight testing; says manufacturers, Boeing and Bell Textron, have successfully addressed major problems that caused two crashes and killed 23 marines (M)

headline.main: Osprey Ready For New Tests Next Month, Pentagon Says

stories.snippet: The Pentagon has concluded that the Marines' V-22 Osprey is ready to return to flight testing next month.    The Defense Department said in a status report to Congress today that the manufacturers had successfully addressed the major problems that...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon has concluded that the Marines' V-22 Osprey is ready to return to flight testing next month. The Defense Department said in a status report to Congress today that the manufacturers had successfully addressed the major problems that caused two crashes and killed 23 marines.

stories.abstract: Investigators analyzing breakup of space shuttle Columbia say plasma gas probably vaporized part of aluminum frame of spacecraft, which may have exploded like a bomb; also look into whether workers created problem with fuel tank in summer and fall of 2002, when it had to be separated from orbiter and reattached with new rocket boosters; say they still face long investigation, but may be able to detect some problems in shuttles and make recommendations for changes before issuing report, making it easier for shuttle to return to flight; photo; drawing shows deterioration in reinforced carbon panel of leading edge of wing of shuttle Atlantis after flight from November 2002 (M)

headline.main: Investigators Looking at Whether Burning Aluminum Caused Explosion in Shuttle

stories.snippet: Investigators analyzing the breakup of the shuttle Columbia said today that plasma gas had probably vaporized part of the aluminum skeleton of the spacecraft, which may have exploded like a bomb.     Members of the board that is investigating the...

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD and JOHN SCHWARTZ

stories.lead_paragraph: Investigators analyzing the breakup of the shuttle Columbia said today that plasma gas had probably vaporized part of the aluminum skeleton of the spacecraft, which may have exploded like a bomb. Members of the board that is investigating the accident said they were rethinking the model they had been using to understand it by focusing on the possibility that some of the aluminum in the shuttle's frame burned, rather than melted.

stories.abstract: Air Force Col Richard O Covey, former astronaut who co-chairs panel that will oversee space shuttle's return to flight in wake of Columbia disaster, says he is not sure when NASA will be able to achieve that goal and that agency will not be 'schedule driven'; panel has spent recent days studying plan calling for launching shuttle Atlantis as early as March as demonstration flight to test safety procedures (M)

headline.main: Panel Unsure When NASA Can Return Shuttle to Flight

stories.snippet: The panel that will oversee the space shuttle's return to flight said today that it was not sure when NASA could achieve that goal but that time was not of the essence.     ''To say, 'All right, we can have all our work done at a particular time,'...

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ with WARREN E. LEARY

stories.lead_paragraph: The panel that will oversee the space shuttle's return to flight said today that it was not sure when NASA could achieve that goal but that time was not of the essence. ''To say, 'All right, we can have all our work done at a particular time,' isn't quite possible yet,'' said Col. Richard O. Covey of the Air Force, a former astronaut who is co-chairman of the 26-member panel. It has spent recent days at the Johnson Space Center here studying the plan to return to flight.

stories.abstract: Close-up photographs of earth taken from space by commercial ventures are seen as a boon for mining companies, mapmakers, geologists, city planners, ecologists, farmers, hydrologists, road makers, journalists, land managers, disaster-relief officials and others seeking to monitor planet's changing face; they also pose questions of practicality, security and privacy; photo of Taj Mahal taken from space by Space Imaging Inc's orbiting camera (M)

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; We're Ready for Our Close-Ups Now

stories.snippet: WHEN Jeffrey K. Harris was head of the National Reconnaissance Office in the mid-1990's, his agency's satellites routinely peered down on the world's hot spots from outer space and photographed them for federal intelligence agencies. It was all...
stories.lead_paragraph: WHEN Jeffrey K. Harris was head of the National Reconnaissance Office in the mid-1990's, his agency's satellites routinely peered down on the world's hot spots from outer space and photographed them for federal intelligence agencies. It was all supersecret and all dedicated to national security. Now Mr. Harris has a new job and a new agenda. As president of Space Imaging Inc., a private company in Thornton, Colo., he wants to get rich by selling photographs taken by his company's satellite camera -- the first in the world to rival military reconnaissance in accuracy and sharpness.

stories.abstract: Photo of International Space Station taken from space shuttle Endeavour

headline.main: Rooms Available, Earth View

stories.snippet: Photo of International Space Station taken from space shuttle Endeavour

stories.abstract: Photos of Earth taken from space shuttle Columbia

headline.main: PLANET EARTH: SO CLOSE, SO FAR

stories.snippet: Photos of Earth taken from space shuttle Columbia

stories.abstract: Article on issue of whether photos taken from space should be considered art, topic of discussion at symposium at American Museum of Natural History organized by Hayden Planetarium and New York University's Institute for Humanities; photo (M)

headline.main: Abstraction in a Celestial Palette, Courtesy of Robots and Outer Space

stories.snippet: While images of Mars, Jupiter and Saturn filled a giant screen in the background, speakers ruminated on the topic of interplanetary photography. It resolves specks of distant light into places of astonishing form and beauty, it opens the eyes of...
stories.lead_paragraph: While images of Mars, Jupiter and Saturn filled a giant screen in the background, speakers ruminated on the topic of interplanetary photography. It resolves specks of distant light into places of astonishing form and beauty, it opens the eyes of science to discovery, but is it art? Specifically, can pictures taken by spacecraft millions of miles away from their human masters truly be deemed art?

stories.abstract: Col James D Halsell Jr of Air Force, astronaut who will be in charge of planning resumption of shuttle flights, asserts that NASA had failed to see trend in shedding of foam from external tank, despite similar incident a few months before Columbia accident, because agency thought it had solved problem years earlier; photo (M)

headline.main: Official Says NASA Erred on Tank Problem

stories.snippet: The astronaut who will be in charge of planning the resumption of shuttle flights said today that NASA had failed to see a trend in the shedding of foam from the external tank, despite a similar incident a few months before the Columbia accident,...
stories.lead_paragraph: The astronaut who will be in charge of planning the resumption of shuttle flights said today that NASA had failed to see a trend in the shedding of foam from the external tank, despite a similar incident a few months before the Columbia accident, because the agency thought that it had solved the problem years earlier. If the Columbia had returned home safely, the shedding of its foam at liftoff would have been treated as a top-level safety problem, because it so closely followed similar shedding from the Atlantis's external tank in October 2002, and the two incidents together would have been recognized as a ''generic'' problem, said the official, Col. James D. Halsell Jr. of the Air Force.

stories.abstract: NASA investigation team says inadequate application and repair of insulation foam on space shuttle Discovery probably contributed to shedding of foam on July liftoff (S)

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Nasa Team Comments On Foam

stories.snippet: Inadequate application and repair of insulation foam on the space shuttle Discovery probably contributed to the shedding of foam on liftoff in July, a NASA investigation team reported. Richard Gilbrech, the team's head, said workers might have...
stories.lead_paragraph: Inadequate application and repair of insulation foam on the space shuttle Discovery probably contributed to the shedding of foam on liftoff in July, a NASA investigation team reported. Richard Gilbrech, the team's head, said workers might have crushed the foam while making repairs or damaged it by overhandling. The tank received more work than previous ones because of modifications after the loss of the shuttle Columbia, which was doomed by a foam-shedding accident in 2003.

stories.abstract: NASA officials express optimism that shuttle Discovery ascended to orbit with no damage and significantly less shedding of foam debris than in previous flights; astronauts begin their detailed inspection of spacecraft for possible damage; NASA official sounds note of caution and says more data will be collected and closer examination of craft will continue over next few days (M)

headline.main: NASA Aides Optimistic On Status Of Shuttle

stories.snippet: So far, the shuttle Discovery appeared to have come through its ascent to orbit with no damage and less shedding of foam debris than in previous flights.

multimedia.caption: Slide Show: Discovery's Liftoff
multimedia.credit: The space shuttle Discovery successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Tuesday, July 4, at 2:38 p.m.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: The space shuttle Discovery successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Tuesday, July 4, at 2:38 p.m.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ and WARREN E. LEARY; John Schwartz reported from Houston for this article, and Warren E. Leary from Florida

stories.lead_paragraph: NASA engineers and managers expressed optimism Wednesday that the shuttle Discovery had come through its ascent to orbit with no damage and substantially less shedding of foam debris from the external tank than in previous flights. ''People are very excited that they have not been surprised by anything,'' said John Shannon, shuttle deputy program manager, after a briefing with reporters.

stories.abstract: NASA officials say Hurricane Katrina has thrown more uncertainty into space shuttle program by damaging two major Gulf Coast facilities and leaving many of its workers homeless; NASA was preparing for March launch, but now officials dismiss idea of keeping to schedule; work continues on problem of shuttle's shedding of foam insulation from external fuel tank (M)

headline.main: Storm's Punch Has Knocked Shuttle Timetable 'Off Kilter'

stories.snippet: NASA officials said that Hurricane Katrina had thrown more uncertainty into the space shuttle program by damaging two facilities and leaving many of its workers homeless.
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA officials said yesterday that Hurricane Katrina had thrown more uncertainty into the space shuttle program by damaging two major Gulf Coast facilities and leaving many of its workers homeless. William H. Gerstenmaier, head of NASA's space operations, had just begun to prepare the schedule for a launching in March and said it was too early to rule out that target. But the hurricane ''has thrown all that activity off kilter a little bit,'' Mr. Gerstenmaier said at a telephone news conference.

stories.abstract: NASA managers say they will extend mission of space shuttle Atlantis for spacewalk to repair problem that could cause heating damage during re-entry; announcement comes as astronauts James F Reilly II and John D Olivas wrap up complex spacewalk of more than six hours (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Mission Extended To Fix Insulation Blanket

stories.snippet: NASA managers said that they would extend the mission of the space shuttle Atlantis for a spacewalk to repair a problem that could cause damage during re-entry.
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA managers said Monday night that they would extend the mission of the space shuttle Atlantis for a spacewalk to repair a problem that could cause heating damage during re-entry. The announcement came during a briefing for reporters as astronauts James F. Reilly II and John D. Olivas were wrapping up a complex spacewalk of more than six hours.

stories.abstract: Astronauts Piers J Sellers and Michael E Fossum from space shuttle Discovery take seven-and-a-half hour spacewalk to repair malfunctioning railway transporter on outside of International Space Station and test whether shuttle's robot arm and sensor boom can be used as work platform; repair work is not complete, but test of boom was successful; photo (M)

headline.main: 2 Astronauts Do Repairs and Tests on Lengthy Spacewalk

stories.snippet: Two astronauts from the shuttle Discovery did some repair work to the International Space Station and tested the shuttle's robot arm.
stories.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts from the shuttle Discovery took a seven-and-a-half-hour walk outside on Saturday, doing a bit of repair work to a malfunctioning part of the International Space Station and testing whether the shuttle's robot arm and sensor boom can be used as a work platform. The two astronauts, Piers J. Sellers and Michael E. Fossum, began easing out of the space station's Quest airlock at 9:17 a.m. Eastern time and returned at 4:48 p.m.

stories.abstract: NASA managers decide not to send astronauts on spacewalk to repair small gouge in belly of space shuttle Endeavor; determine that gouge poses no danger after exhaustive scrutiny; astronauts will proceed with planned work on International Space Station (M)

headline.main: NASA Rules Out Spacewalk To Repair Gouge in Shuttle

stories.snippet: NASA managers decided on Thursday night not to send astronauts on a spacewalk to repair a gouge on the bottom of the space shuttle Endeavour.
stories.lead_paragraph: Convinced that a small gouge in the belly of the space shuttle Endeavour poses no danger, NASA managers decided last night not to send astronauts on a spacewalk to repair it. Astronauts will proceed with previously planned work on the International Space Station, including a spacewalk scheduled for tomorrow. The Endeavour will return to Earth next week. Landing is scheduled for Wednesday.

stories.abstract: Dr Bradley E Schaefer, Louisiana State University physics professor, reports discovery of pictorial representation of Hipparchus' star catalogue completed in 129 BC on statue known as Farnese Atlas; report, presented at American Astronomical Society, holds that sky represented on sculpture best reflects sky of 125 BC, which is in perfect line with Hipparchus' work; Hipparchus' star catalogue text has not been seen for centuries and discovery offers best representation of lost astronomical work to date; photos (M)

headline.main: Visions of Ancient Night Sky Were Hiding in Plain Sight for Centuries

stories.snippet: A professor has found a pictorial representation of Hipparchus' star catalog, the long-lost, earliest known compendium of the night sky.
stories.lead_paragraph: Two thousand years later, astronomers still talk about Hipparchus' star catalog, the earliest known compendium of the night sky. Hipparchus, who lived in Greece during the second century B.C., was perhaps the world's first great astronomer. He calculated, within six and a half minutes, the length of a year. He figured out that Earth's axis wobbles as it spins. For his star catalog, completed in 129 B.C., he devised a coordinate system to plot each star's location and a scale to rank the brightness. Astronomers still use this magnitude scale today.

stories.abstract: Dr Mark Whittle, University of Virginia astronomy professor, has recreated sound of cosmos after Big Bang using computer models to generate cosmic chords and tweaking of data to human audible range; findings and soundtrack, which condenses first million years into five seconds, were presented at American Astronomical Society meeting; photo (M)

headline.main: The Baby Universe's First Cry: A Million Years in 5 Seconds

stories.snippet: If the universe is created with a bang but no one is around to witness it, does it still make a sound?    Some 13.7 billion years later, Dr. Mark Whittle, a professor of astronomy at the University of Virginia, says yes.
stories.lead_paragraph: If the universe is created with a bang but no one is around to witness it, does it still make a sound? Some 13.7 billion years later, Dr. Mark Whittle, a professor of astronomy at the University of Virginia, says yes.

stories.abstract: Two reports on planetary systems are presented at American Astronomical Society in Washington, one in which brown dwarf 65 times as massive as Jupiter orbits sunlike star 58 lightyears from Earth and one in which planet orbits extremely large star -- one that has already burned its hydrogen fuel and is dying; cosmic bubbles, fountains and halos are subjects of other presentations; photos (M)

headline.main: Fountains and Bubbles: New Cosmic Mysteries

stories.snippet: With the whole cosmos as its agenda, the meeting of the American Astronomical Society last week in Washington was a sounding board for scientists with new findings and ideas about nearly everything from mysterious gamma ray bursts in deep space to...
stories.lead_paragraph: With the whole cosmos as its agenda, the meeting of the American Astronomical Society last week in Washington was a sounding board for scientists with new findings and ideas about nearly everything from mysterious gamma ray bursts in deep space to revealing images penetrating the turbulent heart of the Milky Way, Earth's home galaxy. Two new discoveries described at the meeting underscored the growing and bewildering realization that planetary systems abound in the nearby universe and that they come in all shapes and sizes, bearing little apparent resemblance to the Sun's family of planets.

stories.abstract: Dr Philip Massey of Lowell Observatory leads international team of astronomers studying stars KW Sagitarii, KY Cygni and V354 Cephei, red supergiants; findings, which were presented at American Astronomical Society meeting, describe swelling of already massive stars as they near end of life; each of three stars is believed to be more than billion miles wide (M)

headline.main: 3 Giant Stars May Point the Way to Our Sun's Destiny

stories.snippet: Three red supergiant stars have caught the attention of astronomers because they appear to be the biggest stars known, and possibly the biggest possible for a normal star.
stories.lead_paragraph: KW Sagitarii is not the brightest star in the Milky Way, or the heaviest or densest. Neither are two other stars, KY Cygni and V354 Cephei. But these three red supergiant stars have caught the attention of astronomers because they appear to be the biggest stars known, and possibly the biggest possible for a normal star. (Another supergiant, VV Cephei, may be even larger, but that one has been distorted by the gravity of a companion star.)

stories.lead_paragraph: The National Association of Orchestra Leaders has filed papers supporting the management of the Apollo Theater in a labor dispute with musicians who work on the program ''Amateur Night at the Apollo,'' officials said yesterday. In a letter to Grace Blake, the executive director of the Apollo Foundation, Charles Peterson, the treasurer of the orchestra leaders association, called the attempts by band members to organize a union ''illegal and unlawful practices.''

headline.main: Just Another 17-Year-Old Who Has Her Own Label

stories.snippet: Gabrielle Ross may be dedicated to her music, but she’s not exactly a slick self-promoter.
stories.lead_paragraph: GABRIELLE ROSS may be dedicated to her music, but she's not exactly a slick self-promoter. She was discovered, after all, on karaoke night at Broccoli Garden, a Chinese restaurant in Levittown. ''I'm very into my career, but I'm also a down-to-earth girl from Long Island,'' Ms. Ross, 17, who lives in Bellmore, explained before performing at a Patti LaBelle tribute in Harlem last month. ''I don't have psycho stage parents or anything like that.''

stories.abstract: Bill Vaughan, supervisory electronics engineer and manager of Federal Aviation Authority's Airway Facilities Tower Integration Laboratory at Atlantic City International Airport, answers questions about its operations; photo (On the Map column) (M)

headline.main: Testing the Virtual View From a Mock Airport Tower

stories.snippet: Newark Airport will be getting a new, 335-foot-high control tower in November 2002.  But before the construction started in 1999, Federal Aviation Agency engineers and air traffic controlers who would be working in the tower wanted to make sure...
stories.lead_paragraph: Newark Airport will be getting a new, 335-foot-high control tower in November 2002. But before the construction started in 1999, Federal Aviation Agency engineers and air traffic controlers who would be working in the tower wanted to make sure nothing would block their view. To find out, they went to the Airway Facilities Tower Integration Laboratory at the F.A.A.'s William Hughes Technical Center at Atlantic City International Airport. There, using mockups of a cab, or tower interior, plus panoramic photographs or coumpter-generated images on six-foot-high wrap-around display panels, computer scientists and electrical engineers can simulate the view from any airport control tower, including air traffic and weather conditions. The virtual Newark tower is a 240-degree photographic image that includes Elizabeth, Newark, New York City and Newark Bay and the turnpike bridge. Bill Vaughan, the supervisory electronics engineer who manages the laboratory, talked about his operation.

stories.abstract: Dr Harry Janes, research professor and director of greenhouse at Rutgers University's Cook College, answers questions on year-round tomato harvests; photo (On the Map column) (M)

headline.main: Poised to Raise Real Jersey Tomatoes, Year Round

stories.snippet: Just as home gardeners are putting away the tomato cages, those at the experimental agriculture station greenhouse in Bordentown operated by Cook College of Rutgers University are preparing to harvest their first tomatoes of the season. The workers...
stories.lead_paragraph: Just as home gardeners are putting away the tomato cages, those at the experimental agriculture station greenhouse in Bordentown operated by Cook College of Rutgers University are preparing to harvest their first tomatoes of the season. The workers there not only hope to produce a steady stream of tomatoes to be sold to King's Supermarkets in northern New Jersey throughout the winter, but they also hope the tomatoes will be as good as any that are picked in the Jersey fields at the peak of summer. The greenhouse, next to the landfill at the Burlington County Resource Center, is in the middle of its third year of operation. Dr. Harry Janes, a research professor and director of the greenhouse, which is next to the landfill at the Burlington Country Resource Center, talked recently about the operation. Q. How is your tomato greenhouse different from others?

headline.main: Princeton Will Keep an Eye Out for a Cosmic Greeting

stories.snippet: In a month or so a telescope at the FitzRandolph Observatory at Princeton University will start looking for laser communications sent by extraterrestrial life. The SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence) project will be a community effort...
stories.lead_paragraph: In a month or so a telescope at the FitzRandolph Observatory at Princeton University will start looking for laser communications sent by extraterrestrial life. The SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence) project will be a community effort with professors, undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, local residents, high school students and amateur astronomers taking part. Dave Wilkinson, a Princeton physics professor who is leading Princeton Oseti (Optical Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence), spoke about the project. Q. How is this different from other SETI projects?

headline.main: Firefighters Are Ready to Rescue a Space Shuttle in Distress

stories.snippet: Space shuttles  launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., commonly head south, but  for resupply missions to the International Space Station, they  head north. If such a  shuttle were to get in trouble, one of the three places on the East Coast where  it...
stories.lead_paragraph: Space shuttles launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., commonly head south, but for resupply missions to the International Space Station, they head north. If such a shuttle were to get in trouble, one of the three places on the East Coast where it can make an emergency landing is the New Jersey Air National Guard's 177th Fighter Wing Base at Atlantic City International Airport. There, firefighters attached to the 177th Wing will get the astronauts out in a hurry. Tech. Sgt. Joseph Bannon, one of those firefighters, talked about the rescue plans. Q. Why did NASA choose the base at Atlantic City National International Airport?

stories.abstract: Julie Lew article on visiting new $76 million Chabot Space and Science Center, Oakland, Calif, premier astronomy and space museum; photos (M)

headline.main: Opening a Window on the Universe

stories.snippet: AT 45 degrees, it was a chilly November evening in the hills above Oakland, Calif., yet I waited in line patiently with 300 others for nearly an hour to peer at a bunch of sparkly dots that resembled a tiny pile of granulated sugar. One by one, we ...
stories.lead_paragraph: AT 45 degrees, it was a chilly November evening in the hills above Oakland, Calif., yet I waited in line patiently with 300 others for nearly an hour to peer at a bunch of sparkly dots that resembled a tiny pile of granulated sugar. One by one, we filed into a silver-domed observatory and climbed a ladder to look into the lens of a 20-inch telescope named Rachel, one of the largest refractors in the western United States open to the public. Tonight's target was M-15, a group of about 250,000 stars almost 40,000 light-years away. To put it into mind-boggling perspective, one light-minute is equal to a little more than 11 million miles, and despite this almost unfathomable distance, M-15 is still within the Milky Way. This age-old human fascination with our place in an infinite universe is the foundation upon which the new $76 million, 86,000-square-foot Chabot Space and Science Center was built. It is one of the premier astronomy and space museums in the country, with exhibits, equipment and science programs that have earned it an affiliation with the Smithsonian Institution. The center opened in August and is still a work in progress, but what is currently available will satisfy the most ardent stargazer.

stories.abstract: Dragon Skies: Astronomy of Imperial China, some of world's oldest stargazing tools and timepieces, are on display for first time time in US at Chabot Space and Science Center in Oakland, Calif; photo (M)

headline.main: Tools for Ancient Eyes To View the Heavens

stories.snippet: Some of the world's oldest stargazing tools, used by the royal astronomers of ancient China, are on display in Oakland, Calif., in their first appearance in the United States, at the Chabot Space and Science Center. Through Jan. 2, the hilltop...
stories.lead_paragraph: Some of the world's oldest stargazing tools, used by the royal astronomers of ancient China, are on display in Oakland, Calif., in their first appearance in the United States, at the Chabot Space and Science Center. Through Jan. 2, the hilltop observatory will showcase 32 artifacts, many of them original, and 13 interactive displays that make up ''Dragon Skies: Astronomy of Imperial China.'' China's royal astronomers were among the first to chart constellations and record the passing of comets, eclipses and supernovas, creating some of the earliest known continuous written logs of celestial events, dating at least as far back as 1500 B.C.

stories.abstract: Growing numbers of regional museums are assuming more prominent role in nation's science curriculum, filling in gaps in formal science education as more and more schools struggle to keep pace with grueling new federal and state standards; Chabot Space and Science Center in Oakland, Calif, has evolved from small museum and observatory to multifaceted science center; its million-dollar Challenger Mission Center described; photos (M)

headline.main: This Is the Mission: Fill Gap for Schools, Lift Students to Skies

stories.snippet: As more schools struggle to keep pace with grueling new federal and state standards, science centers are playing a bigger role than ever in science education.
stories.lead_paragraph: THE year is 2061. The mission, which is accepted with a mixture of trepidation and giddiness, is to launch a probe into the tail of Halley's comet. Twenty-seven astronauts and mission specialists will carry out the work of Challenger, 75 years after its namesake exploded upon liftoff. The isolation team uses robotic arms to test hazardous materials. The life support team quashes an oxygen depletion emergency. And the navigation team successfully triangulates the comet using a computerized grid on a star field. When the mission is done, these fifth graders slap high-fives, clear the air lock and bolt outside for lunch.

stories.abstract: Chabot Space and Science Center in Oakland, Calif, to open to public on August 19; live and recorded star shows will be presented at planetarium equipped with one of world's most advanced star projectors; photos (M)

headline.main: Star-Gazing at a Higher and Sharper Level

stories.snippet: Amateur astronomers and other sky watchers will have a new West Coast spot to stargaze from when the Chabot Space and Science Center, an 86,000-square-foot facility in the hills of Oakland, Calif., opens Aug. 19.    While the center covers a broad...
stories.lead_paragraph: Amateur astronomers and other sky watchers will have a new West Coast spot to stargaze from when the Chabot Space and Science Center, an 86,000-square-foot facility in the hills of Oakland, Calif., opens Aug. 19. While the center covers a broad range of sciences, the focus is on astronomy and space exploration. An observatory complex houses 8- and 20-inch refractor telescopes (the bigger the telescope, the clearer the view) that were relocated from the center's former facility. A new 36-inch reflector, one of the largest public telescopes in the country, will be installed sometime next year.

stories.abstract: China pledges to return to space within one or two years, just hours after safe return of Shenzhou 5 and astrounaut Yang Liwei (M)

headline.main: Elated, China Promises Another Space Flight in a Year or Two

stories.snippet: Within hours of the safe return of the Shenzhou 5 early Thursday, China pledged to return to space within one or two years, as officials outlined a short-term space agenda that included space walks, space docking and the possible construction of a...
stories.lead_paragraph: Within hours of the safe return of the Shenzhou 5 early Thursday, China pledged to return to space within one or two years, as officials outlined a short-term space agenda that included space walks, space docking and the possible construction of a space lab or space station. The swift commitment underscored the confidence and enthusiasm infused into the space program by the Shenzhou 5 mission, which established China as the third nation to send an astronaut into space.

stories.abstract: NASA, even before independent panel issues report on Columbia space shuttle disaster, has apparently decided that no enormously time-consuming changes will be needed for shuttle fleet to return to space; hopes to resume missions to International Space Station, perhaps as early as Dec, after fixes to shuttle hardware; is also shuffling management of manned spaceflight program (M)

headline.main: NASA Hoping to Fly Shuttle After Fixing Some Hardware and Shifting Managers

stories.snippet: Even before the independent panel issues its report on the disaster that claimed the space shuttle Columbia and its crew of seven, NASA has apparently concluded that no enormously time-consuming changes will be required before the shuttle fleet...

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD with JOHN SCHWARTZ

stories.lead_paragraph: Even before the independent panel issues its report on the disaster that claimed the space shuttle Columbia and its crew of seven, NASA has apparently concluded that no enormously time-consuming changes will be required before the shuttle fleet returns to space, perhaps as early as December. The report by the Columbia Accident Investigation Board is tentatively scheduled for release in a month, and NASA officials say it might include problems they are not yet aware of. But they say that with fixes to the shuttle hardware, they should be able to resume missions to the International Space Station. They are also shuffling the management of the manned spaceflight program.

stories.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column agrees with those who say Columbia disaster should mark end of whole space shuttle program; says space flight has been huge boon to mankind, but almost all the payoff from space travel, scientific and practical, has come from unmanned vehicles and satellites; says sad truth is that for many years NASA has struggled to invent reasons to put people into space; says it is open secret that only real purpose of International Space Station is to provide reason to keep flying space shuttles; says someday, when cost-effective way is found to get people into orbit and back, man should return to space (M)

headline.main: A Failed Mission

stories.snippet: Some commentators have suggested that the Columbia disaster is more than a setback -- that it marks the end of the whole space shuttle program. Let's hope they're right.    I say this with regret. Like millions of other Americans, I dream of a day...
stories.lead_paragraph: Some commentators have suggested that the Columbia disaster is more than a setback -- that it marks the end of the whole space shuttle program. Let's hope they're right. I say this with regret. Like millions of other Americans, I dream of a day when humanity expands beyond Earth, and I'm still a sucker for well-told space travel stories -- I was furious when Fox canceled ''Firefly.'' I also understand that many people feel we shouldn't retreat in the face of adversity. But the shuttle program didn't suddenly go wrong last weekend; in terms of its original mission, it was a failure from the get-go. Indeed, manned space flight in general has turned out to be a bust.

stories.abstract: NASA Admr Michael D Griffin announces shuttle Discovery will return to space on July 13; expresses confidence in agency and craft, which will carry 15 tons of supplies and equipment to International Space Station; crew will test new procedures for inspecting shuttle's fragile skin for damage and for repairing damage; Columbia Accident Investigation Board describes all space flight as having some inherent risks (M)

headline.main: After 2 Years on Ground, Shuttle Is Set to Fly in July

stories.snippet: NASA will return Discovery to space, the first space shuttle flight since the Columbia tragedy.

multimedia.caption: Shuttle Launching Is Set
multimedia.credit: NASA said it planned to return the shuttle Discovery to space on July 13, carrying material to the International Space Station.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: NASA said it planned to return the shuttle Discovery to space on July 13, carrying material to the International Space Station.

stories.lead_paragraph: NASA will return the shuttle Discovery to space in two weeks, after almost two and a half years on the ground since the loss of the shuttle Columbia, officials said Thursday. ''Based on a very thorough and very successful flight readiness review, we are currently 'go for launch' of Discovery on July 13,'' said Michael D. Griffin, the administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

stories.abstract: Article on buying memory foam mattress, based on technology developed by NASA; H Thomas Bryant, president of North American operations at Tempur-Pedic, manufacturer of foam mattresses, says foam provides support that conventional mattresses cannot match; photo (M)

headline.main: The Sleep of Forgetfulness (And the Bed Remembers)

stories.snippet: Having trouble falling asleep? Mattresses promoting technology developed by NASA may help.
stories.lead_paragraph: IF you have flipped through a magazine or turned on the television or radio lately, you may have encountered advertisements for mattresses promoting technology developed by NASA. Most people don't associate spaceships with a good night's sleep. After all, who could doze off knowing that there was nothing but a thin layer of metal between them and oblivion?

stories.abstract: Photo of Antquarium, high-tech ant habitat developed by NASA scientists (Currents column)

headline.main: Itching to Know How Ants Live in Outer Space?

stories.snippet: A new high-tech ant habitat called the Antquarium features sheer plexiglass siding and a transparent blue gel developed by NASA scientists to aid in the study of ants under zero gravity. (The gel serves as both their home and their food.) The...
stories.lead_paragraph: A new high-tech ant habitat called the Antquarium features sheer plexiglass siding and a transparent blue gel developed by NASA scientists to aid in the study of ants under zero gravity. (The gel serves as both their home and their food.) The Antquarium is three and a half inches wide and five inches tall and comes with a magnifying glass and an ant trap for those enterprising enough to catch their own colony; ants are also available by mail. Available for about $30 at stores including F. A. O. Schwarz in New York, (212) 644-9400; the gift shop at the Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago, (773) 753-6297; and www.hearthsong.com. KATHERINE E. NELSON

stories.abstract: Concern for Kids, global charity, and investment company Crestridge are co-developing system that recycles contaminated water into clean, inexpensive drinking water; base design for system was developed by NASA for future space flights; NASA's version, which has to meet different needs than land-based water system, is still being tested, but Concern for Kids hopes to begin processor production in next six months (M)

headline.main: Meant for Space, but Useful on Earth

stories.snippet: NASA is testing a device that would recycle astronauts' sweat, urine and even the moisture from their breath into drinking water.
stories.lead_paragraph: After nearly two decades of research, NASA is testing a device that would recycle astronauts' sweat, urine and even the moisture from their breath into drinking water. It may be two years before the system, as large as two refrigerators, is loaded on a shuttle to serve the astronauts aboard the International Space Station. But smaller and simpler versions will soon be used on Earth, the space agency said.

stories.abstract: Among scientific and technical research projects lost with destruction of space shuttle Columbia are many submitted by schoolchildren across the country and abroad; this is part of educational program developed by NASA to fire immiginations of young (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE STUDENTS
headline.main: Hopes for Experiments Disappear as Disaster Unfolds

stories.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia had many things in its hold when it soared into the Florida sky last month, including basic examples of schoolyard curiosity. There were some marbles, some crayons, a few insects, a lot of plant seeds, and even Central Park...
stories.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia had many things in its hold when it soared into the Florida sky last month, including basic examples of schoolyard curiosity. There were some marbles, some crayons, a few insects, a lot of plant seeds, and even Central Park pond water -- all to answer one of childhood's most fundamental questions: What happens to stuff in space? In recent years NASA has developed an educational program designed to fire the imaginations of the young whenever flaming engines propel one of its spaceships skyward. That is why, besides dozens of technical experiments prepared by scientists and tucked away in the bays of Columbia, there were also projects from, among others, a preschool class in New Freedom, Pa., and a 4-H club in Sacramento.

stories.abstract: National Taiwan University and Chang Gung University researchers have discovered that cinnamon oil is natural larvicide that may be useful in controlling mosquitoes; findings, published in Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, suggest oil can be sprayed over standing water where mosquitos breed; Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and European colleagues tag four beaked whales to track their habits; beaked whales, which have teeth and use echolocation to navigate, are found to dive to depths of 4,150 feet, where they dine on squid and deepwater fish; findings are reported in Royal Society of London journal Biology Letters; National Aeronautics and Space Administration and European imaging specialists develop free plug-in for photoshop that enables individuals to copy astronomical images, which use format called FITS, and create photoshop image; Dr Andrew H Bass, Cornell University neurobiology and behavior professor, and Dr Joseph Sisneros of University of Washington lead study on midshipman fish breeding habits; study, published in journal Science, finds that female fish secrete hormones that alter their hearing during breeding season to better hear males sustained mating calls; researchers hold that study could have impact on studies of human hearing; drawing (M)
