stories.lead_paragraph: Directed by Toni Myers Not rated, 47 minutes ''Space Station 3-D,'' the latest film to be photographed for the giant-screen Imax process in three dimensions, is apparently narrated by Tom Cruise. At least, that's what the credits say, though the images are so overwhelming that it's hard for a viewer to recollect very much of what Mr. Cruise says or how he says it.

headline.main: Is That a Space Helmet Or Just Your 3D Goggles?

stories.snippet: THE Canadian filmmaker Toni Myers was enjoying some much-needed R & R when her cell phone rang. Colonel James S. Voss was checking in from the International Space Station with a surprising development: ''I've shot six seconds of aliens!,'' he...
stories.lead_paragraph: THE Canadian filmmaker Toni Myers was enjoying some much-needed R & R when her cell phone rang. Colonel James S. Voss was checking in from the International Space Station with a surprising development: ''I've shot six seconds of aliens!,'' he announced from 220 miles above earth. Aliens? As producer and director of ''Space Station 3D,'' the new large-format 3D release from Imax, Ms. Myers had developed an advance ''shopping list'' of set-ups and situations, and aliens were no part of the scenario. The project was documentary in character and proud of it. Still, Ms. Myers had encouraged the orbiting crew members to contribute their own suggestions. Col. Voss's extraterrestrials, she learned much later, were stowaways from the ground: children's toys, cool totems of home, hanging out happily in zero-G.

stories.abstract: Board of Directors of Boys Choir of Harlem asks for resignation of founder and director Walter J Turnbull and his brother Horace, choir's executive vice pres, for ignoring complaint of 14-year-old student that he was molested repeatedly by school's chief counselor; Turnbulls said to have feared for reputation of school if news got out; investigators say both Turnbulls let counselor Frank Jones Jr stay in contact with students even after city officials explicitly banned him from 650-student Boys Choir of Harlem Academy, public school that is overseen and financed in part by Dept of Education; only after student's mother went to authorities was Jones arrested, tried, convicted and sent to prison on two-year term for sexual abuse; abuse victim has filed $20 million lawsuit against city, school, Dept of Education, his abuser and several choir officials, including Turnbulls; photos (M)

headline.main: Boys Choir Founder Faulted for Inaction In Sex Abuse Case

stories.snippet: It was the spring of 2001 when an employee of the Boys Choir of Harlem went to Walter J. Turnbull, the founder and director of the world-renowned group, with shocking news: a 14-year-old student in the choir's academy had just accused the school's...
stories.section_name: Front Page; Education; New York and Region

byline.original: By ALAN FEUER and ROBIN POGREBIN; Susan Saulny and Howard Stier contributed reporting for this article

stories.lead_paragraph: It was the spring of 2001 when an employee of the Boys Choir of Harlem went to Walter J. Turnbull, the founder and director of the world-renowned group, with shocking news: a 14-year-old student in the choir's academy had just accused the school's chief counselor of having molested him repeatedly for years. The police were not called. Afraid for his beloved institution, Dr. Turnbull chose instead to meet with the boy, investigators for the city say. The boy asked that the counselor be dismissed. ''You don't make that decision,'' investigators say Dr. Turnbull replied. The counselor remained, and the school did not investigate, investigators say.

stories.abstract: Internet-based branding campaign promoting Houston features what some might consider city's deficits: heat, humidity, hurricanes, flying cockroaches, oil refineries and flooding; campaign, financed in part by Michael Zilkha, wealthy entrepreneur and patron of arts in Houston, uses slogan Houston: It's Worth It, and relies on descriptions of urban afflictions and images of giant mosquitoes and cockroaches to convey sense of how Houston is nevertheless beloved by many residents; photo (M)

headline.main: Selling Houston Warts and All, Especially Warts

stories.snippet: The heat. The humidity. The hurricanes. The flying cockroaches. The refineries. The flooding. The list of factors that make this city challenging, particularly in the steamy month of August, goes on, many Houstonians acknowledge.      Yet perhaps...
stories.lead_paragraph: The heat. The humidity. The hurricanes. The flying cockroaches. The refineries. The flooding. The list of factors that make this city challenging, particularly in the steamy month of August, goes on, many Houstonians acknowledge. Yet perhaps only in Houston -- a city founded in 1836 by two entrepreneurs from New York who described their muddy location as ''well watered'' and ''salubrious'' (one founder, John Kirby Allen, died of congestive fever in 1838) -- could a list of such drawbacks be turned into a marketing campaign.

stories.abstract: Earth will fly in mid-November through debris left behind by comet Tempel-Tuttle, producing Leonid meteor shower; astronomers predict that nighttime pyrotechnics of this year's Leonids will be lull between last year's impressive display over Europe and Middle East and much more prolific streaking in 2001 and 2002; photo (M)

headline.main: Getting Ready for the Sky to Fall Again

stories.snippet: For the first time in three years, Dr. Peter Jenniskens this year will watch the Leonid meteors with his feet on the ground.    Each year in mid-November, the Earth flies through debris left behind by the comet Tempel-Tuttle. The Leonid meteors -- so...
stories.lead_paragraph: For the first time in three years, Dr. Peter Jenniskens this year will watch the Leonid meteors with his feet on the ground. Each year in mid-November, the Earth flies through debris left behind by the comet Tempel-Tuttle. The Leonid meteors -- so named because they appear to radiate out of the constellation Leo -- are comet crumbs that burn up in streaks of light as they slam in the Earth's atmosphere at 155,000 miles per hour. Some of the larger, marble-size meteors end their journeys exploding in impressive fireballs.

stories.abstract: Venus will transit Sun on June 8, 2004, for first time since 1882; small black dot of Venus will be visible from many places around world, but best vantage points for full transit will be in Europe and Middle East; December 6, 1882, transit was used by scientists to try and determine distance between Sun and Earth; such work was which is needed to implement formulas of 17th century astronomer Johannes Kepler; viewing became popular event for many people and was prominently featured in newspapers and magazines; next Venus transit will be on June 6, 2012; drawings (L)

headline.main: Venus Returns for Its Shining Hour

stories.snippet: The world is about to witness a rare spectacle that once launched expeditions to ideal vantage points around the globe and inspired millions of people to venture outside and stare at the heavens.    On June 8, people in the right places on Earth will...
stories.lead_paragraph: The world is about to witness a rare spectacle that once launched expeditions to ideal vantage points around the globe and inspired millions of people to venture outside and stare at the heavens. On June 8, people in the right places on Earth will be able to see Venus move across the face of the Sun in a kind of minieclipse that is visible twice every century or so. The last such occurrence, called a transit of Venus, was in 1882. It inspired an international effort to use the event to answer one of the most pressing scientific questions of the day: What is the exact distance between the Sun and Earth?

stories.abstract: Report commissioned by Center for Naval Analyses warns that human-driven climate warming poses risks to national security of United States; warns that effects of warming could lead to large-scale migrations, increased border tensions, spread of disease and conflicts over food and water, all of which could lead to direct involvement by US military; recommends that climate change be integrated into security strategies (M)

headline.main: Global Warming Called Security Threat

stories.snippet: A report written by a group of retired generals and admirals says that issues usually associated with the environment are also national security concerns.

byline.original: By ANDREW C. REVKIN and TIMOTHY WILLIAMS

stories.lead_paragraph: For the second time in a month, private consultants to the government are warning that human-driven warming of the climate poses risks to the national security of the United States. A report, scheduled to be published on Monday but distributed to some reporters yesterday, said issues usually associated with the environment -- like rising ocean levels, droughts and violent weather caused by global warming -- were also national security concerns.

stories.abstract: Supplies of food and water on International Space Station have fallen so low that two astronauts there are asked to curb their intake; if Russian cargo vessel scheduled to arrive on Dec 25 has mishap or is delayed, astronauts will have to return home ahead of schedule; plans are being put together for crew to leave if necessary (M)

headline.main: With Food Running Low, Space Crew Must Cut Back

stories.snippet: The two astronauts aboard the International Space Station have been asked to curb their calories because of a food shortage, NASA officials said.
stories.lead_paragraph: The two astronauts on the International Space Station have been asked to curb their calories because of a food shortage, NASA officials said Thursday. Supplies of food and water on the station have fallen so low that if a Russian cargo vessel scheduled to arrive on Dec. 25 has a mishap or is significantly delayed, the astronauts, one American and one Russian, will have to abandon the station and return home months ahead of schedule, the NASA officials said.

Johnson Space Center, told reporters that he had spoken at length with the crew that arrived at the International Space Station in November.

stories.abstract: Benjamin Genocchio reviews exhibit JFK and Art at Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn; photo (M)

headline.main: In the Eyes of Artists: Responses to Kennedy

stories.snippet: JOHN F. KENNEDY fascinated and inspired artists in a way no other American president has done. Partly this was because of his youthful good looks, beautiful family and extraordinary charisma, and partly because he carried with him so many hopes for a...
stories.lead_paragraph: JOHN F. KENNEDY fascinated and inspired artists in a way no other American president has done. Partly this was because of his youthful good looks, beautiful family and extraordinary charisma, and partly because he carried with him so many hopes for a brighter, better future. To many Americans, including artists, he seemed like the model president. Coinciding with the 40th anniversary of Kennedy's assassination on Nov. 22, 1963, the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich is presenting ''J.F.K. and Art,'' an exhibition of artistic responses to the man, his myth and legacy. It is the first exhibition in the United States to explore this theme, and is accompanied by a catalog with some new scholarship.

stories.abstract: A O Scott reviews movie Million Dollar Baby, directed by Clint Eastwood and starring Hilary Swank, Morgan Freeman and Eastwood; photos (M)

headline.main: 3 People Seduced by the Bloody Allure of the Ring

stories.snippet: Clint Eastwood's drama about a grizzled boxing trainer and a spunky young fighter is the best movie released by a major Hollywood studio this year.
stories.lead_paragraph: Clint Eastwood's ''Million Dollar Baby'' is the best movie released by a major Hollywood studio this year, and not because it is the grandest, the most ambitious or even the most original. On the contrary: it is a quiet, intimately scaled three-person drama directed in a patient, easygoing style, without any of the displays of allusive cleverness or formal gimmickry that so often masquerade as important filmmaking these days. At first glance the story, about a grizzled boxing trainer whose hard heart is melted by a spunky young fighter, seems about as fresh as a well-worn gym shoe. This is a Warner Brothers release, and if it were not in color (and if the young fighter in question were not female), ''Million Dollar Baby,'' with its open-hearted mixture of sentiment and grit, might almost be mistaken for a picture from the studio's 1934 lineup that was somehow mislaid for 70 years.

stories.abstract: A O Scott reviews Space Cowboys, movie directed by Clint Eastwood; photo (M)

headline.main: Voices of Experience, Rocketing to the Rescue

stories.snippet: ''Space Cowboys'' begins in 1958, with jaunty western guitar music on the soundtrack and black-and-white vistas of the big sky and empty land around Edwards Air Force Base in the California desert. The first scenes follow the adventures of a group of...
stories.lead_paragraph: ''Space Cowboys'' begins in 1958, with jaunty western guitar music on the soundtrack and black-and-white vistas of the big sky and empty land around Edwards Air Force Base in the California desert. The first scenes follow the adventures of a group of reckless young pilots who crash their expensive military plane, bicker and fight among themselves and lose the chance to be the first Americans in space to a chimpanzee named Mary Ann and a new civilian agency called NASA. There is something odd about the four smooth-faced, jaunty young men who make up Team Daedalus, as the pilots are known. Their faces have the clean, generic good looks we've come to associate with the bygone days of the Eisenhower administration, but their voices have the rasp of hard experience, as well as an uncanny familiarity, since they belong to Tommy Lee Jones, Donald Sutherland, James Garner and, most recognizably, Clint Eastwood, who also directed the picture.

stories.abstract: NASA officials express doubt that piece of foam insulation from external fuel tank that struck space shuttle Columbia during January 16 launching from Cape Canaveral could have led to destruction of ship during reentry into earth's atmosphere on February 1 killing all seven astronauts on board; shuttle program manager Ron Dittemore says material is too light to cause fatal damage and that investigators are seeking 'missing link' to explain disaster; dismisses speculation that piece of foam could have been saturated with water or encrusted with ice heavy enough to magnify damage it did to heat-dissipating tiles on underside of left wing; defends engineering study, conducted during 16-day mission, which concluded that damage from foam debris would not affect flight safety; says crew was involved in discussions about spacecraft being hit by debris and did not raise concerns about damage to craft; photos (M)

headline.main: OBSERVATORY

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PROCEEDINGS OF THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCES

stories.snippet: Look-Alike Tuna and Shark      In consumer electronics, the buzzword of the moment is convergence. It used to be, for instance, that you had your cellphone and you had your organizer, and never the twain did meet. Now both gadgets have evolved to be...
stories.lead_paragraph: Look-Alike Tuna and Shark In consumer electronics, the buzzword of the moment is convergence. It used to be, for instance, that you had your cellphone and you had your organizer, and never the twain did meet. Now both gadgets have evolved to be pretty much the same; your cellphone contains your datebook, and you can make calls from your organizer. Convergence can happen in nature, too. Consider the case of lamnid sharks, like the mako and the great white, and tuna. They have evolved separately for about 400 million years, and in some ways are about as different as fish can be. The tuna has bones, the other has only cartilage. But they have the same streamlined body shape, and both have a tall tail fin that is attached to the body at a narrow point .

stories.abstract: Benedict Nightingale travel article on plays, both British and American, to be presented on British stages this spring and summer; photos (M)

headline.main: Europe Festivals 2002; In London, Stoppard Joins the Americans

stories.snippet: ANY new play by Tom Stoppard is sure to cause a stir, but when the dramatist comes up with three at once, theatergoers could be forgiven for going stir-crazy. Certainly, his ''Coast of Utopia,'' which opens in late July at the National Theater, looks...
stories.lead_paragraph: ANY new play by Tom Stoppard is sure to cause a stir, but when the dramatist comes up with three at once, theatergoers could be forgiven for going stir-crazy. Certainly, his ''Coast of Utopia,'' which opens in late July at the National Theater, looks like the major dramatic event of the British summer. The trilogy is his first work for the theater since ''The Invention of Love'' in 1997. That play, a major success in both London and New York, emerged from months of research into classical scholarship, Victorian attitudes to homosexuality and the life of its main character, the gay scholar and poet A. E. Housman. This time, Stoppard's serendipitous mind has turned to idealists and revolutionaries in 19th-century Russia. We should expect an educated but, let's hope, entertaining trip through a nation and a family in political muddle and turmoil.

stories.lead_paragraph: A NASA engineer whose e-mail messages to colleagues warned of potentially catastrophic consequences from in-flight damage to the space shuttle Columbia said yesterday that the exchanges were hypothetical and not meant to predict the accident that destroyed the shuttle. The engineer, Robert H. Daugherty of NASA's Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., said in a telephone news conference that his messages were given adequate consideration by space agency officials and that there was no indication they were shoved aside or not taken seriously.

stories.abstract: NASA administrator Sean O'Keefe says tests suggest that damage to space shuttle Columbia's wing that may have led to craft's destruction was so subtle that very detailed inspection methods to detect such flaws before and during flights will have to be developed (M)

headline.main: Tests Show Need to Overhaul Shuttle Checks, Official Says

stories.snippet: Tests suggest that damage to the space shuttle Columbia's wing that may have led to the craft's destruction was so subtle that NASA will have to develop very detailed inspection methods to detect such flaws before and during flights, the agency's...
stories.lead_paragraph: Tests suggest that damage to the space shuttle Columbia's wing that may have led to the craft's destruction was so subtle that NASA will have to develop very detailed inspection methods to detect such flaws before and during flights, the agency's administrator said today. The administrator, Sean O'Keefe, said he was sobered by the minuscule size of breaches in the leading edge of a test wing subjected to the impact of insulation foam at high speed, much as the Columbia was shortly after liftoff.

stories.abstract: House and Senate leaders, working behind closed doors, struggle to resolve differences on $388 billion spending bill that would squeeze dozens of domestic programs and favor a few; White House officials, under pressure to show progress in reducing budget deficit, threaten that Pres Bush would veto any measure that exceeded spending limits set earlier this year (M)

headline.main: Congressional Leaders Work On Compatible Spending Bill

stories.snippet: House and Senate leaders struggled to resolve differences on a $388 billion bill that would squeeze dozens of domestic programs.
stories.lead_paragraph: Working behind closed doors, House and Senate leaders struggled Thursday to resolve differences on a $388 billion spending bill that would squeeze dozens of domestic programs and favor a few. Under pressure to show progress in reducing the budget deficit, White House officials threatened that President Bush would veto any measure that exceeded the spending limits set earlier this year. But they also warned lawmakers not to shortchange some of Mr. Bush's priorities, like his plan for preliminary work on a mission to Mars.

stories.abstract: Article on turmoil over accounting and reserve reporting by Royal Dutch/Shell, oil giant that traces roots to Dutch oil company and English seashell importer in 1890's; Sir Philip Watts, who rose to top three years ago with program to increase reported reserves, has been ousted amid revelations that company increased its oil and gas reserves not by discovering new sources but by changing accounting to add reserves that may not be usable; estimates of proven reserves have now been cut by 20 percent, 3.9 billion barrels, and SEC is investigating on behalf of American investors; internal documents and interviews with industry experts describe company that in 1990's was under market pressure to show 'correct performance' on reserves that were actually declining because discoveries did not keep pace with production; retired manager Colin Allcard recalls defined targets and 'motivational schemes' as company came under pressure of low prices and competition from larger rivals BP Amoco and Exxon Mobil, which were building reserves with discoveries, mergers and strategic alliances; photo (M)

headline.main: At Shell, New Accounting and Rosier Oil Outlook

stories.snippet: Arriving on stage in a spaceship and an astronaut suit, Philip Watts, then the senior executive in charge of exploration and production for the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, glowed as he delivered a message of optimism to a conference of 600 company...

byline.original: By STEPHEN LABATON and JEFF GERTH; Heather Timmons, in London, contributed reporting for this article

stories.lead_paragraph: Arriving on stage in a spaceship and an astronaut suit, Philip Watts, then the senior executive in charge of exploration and production for the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, glowed as he delivered a message of optimism to a conference of 600 company executives in the Dutch city of Maastricht in June 1998. ''I have seen the future and it was great,'' he declared.

stories.abstract: NASA is one of few agencies to get budget increase for fiscal 2006, five percent rise to $16.2 billion, but Bush administration officials say more than $1 billion needed for mission to repair Hubble Space Telescope will not be part of package; NASA Administrator Sean O'Keefe's Jan 2004 decision on grounds of safety not to allow shuttle repair mission to orbiting observatory resulted in wave of criticism and NASA began developing plan to use robot device for repairs (M)

headline.main: Money to Fix Space Telescope May Be Cut by White House

stories.snippet: A service mission to extend the life of the Hubble Space Telescope could be jeopardized by a White House plan to cut NASA's budget.
stories.lead_paragraph: A much-anticipated service mission to extend the life of the Hubble Space Telescope could be jeopardized by a White House plan to eliminate funding for it from NASA's 2006 budget request, government officials said. Officials in the Bush administration and in Congress, who asked not to be identified because the budget has not been officially sent to Congress, said NASA was one of the few agencies that would get a proposed budget increase next year. However, a mission to service Hubble, estimated to exceed $1 billion, will not be part of that package, they said.

stories.abstract: NASA records show that emergency plan to use International Space Station as safe haven for shuttle astronauts whose craft cannot safely return to earth carries high risk of failure; says station lacks adequate support systems and supplies for its occupants and shuttle crew to survive for more than few months at best and few weeks at worst, not enough time to perform rescue; information underscores risk inherent in space travel; some NASA employees say safety remains afterthought (M)

headline.main: NASA Rescue Plan Is Reported to Have High Risk of Failure

stories.snippet: NASA's emergency plan to use the International Space Station as a safe haven for shuttle astronauts whose craft cannot safely return to earth would carry a high risk of failure if it were ever tried, according to internal space agency documents.    ...
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA's emergency plan to use the International Space Station as a safe haven for shuttle astronauts whose craft cannot safely return to earth would carry a high risk of failure if it were ever tried, according to internal space agency documents. The documents say the space station lacks adequate support systems and supplies to assure that its own occupants and a shuttle crew could stay alive for more than a few months at best and a few weeks at worst -- not enough time, under many possible situations outlined in the documents, to carry off a rescue plan.

stories.abstract: Deborah Solomon interview with performance artist Laurie Anderson, whose new one-woman show The End of the Moon is based on her stint as artist in residence at NASA; Photo (m)

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 1-30-05: QUESTIONS FOR LAURIE ANDERSON
headline.main: Post-Lunarism

stories.snippet: The performance artist talks about spending a year at NASA, what she loves about space and what she hates about Broadway.
stories.lead_paragraph: Q: Your new one-woman show, ''The End of the Moon,'' is based on your stint as an artist in residence at NASA. Why would a performance artist known for her iconoclasm want to visit mission control in Houston? As sad as I am about being in the United States these days, NASA is genuinely exciting. I keep thinking what it would be like to be a kid in this country. I think it would be really depressing, except for NASA.

stories.abstract: Profile of and interview with performance artist Laurie Anderson, 57, who comments on her space-struck new show, the End of the Moon, and her stint as National Aeronautics and Space Administration's first artist in residence; photo (M)

headline.main: Inviting the Cosmos Onto the Stage

stories.snippet: Laurie Anderson's "End of the Moon" is the creative result of her "secret dream" come true  a two-year stint as NASA's official artist.
stories.lead_paragraph: Laurie Anderson has often made futuristic technology a defining feature of her performances. The video for her crossover 1980 pop hit, ''O Superman,'' depicted her trademark gadget: a mouth light that emitted a brilliant beam as she sang in a robotic, computer-modulated voice. ''Songs and Stories From Moby-Dick'' (1999), one of her most elaborate productions, toured with 40 tons of video, sound and light gear, including digital musical instruments that she helped design. So when she received a call in 2002 from someone who claimed to be from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, asking her to be the space agency's first ''artist in residence,'' she hung up the phone. ''I was sure it was a fan who had figured out my secret dream,'' she said.

stories.abstract: James Oestreich reviews book Stravinsky and Balanchine: A Journey of Invention by Charles M Joseph; photo (M)

Gottlieb summarized recently in The New York Observer, ''but much of what's replacing him comes from a very different, often antagonistic, aesthetic.''

stories.abstract: National Aeronautics and Space Administration selects design team led by TRW Inc to build Next Generation Space Telescope; new observatory, half as big as Hubble telescope, will have light-gathering mirror six times the size of Hubble and suite of more sensitive instruments; launch is planned for 2010; drawing; diagrams (M)

headline.main: New Eyes in Space, Even Sharper Than Hubble's

stories.snippet: Even in astronomy, there are some tough acts to follow. After parting a curtain to the universe with the Hubble Space Telescope and allowing millions to experience previously hidden wonders in space, what do you do for an encore?    The National...
stories.lead_paragraph: Even in astronomy, there are some tough acts to follow. After parting a curtain to the universe with the Hubble Space Telescope and allowing millions to experience previously hidden wonders in space, what do you do for an encore? The National Aeronautics and Space Administration last week revealed its choice for the next stage in expanding human vision into deep space. The agency announced that it would build the long-discussed Next Generation Space Telescope, selecting the design of a team led by TRW Inc., for a successor to Hubble to be launched in 2010. The new observatory, while only half as big as the 24,000-pound Hubble, will have a primary, light-gathering mirror 20 feet in diameter compared with the existing telescope's 8-foot reflector. With a mirror that has a light gathering area six times as large as the Hubble's and a suite of more sensitive instruments, the new telescope should be able to detect objects a hundredth the brightness Hubble can see in visible light and one four-hundredth the brightness in the infrared part of the light spectrum.

stories.abstract: NASA will launch next-generation space observatory in 2010 that will study light produced in earliest days of universe; awards $824.8 million contract to team led by TRW Inc; observatory, to be named after James Edwin Webb, pioneering NASA administrator, will have six times light-gatering areas as Hubble Space Telescope, whose mission ends in 2010; Webb Observatory will be positioned in area of space called Lagrange Point 2, where gravity of Earth and Sun are in balance and spacecraft can maintain its orbit with little rocket adjustment (M)

headline.main: Next-Generation Space Telescope Chosen to Peer Into Past

stories.snippet: NASA chose a successor to the Hubble Space Telescope today, announcing that it would launch a next-generation space observatory in 2010 that would study light produced in the earliest days of the universe.    The space agency selected TRW Inc., of...
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA chose a successor to the Hubble Space Telescope today, announcing that it would launch a next-generation space observatory in 2010 that would study light produced in the earliest days of the universe. The space agency selected TRW Inc., of Redondo Beach, Calif., to lead a team that will build the observatory, which will be called the James Webb Space Telescope in honor of a pioneering NASA administrator. The TRW design won out over a proposal by a group led by Lockheed Martin Space Systems.

stories.abstract: Scientists gathered at Cambridge University to mark Dr Stephen W Hawking's 60th birthday with weeklong workshop on theoretical physics and cosmology are still puzzled by his 1973 discovery that black holes can leak energy and particles into space; photos (M)

headline.main: Hawking's Breakthrough Is Still an Enigma

stories.snippet: In the fall of 1973 Dr. Stephen W. Hawking, who has spent his entire professional career at the University of Cambridge, found himself ensnared in a horrendous and embarrassing calculation. Attempting to investigate the microscopic properties of...
stories.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1973 Dr. Stephen W. Hawking, who has spent his entire professional career at the University of Cambridge, found himself ensnared in a horrendous and embarrassing calculation. Attempting to investigate the microscopic properties of black holes, the gravitational traps from which not even light can escape, Dr. Hawking discovered to his disbelief that they could leak energy and particles into space, and even explode in a fountain of high-energy sparks. Dr. Hawking first held off publishing his results, fearing he was mistaken. When he reported them the next year in the journal Nature, he titled his paper simply ''Black Hole Explosions?'' His colleagues were dazzled and mystified.

stories.abstract: Astonomers using Hubble Space Telescope study mysterious antigravity force that sent galaxies hurtling away from each other; force, known as dark energy, provides clues to mystery that has thrown physics and cosmology into turmoil over last decade; data suggest that dark energy has changed little over course of cosmic history, lending support to conventional theory that source of cosmic antigravity is cosmological constant that Einstein used in his 1917 equations, but later rejected (M)

headline.main: 9 Billion-Year-Old 'Dark Energy' Reported

stories.snippet: Astronomers have discovered that billions of years before a mysterious antigravity overcame cosmic gravity and sent the galaxies scooting apart, it was already present in space, affecting the evolution of the cosmos.
stories.lead_paragraph: A strange thing happened to the universe five billion years ago. As if God had turned on an antigravity machine, the expansion of the cosmos speeded up, and galaxies began moving away from one another at an ever faster pace. Now a group of astronomers using the Hubble Space Telescope have discovered that billions of years before this mysterious antigravity overcame cosmic gravity and sent the galaxies scooting apart like muscle cars departing a tollbooth, it was already present in space, affecting the evolution of the cosmos.

stories.abstract: Editorial lauds launching of American and two Russian astronauts from Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan to dock with new International Space Station and become its first inhabitants; says more pressing task will be to design high-quality research agenda for $60 billion engineering project lest it remain structure in search of mission (S)

headline.main: Opening the Space Station

stories.snippet: There was something anticlimactic about yesterday's launch of an American and two Russians toward the International Space Station, whose first linked modules are now circling 240 miles overhead, ready to be activated and expanded. The huge $60...
stories.lead_paragraph: There was something anticlimactic about yesterday's launch of an American and two Russians toward the International Space Station, whose first linked modules are now circling 240 miles overhead, ready to be activated and expanded. The huge $60 billion engineering project has been delayed repeatedly, and when the astronauts were finally sent aloft from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, the venture got limited attention in an America absorbed in its closest presidential race in years. Even so, if all goes well in coming years, this could mark the start for Americans of continuous operations in space as opposed to intermittent shuttle trips. This page has been lukewarm about the station from the beginning, feeling that it would be enormously costly and yield only limited scientific returns, most of which could be gained by satellites and unmanned probes to the solar system. Many of the claims advanced for the station -- such as the opportunity it provides to grow perfect crystals in the absence of gravity and to perform other exquisite manufacturing tasks -- have been hyped beyond reason and debunked by expert committees. But that does not mean there is no value at all in the enterprise. The fact that 16 nations are collaborating on the American-led project is a diplomatic achievement, as is the participation of Russian space and rocket scientists who might otherwise be tempted to put their skills to malevolent use. Once the station is fully assembled and running, scientists may learn more about how astronauts react, physically and mentally, to extended periods in space. The astronauts will master the skills for assembling big structures in space.

stories.abstract: Russian and American astronauts prepare to blast off from Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan to dock with new orbiting International Space Station on four-month shakedown mission to make it habitable; US astronaut Capt William M Shepherd will enter craft as first commander; Russian cosmonaut Yuri P Gidzenko will command Soyuz spacecraft on two-day trip to station; will control rendezvous and docking; Sergei K Krikalev will serve as flight engineer; $60 billion space station being constructed by 16 nations led by US and Russia is currently 143-foot-long structure of linked modules weighing 162,000 pounds; will be expanded to mass of 1 million pounds over next five years, covering area larger than football field and will include at least four major scientific modules (M)

headline.main: Russian and U.S. Crew Ready To Blast Off to Space Station

stories.snippet: A patient crew of astronauts is ready to blast off to the International Space Station to begin what could be more than 15 years when humans will continually occupy the orbiting outpost.    The three-man crew of astronauts from Russia and the United...
stories.lead_paragraph: A patient crew of astronauts is ready to blast off to the International Space Station to begin what could be more than 15 years when humans will continually occupy the orbiting outpost. The three-man crew of astronauts from Russia and the United States is scheduled to lift off aboard a Russian Soyuz rocket from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan at 2:53 a.m., Eastern time, on Tuesday. If all goes well, this Expedition One crew will dock with the new space station early Thursday to begin a four-month shakedown mission to make the spacecraft habitable.

stories.abstract: Two new satellite surveys show that warming air and water are causing Antarctica to lose ice faster than it can be replenished by interior snowfall, thus contributing to rising global sea levels; studies differ significantly in estimates of how much water is being added to oceans this way (S)

headline.main: Loss of Antarctic Ice Increases

stories.snippet: Two satellite surveys show that Antarctica is losing ice faster than it can be replenished, and thus is contributing to rising sea levels.
stories.lead_paragraph: Two new satellite surveys show that warming air and water are causing Antarctica to lose ice faster than it can be replenished by interior snowfall, and thus are contributing to rising global sea levels. The studies differed significantly in estimates of how much water was being added to the oceans this way, but their authors both said that the work added credence to recent conclusions that global warming caused by humans was likely to lead to higher sea levels than previous studies had predicted.

stories.abstract: Initial ground tests of air from International Space Station suggest that environmental conditions aboard it are good, easing recent concern among some engineers; Russians conducted tests on air samples returned last month and other samples of air and water await testing (M)

headline.main: Space Station Environment Is Safe, Tests Show, Easing Worries

stories.snippet: Initial ground tests of air from the International Space Station suggest that environmental conditions aboard it are good, easing a recent concern among some engineers, NASA officials said Friday.    William Gerstenmaier, the agency's station program...
stories.lead_paragraph: Initial ground tests of air from the International Space Station suggest that environmental conditions aboard it are good, easing a recent concern among some engineers, NASA officials said Friday. William Gerstenmaier, the agency's station program manager, said that Russian scientists had thoroughly tested air samples returned last month with the previous station crew and found them acceptable. NASA representatives observed the testing and confirmed the thoroughness of the results, he said.

stories.abstract: Multiple roles played by top Pengaton and government officials, who have joined ranks of military contractors as executives, board members and lobbyists, are coming under closer scrutiny after former top Air Force official Darleen Druyun negotiated lucrative job contract with Boeing Co while still overseeing Boeing business; Edward C Aldridge, who worked under Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld until last year and now sits on board at Lockeed Martin, which gets more than $20 billion each yeaer in military contracts, is coming under scrutiny for possible conflict of interest; chart; photo (M)

headline.main: Pentagon Brass and Military Contractors' Gold

stories.snippet: Edward C. Aldridge's storied career exemplifies the dizzying spins of the revolving door between the Pentagon and its military contractors. He has been secretary of the Air Force, president of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and, most recently, an...
stories.lead_paragraph: Edward C. Aldridge's storied career exemplifies the dizzying spins of the revolving door between the Pentagon and its military contractors. He has been secretary of the Air Force, president of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and, most recently, an under secretary of defense. Now, he is a member of the Lockheed Martin Corporation board, a detail that did not prevent him from being named to head President Bush's commission on space exploration. Lockheed is one of NASA's biggest contractors, and only Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, objected and called for Mr. Aldridge's removal, complaining of conflict of interest.

stories.abstract: Federal prosecutors widen investigation into questionable tax shelters involving Paul Daugerdas and colleagues Erwin Mayer and Donna Guerin, former tax lawyers at Jenkens & Gilchrist of Dallas; widening of probe indicates law firms, banks and investment firms that aided accounting firms in such shelters are coming under scrutiny; three lawyers have been accused of writing hundreds of legal opinion letters in recent years that blessed aggressive tax shelters sold by accounting firms and, in some cases, by law firm itself, that did not meet approval of Internal Revenue Service (M)

headline.main: Inquiry Into Tax Shelters Widens Beyond Audit Firms

stories.snippet: Paul M. Daugerdas, the tax lawyer at the heart of a broadening federal investigation into questionable tax shelters, has long had an interest in space exploration, colleagues say.
stories.lead_paragraph: Paul M. Daugerdas, the tax lawyer at the heart of a broadening federal investigation into questionable tax shelters, has long had an interest in space exploration, colleagues say. In 1999, the year he established the Chicago office of the Dallas law firm of Jenkens & Gilchrist, he, along with thousands of others, had his name engraved on two microchips that were tucked inside an unmanned spacecraft named Stardust. A section of that NASA probe will wander space forever.

stories.abstract: NEAR Shoemaker, first spacecraft to land on asteroid, gets reprieve from scheduled communications shutdown and will stay in contact with Earth little longer; NASA officials extend mission by 10 days to allow more data to be collected; photo (M)

headline.main: Mission Extended for Surprisingly Sturdy Little Spacecraft

stories.snippet: The first spacecraft to land on an asteroid got a reprieve from a scheduled communications shutdown today and will stay in contact with Earth a little longer.    NASA officials said they decided to extend the mission of the NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft...
stories.lead_paragraph: The first spacecraft to land on an asteroid got a reprieve from a scheduled communications shutdown today and will stay in contact with Earth a little longer. NASA officials said they decided to extend the mission of the NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft by 10 days to allow more data to be collected from the 1,100-pound craft that unexpectedly survived touchdown on the asteroid Eros on Monday in remarkably good condition.

stories.abstract: Mars Phoenix Lander, which is scheduled to be first spacecraft to land in polar region of Mars, is primarily designed to look for signs of liquid water; is stationary laboratory capable of analyzing eight square yards of surface area around craft; Peter H Smith, University of Arizona researcher and mission's principal scientist, describes exploration as vertical rather than horizontal as Phoenix is expected to dig deep in surface of Mars; drawing; photos (M)

headline.main: NASA to Begin Digging Mission on Northern Pole of Mars

stories.snippet: The Mars Phoenix Lander will stay on one spot of the Martian arctic and use a mechanical arm to explore the area in detail.
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA is about to launch a scientific laboratory to Mars that will be the first spacecraft to land in the northern polar region of the planet and dig for evidence of water or other conditions that could support some form of life. The spacecraft, Mars Phoenix Lander, is set to launch from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on a Delta II rocket during a three-week window that opens Friday. If the 770-pound lander touches down safely after its 10-month journey, it will spend three months or longer probing the ground and monitoring the weather above.

stories.abstract: Astrologers say that demoting Pluto to dwarf status will not make any difference, even though they were quite excited in 2006 about discovery of potential 10th planet Xena; they say that discovery of planet raises public consciousness and that Pluto's energy has already been felt; drawing (M)

headline.main: It's Not the Planet, Silly, It's the Energy

stories.snippet: Not that there is any reason to expect astrologers to be consistent, but why is it that adding a planet changes things, but subtracting one doesn’t?
stories.lead_paragraph: Last year, astrologers were wild about Xena -- that's the nickname astronomers had given to a recently discovered far-off icy rock that stood a good chance of becoming the solar system's 10th planet. They predicted great things for their astrological charts as Xena's orbit was plotted in ensuing years. But last week, when the International Astronomical Union announced at a meeting in Prague that Pluto had been demoted to dwarf status and that by the group's new calculations the solar system no longer contained even 9 planets, much less 10, astrologers said it wouldn't make any difference.

stories.abstract: Clyde Haberman NYC column says recent demotion of planet Pluto to 'dwarf planet' changes nothing about it but label; analogizes New Yorkers as true 'Plutocrats,' often facing officials who use 'linguistic gymnastics' to try and make tough situations appear to go away, like redefining 'on time' subway train as one that is no more than three minutes late (M)

headline.main: When the Skies Lose a Planet, A City Shrugs

stories.snippet: The astronomers' redefinition that demoted Pluto pretty much alters nothing, just as government officials often come up with redefinitions to try to make tough situations go away.
stories.lead_paragraph: IF you have followed Pluto's sad tale, you know by now that it metaphorically had the epaulettes ripped from its shoulders yesterday, the buttons yanked from its tunic, the sword snatched from its hand and snapped in two. No longer is Pluto an honest-to-goodness planet. The International Astronomical Union reduced it to a ''dwarf planet,'' unworthy of being ranked with its eight former siblings. Oh, the shame of it all.

stories.abstract: William J Broad essay supports idea that science and religion can coexist and cites recent discovery of scientific truth behind Oracle of Delphi's legendary powers; holds that many great scientists have also been religious individuals and one view does not preclude other; drawing (M)

headline.main: The Oracle Suggests a Truce Between Science and Religion

stories.snippet: The truth is that science and spirituality have the potential to coexist in peace, complementing rather than constantly battling each other.
stories.lead_paragraph: It may seem that the longstanding war between science and religion is entering a new phase: Darwin versus intelligent design, religious opposition to stem cell research, Western secularism versus Islamic fundamentalism. All around we see growing tensions between the scientific demand for truth through reason and experiment, and the religious desire for consolation and revealed truth. What seems like a clear trend, however, in fact misrepresents the underlying reality. We have indeed seen many conflicts over the centuries, vividly in the case of Galileo versus the church.

stories.abstract: Nine letters on July 25 article about books on science and religion; Michael J Gorman says that science without faith is empty; Derek Lessing and Patrick Enright hold that those who claim existence of God must provide proof of their assertion for it to be believed; Kenneth R Stunkel doubts that debate between science and religion will ever be resolved; Doug Fox suggests that scientists consider themselves to be agnostics; Carol Hamilton says that history of Christianity is not unique; William Payne contends that terms good and evil lack reference points without religion; Michael Hadjiargyrou says faith stems from man trying to understand physical world around him; William Horwitz suggests that article should have clarified difference between atheism and agnosticism; drawing (L)

headline.main: Reconciling Proof and Belief

stories.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Faith, Reason, God and Other Imponderables'' (Books on Science, July 25): It never ceases to amaze me how scientists condescendingly tolerate people who have what they consider an utterly irrational belief and faith in God...
stories.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Faith, Reason, God and Other Imponderables'' (Books on Science, July 25): It never ceases to amaze me how scientists condescendingly tolerate people who have what they consider an utterly irrational belief and faith in God and an afterlife. I think of myself as a rational person, practical and pragmatic. Like many people, I ask myself whether science or religion makes me happier and offers me more promise of happiness in the future.

stories.abstract: Pres George W Bush's order to redirect focus of National Aeronautics and Space Agency toward human exploration of Moon and Mars causes agency to shift allocation of time, energy and money away from space science; programs on understanding Sun and Earth interaction, climate change on earth and investigation of dark energy are among programs losing substantial funding, while new programs investigating moon and developing robotics and vehicles have been added; Dr David Spergel, member of NASA's space science advisory committee and Princeton University astronomer, holds that space science has been agency's crowning achievement and new focus on exploration may hold back scientific endeavors; many scientists are concerned about change in priority; drawing; graph (L)

headline.main: At NASA, Science Sharply Shifts Course

stories.snippet: After President Bush's order that NASA redirect its energies toward human exploration of the Moon and Mars, the space agency has drastically shifted its scientific priorities, delaying missions and cutting the projected budgets of programs that it...
stories.lead_paragraph: After President Bush's order that NASA redirect its energies toward human exploration of the Moon and Mars, the space agency has drastically shifted its scientific priorities, delaying missions and cutting the projected budgets of programs that it does not perceive as related to the exploration. Much attention has been focused on the decision to let the Hubble Space Telescope die by canceling the shuttle mission to maintain it. But in the meantime, whole fields of science have been demoted to asterisks on NASA budget projections over the next few years, leading many scientists to fear for the future of science in space.

stories.abstract: Venus will transit Sun on June 8, 2004, for first time since 1882; small black dot of Venus will be visible from many places around world, but best vantage points for full transit will be in Europe and Middle East; December 6, 1882, transit was used by scientists to try and determine distance between Sun and Earth; such work was which is needed to implement formulas of 17th century astronomer Johannes Kepler; viewing became popular event for many people and was prominently featured in newspapers and magazines; next Venus transit will be on June 6, 2012; drawings (L)

headline.main: Venus Returns for Its Shining Hour

stories.snippet: The world is about to witness a rare spectacle that once launched expeditions to ideal vantage points around the globe and inspired millions of people to venture outside and stare at the heavens.    On June 8, people in the right places on Earth will...
stories.lead_paragraph: The world is about to witness a rare spectacle that once launched expeditions to ideal vantage points around the globe and inspired millions of people to venture outside and stare at the heavens. On June 8, people in the right places on Earth will be able to see Venus move across the face of the Sun in a kind of minieclipse that is visible twice every century or so. The last such occurrence, called a transit of Venus, was in 1882. It inspired an international effort to use the event to answer one of the most pressing scientific questions of the day: What is the exact distance between the Sun and Earth?

stories.abstract: Soyuz rocket carrying American astronaut, Edward Lu, and Russian cosmonaut blasts off for international space station on mission intended to keep space exploration going despite Columbia space shuttle tragedy; rocket blasts off from Baikonur, Kazakhstan (S)

headline.main: American and Russian Blast Off Into Space

stories.snippet: A Soyuz rocket carrying an American astronaut and Russian cosmonaut blasted off for the international space station today on a mission intended to keep space exploration going despite the Columbia space shuttle tragedy.    From deep in the Kazakh...
stories.lead_paragraph: A Soyuz rocket carrying an American astronaut and Russian cosmonaut blasted off for the international space station today on a mission intended to keep space exploration going despite the Columbia space shuttle tragedy. From deep in the Kazakh steppe, the 130-foot Russian rocket, the latest version of the world's longest-serving manned spacecraft, soared into space at 7:54 a.m. on its way to the station, some 220 miles above Earth. Shortly after liftoff, the rocket was safely in orbit, space officials said.

stories.abstract: Two-person relief crew, American Dr Edward T Lu and Russian Yuri I Malenchenko, arrive at International Space Station and three-person crew, Americans Kenneth D Bowersox and Dr Donald R Pettit and Russian Nikolai M Budarin, prepare to depart after more than five months in space; Columbia shuttle disaster, which has suspended flights during crash investigation, necessitated pared down crew and halted construction efforts; mission will require smaller crew to conserve supplies, which are dwindling since shuttle suspension, to perform more routine station maintenance and operations and perform limited 200 hours of research; there are no expansion projects planned; current three-man crew will return to earth in Soyuz rescue capsule in first ever American astronaut landing outside of US scheduled for Kazakhstan; photo (M)

headline.main: 2-Man Crew, With Modified Duties, Reaches Space Station

stories.snippet: The pared-down relief crew arrived at the International Space Station today, just two men who will work to keep the massive project running in place until American space shuttles fly again and construction can resume.    Duties of this two-man crew...
stories.lead_paragraph: The pared-down relief crew arrived at the International Space Station today, just two men who will work to keep the massive project running in place until American space shuttles fly again and construction can resume. Duties of this two-man crew will differ greatly from those of its three-member predecessors: as a result of the grounding of the American shuttle fleet after the loss of the Columbia on Feb. 1, space station building has come to a halt and normal supply lines are choked. The new crew will have less time for research and will have to pay extra attention to food, water and other consumables, which are in increasingly short supply without regular shuttle visits.

stories.abstract: Problem with thruster on radar antenna mast on space shuttle Endeavour may force astronauts to cut short precise radar mapping of Earth (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; NASA May Cut Short Its Mapping of Earth

stories.snippet: A problem with a thruster on the radar antenna mast on the space shuttle Endeavour could force the astronauts to cut short their precise mapping of Earth.    Despite the flow of nitrogen gas, a small valve on the end of the mast jutting out of the...
stories.lead_paragraph: A problem with a thruster on the radar antenna mast on the space shuttle Endeavour could force the astronauts to cut short their precise mapping of Earth. Despite the flow of nitrogen gas, a small valve on the end of the mast jutting out of the shuttle cargo bay provided little if any thrust. To compensate, the shuttle's pilots had to fire the shuttle thrusters more than usual to keep the 197-foot mast, the longest rigid structure ever flown in space, in the right position.

stories.abstract: Engineers have come up with ways to save fuel aboard space shuttle Endeavour, making NASA optimistic that astronauts can complete their mapping of Earth (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; Conserving Fuel on High

stories.snippet: Engineers have come up with ways to save fuel aboard the space shuttle Endeavour, making NASA optimistic that the astronauts can complete their mapping of Earth.    For the last few days, the astronauts have been using more shuttle fuel than planned...
stories.lead_paragraph: Engineers have come up with ways to save fuel aboard the space shuttle Endeavour, making NASA optimistic that the astronauts can complete their mapping of Earth. For the last few days, the astronauts have been using more shuttle fuel than planned to keep a radar antenna mast with a faulty thruster pointed in the right direction. The ideas for conserving fuel include changes in shuttle maneuvers and in urine disposal.

stories.abstract: Replacement crew for International Space Station blasts off aboard Soyuz spacecraft from Baikonur Cosmodrome, Russia; American Leroy Chiao and Russian Salizhan Sharipov will relieve Gennady Padalka and NASA science officer Mike Finckea, who have been on station since Apr (S)

headline.main: Relief Crew Is on Its Way to Space Station

stories.snippet: A replacement crew for the International Space Station blasted off aboard a Soyuz spacecraft from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Russia.
stories.lead_paragraph: A replacement crew for the International Space Station blasted off aboard a Soyuz spacecraft from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Russia early today. The capsule will dock to the orbiting complex on Saturday.

stories.abstract: Russian veteran astronaut Col Gennadi I Padalka and NASA rookie Lt Col Edward Mike Fincke are preparing to blast off in Soyuz spacecraft from Baikonur Cosmodrome, Kazakhstan, on April 18; will replace crew of International Space Station; Russians have proposed that length of mission be extended to one year from six months; longer flights would help in preparations for proposed trips to Mars and Moon and provide Russia with opportunity to defray program costs by taking commercial passengers on flights; European Automated Transfer Vehicle, unpiloted cargo ship to service station, is due to start flights next year; photo, graph (M)

headline.main: Crew Prepares to Leave for Six Months at Space Station

stories.snippet: A fresh crew is about to depart for a six-month stay aboard the International Space Station, even as program officials consider extending their replacements' tour to a full year.    A veteran space traveler, Col. Gennadi I. Padalka of the Russian Air...
stories.lead_paragraph: A fresh crew is about to depart for a six-month stay aboard the International Space Station, even as program officials consider extending their replacements' tour to a full year. A veteran space traveler, Col. Gennadi I. Padalka of the Russian Air Force, and a rookie NASA astronaut, Lt. Col. Edward Mike Fincke of the Air Force, are to blast off for the station late Sunday aboard a Russian Soyuz spacecraft from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.

stories.abstract: Elvis Mitchell reviews movie The Alamo, directed by John Lee Hancock and starring Dennis Quaid, Billy Bob Thornton and Jason Patric; photos (M)

headline.main: A Mythic Last Stand Stripped of Fantasy

stories.snippet: The oppressively solemn film ''The Alamo'' marches in the line of earlier Disney-financed looks at historic moments like ''Pearl Harbor.'' In re-enacting, with a heavy heart and a heavy hand, the actual events surrounding the storied 1836 battle in...
stories.lead_paragraph: The oppressively solemn film ''The Alamo'' marches in the line of earlier Disney-financed looks at historic moments like ''Pearl Harbor.'' In re-enacting, with a heavy heart and a heavy hand, the actual events surrounding the storied 1836 battle in the war of independence fought by Texas against the Mexican forces of General Santa Anna, the movie is both elegiac and trivial. This is an accomplishment of sorts, generally of the sort that no one plans. The filmmakers' motivation is obviously to strip away the ennobling layers of lacquer applied to the lives of Davy Crockett, Jim Bowie and the others fighting to wrest Texas from Mexico and establish a republic -- a sheen polished by previous projects, including the poisonously intoxicating coats lavished by Disney's own ''Davy Crockett'' shows.

stories.abstract: Anita Gates reviews made-for-TV movie Evel Knievel, directed by John Badham and starring George Eads; photo (M)

headline.main: Leaping Tall Fountains at a Single Bound

stories.snippet: There are certain necessities in the film biography of a famous man. There must be a scene in which the man, drunk with his new success, drives his wife to the huge new house he has just bought (without consulting her, but only because he wants to...
stories.lead_paragraph: There are certain necessities in the film biography of a famous man. There must be a scene in which the man, drunk with his new success, drives his wife to the huge new house he has just bought (without consulting her, but only because he wants to surprise her). Later, there's the scene in which the wife, all alone in that house and justifiably sullen because of neglect, greets the husband, who has been out cavorting with adoring women, spending all his time on his career, or both. The table is set for a meal, which the great man missed hours ago. TNT's cookie-cutter movie ''Evel Knievel,'' which has its premiere tonight at 8, delivers both scenes in stupefyingly standard fashion. Seeing her new home, Jaime Pressly, as Linda Bork Knievel, says, ''It's so big,'' and, ''This just cost way too much money.'' Later, when Evel (George Eads) makes his first appearance after a night of kissing strange women's breasts and drinking, he appears in the doorway, with his shirt open to the waist. Linda is clearing away the breakfast dishes.

stories.abstract: Microwave Anistropy Probe (MAP), $145 million NASA satellite, will be launched in June to observe microwave background of universe, which scientists see as key to cosmology just as DNA is key to biology; will produce separate accountings of various kinds of matter in universe; may also provide new measure of how fast universe is expanding as legacy of Big Bang and detect clues to what set Big Bang off in first place; recent observations from balloons and from ground have produced doubts as to whether some predicted features of microwave background are missing and whether various experiments are in contradiction with one another on their results; may even hint at something crucially wrong in theory called inflation, picture of what happened in earliest moments of Big Bang supported by most experts; photos; drawing (L)

headline.main: In Big Bang's Echoes, Clues to the Cosmos

stories.snippet: A dappled glow from the explosive birth of the universe is teasing astronomers with its mysteries and apparent contradictions, as it has again and again since two scientists at Bell Laboratories in Holmdel, N.J., discovered it accidentally in 1965.  ...
stories.lead_paragraph: A dappled glow from the explosive birth of the universe is teasing astronomers with its mysteries and apparent contradictions, as it has again and again since two scientists at Bell Laboratories in Holmdel, N.J., discovered it accidentally in 1965. The discovery of this radiation, in the form of a hiss in the microwave part of the radio spectrum arriving from all directions of space, firmly cemented the Big Bang -- a picture in which the universe began in a great explosion more than 10 billion years ago -- in its current position as the leading theory of cosmic birth.

stories.abstract: Most precise, detailed map yet produced of universe just after its birth confirms Big Bang theory, revealing emergence of first stars in cosmos only 200 million years after Big Bang, some half billion years earlier than theorized; map supports strange picture that has emerged recently of universe expanding at ever-faster rate, pushed apart by mysterious 'dark energy'; astronomers now say universe is 13.7 billion years old and consists of 4 percent atoms, 23 percent dark matter and 73 percent dark energy, and is geometrically 'flat'; photos of images compiled by Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe satellite, which sees microwave energy left over from Big Bang; Dr Charles L Bennett of Goddard Space Flight Center led international team that built satellite and analyzed results; satellite was launched in June 2001 and has been orbiting Earth and recording cosmic emanations from point on other side of moon; astrophysicists explain findings at news conference at NASA headquarters in Washington; satellite has been named for project leader Dr David Wilkinson, Princeton cosmologist who died last Sept (M)

headline.main: Cosmos Sits for Early Portrait, Gives Up Secrets

stories.snippet: The most detailed and precise map yet produced of the universe just after its birth confirms the Big Bang theory in triumphant detail and opens new chapters in the early history of the cosmos, astronomers said yesterday.    It reveals the emergence...
stories.lead_paragraph: The most detailed and precise map yet produced of the universe just after its birth confirms the Big Bang theory in triumphant detail and opens new chapters in the early history of the cosmos, astronomers said yesterday. It reveals the emergence of the first stars in the cosmos, only 200 million years after the Big Bang, some half a billion years earlier than theorists had thought, and gives a first tantalizing hint at the physics of the ''dynamite'' behind the Big Bang.

stories.abstract: Inside Art column; experts believe Halsey Minor will lose about $13 million in Christie's sale of collection in addition to $10 million estimated loss at private sale; Metropolitan announces acquisitions of major European and Japanese works for permanent collection; photo (M)

headline.main: INSIDE ART

stories.snippet: The Americans, At Lower Prices      American collectors and dealers were anticipating a Christie's catalog of ''Important American Paintings From a Distinguished Private Collection'' long before it went in the mail. While the auction house did not...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Americans, At Lower Prices American collectors and dealers were anticipating a Christie's catalog of ''Important American Paintings From a Distinguished Private Collection'' long before it went in the mail. While the auction house did not put the seller's name on the catalog, everybody in the field knew the art was being sold by Halsey Minor, the founder of CNET Networks, a computer and technology Web site. He had been the biggest buyer of American modernist paintings for four years, snapping up works by masters like Winslow Homer and Andrew Wyeth, Marsden Hartley and Stuart Davis at top dollar, and buying everything through the Gerald Peters Gallery in Manhattan.

stories.abstract: Partners in International Space Station agree to launch European and Japanese components earlier than originally planned to ensure they are functioning by 2010, when orbiting space laboratory is to be fully assembled; heads of space agencies representing United States, Russia, Europe, Japan and Canada meet at Kennedy Space Center in Florida to work on new plan for completing $100 billion space station; Michael D Griffin, NASA administrator, says agency plans 16 more flights of space shuttle to finish station by end of decade (M)

headline.main: Schedule To Complete Space Station Is Advanced

stories.snippet: International partners agreed to launch European and Japanese components earlier to ensure they were functioning by 2010, when the space shuttle is to be retired.
stories.lead_paragraph: Partners in the International Space Station agreed Thursday to launch European and Japanese components earlier than originally planned to ensure they were functioning by 2010, when the orbiting space laboratory is to be fully assembled. Heads of the space agencies representing the United States, Russia, Europe, Japan and Canada met at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida to work on a new plan for completing the $100 billion space station.

stories.abstract: Gregory Olsen of Ridgefield Park, NJ, is training in Russia to become second American tourist to be launched into space; did poorly in high school, but eventually became successful inventor and owner of Sensors Unlimited; paid $20 million for trip into space; photo (S)

headline.main: From a C Student to a Celestial Traveler

stories.snippet: In 1962, with an F in trigonometry and a C average at Ridgefield Park High School in New Jersey, Gregory Olsen seemed destined for the final frontier of a steady job, evenings in front of the television and, if lucky, vacations on the Jersey Shore.  ...
stories.lead_paragraph: In 1962, with an F in trigonometry and a C average at Ridgefield Park High School in New Jersey, Gregory Olsen seemed destined for the final frontier of a steady job, evenings in front of the television and, if lucky, vacations on the Jersey Shore. ''The guidance counselor assured me that I would never get into any college and that I should join the Army,'' said Mr. Olsen, 59.

stories.abstract: Dennis A Tito, 60-year-old multimillionaire who made fortune in earthbound field of pension fund management but never gave up youthful dream of space, will spend $20 million to become world's first extraterrestrial tourist when he blasts off in Soyuz spacecraft for six-day mission aboard International Space Station; photos; money will go to cash-strapped Russian space program; son of New York City printer and seamstress began as aerospace engineer at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, designing for Mariner missions before leaving some 30 years ago to apply computer concepts to investment strategy; he founded Wilshire Associates, known for Wilshire 5000 stock index; Tito, whose trip was long opposed by NASA, has spent more than seven months in training in Russia and about 25 relatives and friends are there for bon voyage; sons Mike and Brad comment; Tito lives alone in huge dream house he built atop Pacific Palisades (M)

headline.main: $20 Million Paid for a Ticket, But Tenacity Paved the Way

stories.snippet: He lives alone in a 30,000-square-foot hilltop house that may be the biggest in town, with a whole room devoted to the collection of gas-powered model airplanes he built himself. He loves sailing and opera and fast cars, which his friends and family...
stories.lead_paragraph: He lives alone in a 30,000-square-foot hilltop house that may be the biggest in town, with a whole room devoted to the collection of gas-powered model airplanes he built himself. He loves sailing and opera and fast cars, which his friends and family say he drives slowly. He made a fortune in the earthbound field of pension fund management but never gave up on his youthful dream of reaching for the stars. Now, barring further complications, Dennis A. Tito, a 60-year-old, 5-foot-5, 140-pound millionaire a couple hundred times over, will become the world's first extraterrestrial tourist, blasting off as soon as Sunday in an extra seat on a Russian Soyuz spacecraft for a six-day mission aboard the International Space Station.

stories.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour is set for launching on mission to deliver mobile robotic arm to International Space Station, Canada's main contribution to project; arm is designed to mvoe itself all abut station, serving as hands and eyes of crew wherever outside work is needed; drawing (L)

headline.main: Special Delivery for the Space Station: A Robotic Arm

stories.snippet: The International Space Station is to receive a major arm up this week when astronauts aboard the shuttle Endeavour deliver a robot helper critical to expanding and maintaining the orbiting laboratory.    Endeavour, carrying a diverse international...
stories.lead_paragraph: The International Space Station is to receive a major arm up this week when astronauts aboard the shuttle Endeavour deliver a robot helper critical to expanding and maintaining the orbiting laboratory. Endeavour, carrying a diverse international crew of seven, is to blast off from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Thursday with Canada's main contribution to the project, a mobile robotic arm.

stories.abstract: Astronauts from space shuttle Atlantis attach Columbus science module to International Space Station; module adds 2,600 cubic feet of volume to space station, doubling its research ability, and is European Space Agency's primary contribution to project; photo (M)

headline.main: European Lab Attached to Space Station

stories.snippet: Astronauts placed the crown jewel of Europe’s contribution to the International Space Station into its permanent setting on Monday with the attachment of the Columbus science module.
stories.lead_paragraph: Astronauts placed the crown jewel of Europe's contribution to the International Space Station into its permanent setting on Monday with the attachment of the Columbus science module. On a seven-hour, 58-minute spacewalk, two astronauts and a robot arm guided the Columbus out of the cargo bay of the space shuttle Atlantis and affixed it to station.

stories.abstract: NASA launches Observer, second Mars rover, on mission to study whether planet ever had enough water to sustain life; launch follows weeks of delays (S)

headline.main: After Delays, NASA Launches 2nd Mars Rover

stories.snippet: After nearly two weeks of delays, a rocket holding NASA's second Mars rover was launched into a night sky today on a mission to study whether the planet ever had enough water to sustain life.    The rover, Opportunity, lifted off in a cloud of steam...
stories.lead_paragraph: After nearly two weeks of delays, a rocket holding NASA's second Mars rover was launched into a night sky today on a mission to study whether the planet ever had enough water to sustain life. The rover, Opportunity, lifted off in a cloud of steam aboard a Delta II Heavy rocket at 11:18 p.m.

stories.abstract: NASA mission to study geomagnetic storms used satellites and ground observations to determine order of events surrounding aurora borealis; researchers say they have identified trigger for colorful electrical storms in polar regions; they hope this is step in developing reliable forecasts of geomagnetic storms that can disrupt satellites in orbit and power grids on ground; their findings appear in July 24 article published on Web site of journal Science; photo (M)

headline.main: Scientists Find Trigger for Northern Lights

stories.snippet: The researchers hope the finding will be a step in developing reliable forecasts of geomagnetic storms.

multimedia.caption: The Trigger for The Northern Lights
multimedia.credit: An animation illustrating a new understanding of what causes the Northern LIghts. The blue lines represent the Earth’s magnetic field.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: An animation illustrating a new understanding of what causes the Northern LIghts. The blue lines represent the Earth’s magnetic field.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: The Trigger for The Northern Lights

stories.lead_paragraph: Scientists say they have discovered what makes the northern lights dance. Researchers working on a NASA mission to understand the interplay of magnetic fields and charged particles blown outward from the Sun have identified the trigger for the colorful electrical storms in the polar regions. They hope this is a step in developing reliable forecasts of geomagnetic storms that can disrupt satellites in orbit and power grids on the ground.

stories.abstract: Robert D Bulkley letter on November 21 article about debate between religion and science says that scientists need to understand religion before they can critcize it; Rev Anne-Marie Hislop letter holds that person can believe in both points of view; Russ Hammonds letter suggests that scientists must have faith in their convictions, even if they cannot be proven at this time and that religious faith is quite similar to scientific faith; George Holmes letter asserts that religious beliefs are not valid; Brian C Hall letter suggests that there may be mathematical solutions to questions about stability of solar system; Kate Bollinger letter says that people should be less adversarial in debate and instead honestly share ideas; drawing

headline.main: A Debate on Science and Religion

stories.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''A Free-for-All on Science and Religion'' (Nov. 21): Those scientists who are preparing to fight back at religion apparently know no more about religion than their literalist/fundamentalist opponents know about science....
stories.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Free-for-All on Science and Religion'' (Nov. 21): Those scientists who are preparing to fight back at religion apparently know no more about religion than their literalist/fundamentalist opponents know about science. Science can tell us about what exists in space and time; it cannot tell us about the eternity that created the space and time that science studies. Religion is neither scientific nor antiscientific, but an entirely different kind of knowledge. It is too bad that many scientists limit their understanding of religion to the most simplistic literalism. No one will benefit from a fight that is fought on the terms that these two sides have chosen. Robert D. Bulkley Beaverton, Ore. To the Editor: In the most recent tug-of-war, atheistic scientists seem to be partnering with conservative Christians in a classic debate centered on Western dualism. Either one tosses God and Scripture or one is a nonthinking believer in Adam, Eve and the apple.

stories.abstract: James Mechalakos letter on Paul Davies Apr 12 article on theory of multiple universes reflects on relationship between religion and science

headline.main: Religion and Science

stories.snippet: To the Editor:    In ''A Brief History of the Multiverse'' (Op-Ed, April 12), Paul Davies describes the theory of multiple universes as too large for scientific verification and reliant on leaps of faith, and compares it to the invocation of what he...
