stories.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''A Brief History of the Multiverse'' (Op-Ed, April 12), Paul Davies describes the theory of multiple universes as too large for scientific verification and reliant on leaps of faith, and compares it to the invocation of what he calls an ''ad hoc'' Creator to explain away everything.

stories.abstract: Astronauts on first spacewalk of shuttle Discovery's mission to International Space Station attach new Japanese-made laboratory, known as Kibo, to side of station; photo (M)

headline.main: Laboratory Module Attached To Side of the Space Station

stories.snippet: The Japanese-made laboratory is known as Kibo, Japanese for “hope.”
stories.lead_paragraph: The International Space Station has a new room. Astronauts on the first spacewalk of the shuttle Discovery's mission to the International Space Station freed a new Japanese-made laboratory from its moorings in the shuttle payload bay on Tuesday so that it could be removed.

stories.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery is launched on mission to deliver $1 billion bus-size laboratory known as Kibo module to International Space Station; NASA officials are not concerned about danger from pieces of foam that video showed falling off shuttle's external fuel tank during launch; laboratory is second and largest of three shuttle payloads that will bring full Kibo assembly to space station; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Discovery Heads Toward the Space Station

stories.snippet: The shuttle blasted its way into orbit through wispy clouds against blue skies on its way to deliver a bus-size laboratory to the International Space Station.

multimedia.caption: Meet the Crew
multimedia.credit: Biographies of the astronauts on board the space shuttleDiscovery for its latest trip to the International Space Station.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Biographies of the astronauts on board the space shuttleDiscovery for its latest trip to the International Space Station.

stories.lead_paragraph: The shuttle Discovery blasted its way into orbit on Saturday through wispy clouds against blue skies on its way to deliver a bus-size laboratory to the International Space Station. The column of smoke, bright white against the brilliant day, cast a shadow to the east as the shuttle ascended, and the sound waves made the air shudder.

stories.abstract: Long-overdue Russian-made service module for International Space Station is set to be launched into orbit; experts say that successfully launching the module, called Zvezda, Russian for star, is one of most critical steps in the $60 billion project, for both engineering and political reasons; drawings; photos (M)

headline.main: Space Station Living Room Is Ready to Rocket

stories.snippet: The future of the stalled International Space Station could hinge on a star.    Construction of what is to become the largest structure that humans have ever put into space has been on hold, awaiting the late arrival of the station's critical...
stories.lead_paragraph: The future of the stalled International Space Station could hinge on a star. Construction of what is to become the largest structure that humans have ever put into space has been on hold, awaiting the late arrival of the station's critical Russian-made command and living section.

stories.abstract: Local boosters in Huntsville, Ala, are hoping to use 50th anniversary of Explorer I, first American satellite launched into orbit, to promote Huntsville as Rocket City; relocation of German rocket scientists to area in 1950 transformed city from small cotton town to birthplace of space program, now with one of country's highest concentrations of rocket scientists and propulsion experts; photos; map (M)

headline.main: When the Germans, and Their Rockets, Came to Town

stories.snippet: After World War II, Huntsville, Ala., was transformed by Wernher von Braun’s rocket program. Now it has one of the country’s highest concentrations of scientists and engineers.
stories.lead_paragraph: In 1950, this cotton market town in northern Alabama lost a bid for a military aviation project that would have revived its mothballed arsenal. The consolation prize was dubious: 118 German rocket scientists who had surrendered to the Americans during World War II, led by a man -- a crackpot, evidently -- who claimed humans could visit the moon. Ultimately those German immigrants made history, launching the first American satellite, Explorer I, into orbit in January 1958 and putting astronauts on the moon in 1969. The crackpot, Wernher von Braun, was celebrated as a visionary.

stories.abstract: Editorial holds life of Hubble Space Telescope should be extended until more advanced replacement, now in planning stages, is placed in orbit

headline.main: The Fate of the Hubble Telescope

stories.snippet: The Hubble Space Telescope, an astonishingly productive but aging space-based observatory, is facing challenges that will determine how long it can keep performing first-rate science. In our view, the life of the telescope should be extended until a...
stories.lead_paragraph: The Hubble Space Telescope, an astonishingly productive but aging space-based observatory, is facing challenges that will determine how long it can keep performing first-rate science. In our view, the life of the telescope should be extended until a more advanced replacement, now in the planning stages, is placed in orbit. After some early technical modifications to repair flaws in its primary mirror, Hubble has been a resounding success. Floating well above the distorting effects of the atmosphere, the observatory has been able to detect extremely faint objects that cannot be found by earthbound telescopes. Hubble has provided the clearest and deepest views of the distant universe, calibrated the age and expansion rate of the universe, and detected supermassive black holes that seem to lie at the core of most galaxies, among myriad other achievements.

stories.abstract: Nearly every major element of Pres Ronald Reagan's original proposal to place weapons in space is back in center of Pentagon's plans for national missile shield; space-based defenses would be placed in orbit as permanent sentinels, waiting until enemy warhead rises above atmosphere before trying to obliterate warhead, missile carrying it or both; Pentagon's new plan calls for accelerated development of chemical lasers that would fly in space or high in atmosphere, fresh research on abandoned program to launch thousands of interceptors into space and expansion of project to place dozens of sensor-laden satellites into orbit; critics of new plan, like critics of Reagan's plan 20 years ago, fear it could transform space from placid zone into potential battlefield; diagrams (M)

headline.main: Cast of Star Wars Makes Comeback in Bush Plan

stories.snippet: Twenty years after President Ronald Reagan created an international furor by proposing to place weapons in space, the Pentagon has put nearly every major element of the original program back in the center of its plans as part of a national missile...
stories.lead_paragraph: Twenty years after President Ronald Reagan created an international furor by proposing to place weapons in space, the Pentagon has put nearly every major element of the original program back in the center of its plans as part of a national missile shield. Unlike the ground-launched interceptor that successfully pulverized a mock warhead above Earth's atmosphere a week ago, space-based defenses would be placed in orbit as permanent sentinels, waiting until an enemy warhead rose above the atmosphere before trying to obliterate the warhead, the missile carrying it or both.

stories.abstract: IMC Global will sell its salt and Ogden businesses for about $640 million to affiliate of management firm Apollo Management LP; IMC Global, one of biggest maker of fertilizer, will initially receive about $600 million in cash from Apollo, and remainder of purchase price will be stake in salt business, now owned by Apollo, which is managed by Leon Black (S)

headline.main: SALT PRODUCER WILL SELL BUSINESSES FOR $640 MILLION

stories.snippet: IMC Global, the world's third-biggest salt producer, will sell its salt and Ogden businesses for about $640 million to an affiliate of the closely held management firm Apollo Management L.P. IMC Global, one of the biggest makers of fertilizer, will...
stories.lead_paragraph: IMC Global, the world's third-biggest salt producer, will sell its salt and Ogden businesses for about $640 million to an affiliate of the closely held management firm Apollo Management L.P. IMC Global, one of the biggest makers of fertilizer, will initially receive about $600 million in cash from Apollo, and the remainder of the purchase price will be a stake in the salt business, now owned by Apollo, which is based in New York and managed by the investor Leon Black. The Ogden, or Great Salt Lake, evaporation operation makes solar salt, sulphate of potash and magnesium chloride. The sale will help IMC Global, which is based in Lake Forest, Ill., concentrate on its main fertilizer business, a spokesman, David Prichard, said.

stories.abstract: Hexion Specialty Chemical, company owned by Apollo Management, makes $10.4 billion offer for Huntsman Corp; bidding for Huntsman is again pitting bidders for GE's plastics unit against each other; Apollo and Access Industries lost out in May to Saudi Basic Industries Corp, which paid $11.6 billion for GE unit (M)

headline.main: Apollo Makes $10.4 Billion Counteroffer for Huntsman

stories.snippet: Hexion Specialty Chemical, a company owned by Apollo, on Tuesday offered $10.4 billion for Huntsman, little more than a week after the company agreed to a deal with a unit of Access Industries.

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

stories.lead_paragraph: Less than two months after an unsuccessful attempt to acquire General Electric's plastics division, the private equity firm Apollo Management is making another run at a big industrial operation by trying to break up a $9.6 billion deal for the Huntsman Corporation. Late Tuesday, Hexion Specialty Chemical, a company owned by Apollo, made a $10.4 billion offer for Huntsman, little more than a week after the company agreed to a deal with a unit of Access Industries, a conglomerate owned by Leonard Blavatnik.

stories.abstract: Some senior members of Congress believe investigation of space shuttle disaster must be taken over by presidential commission because of serious concerns about independence of NASA's board; Reps Bart Gordon and F James Sensenbrenner Jr call on Pres Bush to name panel (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE INVESTIGATORS
headline.main: Lawmakers Favor Panel Under Bush On Columbia

stories.snippet: Some senior lawmakers say they believe the investigation of the Columbia space shuttle must be taken over by a presidential commission, saying serious concerns remain about the independence of the board set up by NASA officials.    Representative...
stories.lead_paragraph: Some senior lawmakers say they believe the investigation of the Columbia space shuttle must be taken over by a presidential commission, saying serious concerns remain about the independence of the board set up by NASA officials. Representative Bart Gordon of Tennessee, the senior Democrat on the House space subcommittee, asserted today that NASA is ''rapidly losing credibility'' because of its unwillingness to allow an independent and credible investigation of the shuttle crash.

stories.abstract: Editorial urges Pres Bush to name full-fledged presidential commission on space shuttle Columbia disaster, expressing concern that board now in charge of investigation lacks independence needed to give its findings maximum credibility

headline.main: Fixing the Shuttle Inquiry

stories.snippet: Investigation of the Columbia disaster moved into a new phase last week when a special board took charge of the inquiry and Congress began its own hearings. These were important steps to broaden the inquiry beyond NASA's own technical investigations....
stories.lead_paragraph: Investigation of the Columbia disaster moved into a new phase last week when a special board took charge of the inquiry and Congress began its own hearings. These were important steps to broaden the inquiry beyond NASA's own technical investigations. But we remain concerned that the board now in charge still lacks the independence needed to give its findings maximum credibility. The early stages of the Columbia investigation were carried out by employees and contractors of NASA. To buttress confidence in the impartiality of the inquiry, the space agency convened an oversight board of top safety officials from other government agencies and named a retired admiral who had investigated the U.S.S. Cole bombing to head it. That board has now taken control of the investigation.

stories.abstract: Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin are paying $1.3 million a year to park their private plane and two others used by other company executives on Moffett Field, airport run by NASA that is nearly adjacent to Google headquarters and generally closed to private aircraft; perk is likely to turn other Silicon Valley tycoons green with envy, but it may not sit well with community that is proud to have Google in its midst; agreement between Google and NASA provides for agency to place scientific instruments and researchers on planes; photos (M)

headline.main: Google Claims Ultimate Perk: NASA Runway

stories.snippet: Google’s executives have secured the use of a NASA-run airstrip that is just minutes from their offices.
stories.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 -- In the annals of perks enjoyed by America's corporate executives, the founders of Google may have set a new standard: an uncrowded, federally managed runway for their private jet that is only a few minutes' drive from their offices. For $1.3 million a year, Larry Page and Sergey Brin get to park their customized wide-body Boeing 767-200, as well as two other jets used by top Google executives, on Moffett Field, an airport run by NASA that is generally closed to private aircraft.

stories.abstract: H211, company that operates private jets owned and used by Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin, adds Dornier Alpha fighter jet to its fleet; photo (S)

headline.main: Google Founders' New (Fighter) Jet

stories.snippet: Google Founders' New (Fighter) Jet     A company controlled by Google's top executives, including its billionaire founders, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, has added a new plane to its well-equipped fleet: a fighter jet. More precisely, the plane is a...
stories.lead_paragraph: Google Founders' New (Fighter) Jet A company controlled by Google's top executives, including its billionaire founders, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, has added a new plane to its well-equipped fleet: a fighter jet. More precisely, the plane is a Dornier Alpha Jet, a light attack and training aircraft made by a French-German joint venture.

stories.abstract: Boston University trustees board executive committee reportedly asks board to weigh rescinding offer of presidency to Daniel S Goldin after giving him no confidence vote; reason is unclear, but slight to departing chancellor John Silber, who has dominated school for years, is suspected; photos (M)

headline.main: Turmoil at the Top at Boston University

stories.snippet: Who will run Boston University, the nation's fourth largest private university?    Daniel S. Goldin, the former NASA chief, thought he had the job, with the title of president, and a salary of more than $600,000 a year. He was supposed to start work...
stories.lead_paragraph: Who will run Boston University, the nation's fourth largest private university? Daniel S. Goldin, the former NASA chief, thought he had the job, with the title of president, and a salary of more than $600,000 a year. He was supposed to start work this Saturday. He had invited the entire faculty to a gala luncheon on Nov. 17, the day of his official inauguration.

stories.abstract: Boston University offers its presidency to Daniel S Goldin, NASA administrator from 1992 to 2001; photo (S)

headline.main: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Boston U. Wants Ex-NASA Chief

stories.snippet: Boston University has offered its presidency to Daniel S. Goldin, who was the NASA administrator from 1992 to 2001. Mr. Goldin, left, has a bachelor's degree from the City College of New York and is a senior fellow at the Neurosciences Institute in...
stories.lead_paragraph: Boston University has offered its presidency to Daniel S. Goldin, who was the NASA administrator from 1992 to 2001. Mr. Goldin, left, has a bachelor's degree from the City College of New York and is a senior fellow at the Neurosciences Institute in San Diego. John Silber, the chancellor, has been interim president since last July, when Jon Westling resigned. Katie Zezima (NYT)

stories.abstract: James N Hallock, aviation safety expert who is on board investigating Columbia space shuttle accident, announces that board will use independent laboratories and outside experts to review major technical work performed by NASA and its contractors, in response to concerns raised by Congress and others about credibility of inquiry; says board will order outside tests to double-check Boeing's conclusion that foam debris strike damage was 'inconsequential', finding disputed by Dr Paul S Fischbeck, who was commissioned by NASA in 1990 to investigate risks to shuttle from damaged tiles; board will move out of NASA offices into commercial space to give it neutral territory to work from (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE INVESTIGATORS
headline.main: Outside Experts To Aid Review Of NASA Work

stories.snippet: The board named to investigate the space shuttle disaster will employ independent laboratories and outside experts to review the major technical work performed by NASA and its contractors, one of its members said today.    The move is designed to...

byline.original: By JOHN M. BRODER and MATTHEW L. WALD

stories.lead_paragraph: The board named to investigate the space shuttle disaster will employ independent laboratories and outside experts to review the major technical work performed by NASA and its contractors, one of its members said today. The move is designed to address concerns raised by Congress and some non-NASA scientists about the credibility of the inquiry. They said that NASA should not be permitted to investigate itself and have demanded that the review panel, headed by retired Adm. Harold W. Gehman Jr., be expanded to include experts with no ties to the space agency or the military.

stories.abstract: Homeland Security Department postpones program to employ domestic spy satellites because of privacy concerns and legal issues raised by Congress (S)

headline.main: U.S. Postpones Domestic Spy Satellite Program

stories.snippet: A program to employ spy satellites for certain domestic uses has been postponed because of privacy concerns.
stories.lead_paragraph: A program to employ spy satellites for certain domestic uses has been postponed because of privacy concerns. Congress had already provided money for the program, which was to begin this month. But some lawmakers demanded more information about its legal basis and what protections there were to ensure that the government was not peering into the homes of Americans. As a result, the Homeland Security Department is not formally moving ahead with the program until it answers those questions, a department spokesman said.

stories.abstract: NASA, after days of uncertainty, tells atronauts on space shuttle Endeavour that they have enough fuel to complete their mission to map Earth (S)

headline.main: Shuttle to Complete Mission

stories.snippet: After days of uncertainty, NASA told the astronauts on the space shuttle Endeavour today that they had enough fuel to complete their mission to map Earth.    ''We have full cryo for a nominal mission,'' Mission Control said.
stories.lead_paragraph: After days of uncertainty, NASA told the astronauts on the space shuttle Endeavour today that they had enough fuel to complete their mission to map Earth. ''We have full cryo for a nominal mission,'' Mission Control said.

stories.abstract: NASA prepares to launch Mars Odyssey on $300 million, two-year mission to map Mars chemical composition, look for signs of water near surface and evaluate potential radiation risks to future human explorers; NASA's goals for Mars exploration are more cautiously modest than before double failure of Mars Climate Orbiter and Mars Polar Lander in 1999; map; drawing (M)

headline.main: Chastened, NASA Readies New Mars Craft

stories.snippet: Back to Mars, back to the search into its mystifying past and present, but this time the goal of exploration is more cautiously modest than before.    After two failures at the brink of success a year and a half ago, the National Aeronautics and...
stories.lead_paragraph: Back to Mars, back to the search into its mystifying past and present, but this time the goal of exploration is more cautiously modest than before. After two failures at the brink of success a year and a half ago, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has regrouped and is ready to launch a single spacecraft to fly to Mars, now more than 77 million miles away. The new orbiter, Mars Odyssey, is scheduled for liftoff on Saturday at Cape Canaveral, Fla., and if all goes well it will begin orbiting Mars on Oct. 24.

stories.abstract: Bernard Weinraub profiles B B King in series The Music They Made: Legends of Rock, Country and Soul; King is last of great bluesman and one of most important electric guitarists of last half century, with impact that long ago transcended blues and infiltrated rock 'n' rolls; pursues flourishing career at age 77, playing about 200 club dates a year and earning two more Grammy awards this year to bring his total to 13; has struggled his entire life to earn respect for himself and blues; is still angry over poverty and racism he endured as child in Mississippi; photos (L)

headline.main: Spinning Blues Into Gold, the Rough Way

stories.snippet: B.B. King is tired. The last of the great bluesmen, Mr. King sits slumped in a chair in a Manhattan hotel room. It is early afternoon, and Mr. King, sipping water, is resting before a sold-out appearance at the club named for him on 42nd Street.    A...
stories.lead_paragraph: B.B. King is tired. The last of the great bluesmen, Mr. King sits slumped in a chair in a Manhattan hotel room. It is early afternoon, and Mr. King, sipping water, is resting before a sold-out appearance at the club named for him on 42nd Street. A big man encased in a silk Hawaiian-style shirt, Mr. King, at 77, travels relentlessly around the country, as consumed with performing and recording as he was 30 years ago. ''If I don't keep doing it, keep going, they'll forget me,'' he says.

stories.abstract: Profile of and interview with Bo Diddley, electric guitarist and musical pioneer who has influenced generations of rockers, article in series The Music They Made: Legends of Rock, Country and Soul; performers as diverse as Elvis Presley, Buddy Holly, Jimi Hendrix, Mick Jagger and Bruce Springsteen have been inspired by syncopated Bo Diddley beat; Bo Diddley was named Otha Ellas Bates at birth on Dec 30, 1928, in McComb, Miss; photos (L)

headline.main: Pioneer of a Beat Is Still Riffing for His Due

stories.snippet: Every morning at 4 a.m., Bo Diddley walks into a ramshackle studio on his 76-acre property outside Gainesville to write music. Several electric guitars are scattered on the floor. The studio, a double-wide trailer, is crammed with recording...
stories.lead_paragraph: Every morning at 4 a.m., Bo Diddley walks into a ramshackle studio on his 76-acre property outside Gainesville to write music. Several electric guitars are scattered on the floor. The studio, a double-wide trailer, is crammed with recording equipment, a synthesizer and electronic gadgets of obscure types. Piled in every corner are boxes of tapes of Bo Diddley songs never released. Mr. Diddley, 74, sat forward on a hard chair and lifted a blond-finished guitar, made for him by a music store in Gainesville. His enormous fingers, wrinkled and strong, grazed the strings. Hooked into an electronic gadget, the strums became the sounds of a small orchestra: strings, chimes, a brassy horn, an organ and a gospel piano, providing a thumping echo of Bo Diddley songs.

stories.abstract: Rep Henry A Waxman wrests chairmanship of House Energy and Commerce Committee from Rep John Dingell in coup that is expected to accelerate passage of energy, climate and health legislation backed by Pres-elect Barack Obama; Waxman has long championed wide industry regulation; profiles of Waxman and Dingell; photos (M)

headline.main: Democrats Oust Longtime Leader Of House Panel

stories.snippet: Henry A. Waxman’s victory over John D. Dingell is expected to accelerate passage of energy, climate and health legislation backed by Barack Obama.

byline.original: By JOHN M. BRODER; Micheline Maynard contributed reporting from Detroit

stories.lead_paragraph: Representative Henry A. Waxman wrested the chairmanship of the powerful House Energy and Commerce Committee from Representative John D. Dingell on Thursday in a coup that is expected to accelerate passage of energy, climate and health legislation backed by President-elect Barack Obama. Mr. Waxman, 69, of California, who mounted a quiet but devastatingly effective two-week campaign against his longtime Democratic colleague, won the chairmanship with a 137-to-122 vote in the Democratic Caucus. The vote was secret, but many allies of Speaker Nancy Pelosi backed Mr. Waxman's move, and several members said they had voted on the assumption that Ms. Pelosi had tacitly approved.

stories.abstract: Federally-financed New York Climate and Health Project, released by Columbia University scientists, predicts that metropolitan area will be hotter, wetter and unhealthier place to live well before end of 21st century; sees air pollution and heat-related deaths increasing as global temperatures rise by 2.4 to 10.4 degrees by 2100 (M),

headline.main: Forecast for New York This Century: Hotter and Wetter

stories.snippet: It will not happen the day after tomorrow. Nor a decade from now.     But well before this century ends, global warming will make New York City and the metropolitan area that surrounds it a hotter, wetter and significantly less healthy place to live...
stories.lead_paragraph: It will not happen the day after tomorrow. Nor a decade from now. But well before this century ends, global warming will make New York City and the metropolitan area that surrounds it a hotter, wetter and significantly less healthy place to live and work, according to a federally financed study released on Friday by a group of scientists at Columbia University.

stories.abstract: Airbus A380 superjumbo jet will be on display at Farnborough International Air Show amid problems facing parent company European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company involving production delays of aircraft and questions about timing of stock sales by co-chief executive Noel Forgeard; problems led to his dismissal; company hopes to emphasize its gains in military contracts as symbol of stronger trans-Atlantic relationships; photos (M)

headline.main: It's Air Show Time, but Airbus May Not Want the Spotlight

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: EUROPEAN AERONAUTIC DEFENSE AND SPACE CO

stories.snippet: The show could not come at a worse time for Airbus as its rival, Boeing, has soared against a backdrop of a booming demand for air travel.

multimedia.caption: Audio Slide Show: Power Plays in Flight

legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: Audio Slide Show: Power Plays in Flight

byline.original: By LESLIE WAYNE; Katrin Bennhold contributed reporting from Paris for this article

stories.lead_paragraph: No matter where it goes, the Airbus A380, a double-decker superjumbo jet so big that it has been called the Whale, turns heads. As the world's leaders in aviation gather at the Farnborough International Airshow, which opens Monday about 30 miles southwest of here, the A380 will be on center stage as it makes its Farnborough debut. But the plane is also an outsize reminder of the problems facing Airbus and its parent company, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company.

stories.abstract: Monster Worldwide is subpoenaed by United States Attorney over timing of stock option grants to executives; company opens internal investigation of all its grants; Monster is among 30 companies whose stock option awards practices have attracted attention (S)

headline.main: Monster Is Subpoenaed

stories.snippet: Monster Worldwide, parent of the job search site Monster.com, was subpoenaed over the timing of stock option grants to executives.
stories.lead_paragraph: Monster Worldwide, parent of the job search site Monster.com, was subpoenaed yesterday by the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York over the timing of stock option grants to executives. Earlier in the day, Monster Worldwide disclosed that it had opened an internal investigation of all its stock option grants. The company often granted options dated before steep rises in its share price, The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday.

stories.abstract: Russia's Supreme Court overturns jury's acquittal of Valentin V Danilov, physicist charged with espionage for selling data on space and satellite technology he and other scientists argued was not classified to Chinese company; orders new trial; Danilov says court responds to pressure from Federal Security Service, phone interview (M)

headline.main: Russian Court Overturns Acquittal in Spy Case

stories.snippet: Russia's Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned the acquittal of a physicist who had been charged with espionage, ordering a new trial in a case that has been seen as part of a crackdown on researchers and scientists working with foreigners.     The...
stories.lead_paragraph: Russia's Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned the acquittal of a physicist who had been charged with espionage, ordering a new trial in a case that has been seen as part of a crackdown on researchers and scientists working with foreigners. The ruling reversed a jury's decision in December to clear the physicist, Valentin V. Danilov, who had been charged with selling information on space and satellite technology that he and other scientists argued was not classified to a company in China.

stories.abstract: Canada confirms its decision to block America-based Alliant Techsystems' $1.33 billion takeover bid for space and satellite division of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates, Canada's leading space technology firm; it is first time Canada has rejected foreign takeover outright in 19 years since Canada Investment Act took effect in 1989 (S)

headline.main: Canada Blocks U.S. Takeover of a Technology Firm

stories.snippet: Canada confirmed its decision to block an American company's takeover of the space and satellite division of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates, Canada's leading space technology firm. The industry minister, Jim Prentice, first turned down last month...
stories.lead_paragraph: Canada confirmed its decision to block an American company's takeover of the space and satellite division of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates, Canada's leading space technology firm. The industry minister, Jim Prentice, first turned down last month a $1.3 billion takeover bid from Alliant Techsystems, a munitions and rocket component maker based near Minneapolis, for M.D.A.'s space division. It is the first time Canada has rejected a foreign takeover outright in the 19 years since the Canada Investment Act took effect in 1989.

stories.abstract: Space debris is suspect as investigators press efforts to determine why space shuttle Columbia disintegrated in earth's atmosphere on February 2, even though most of debris circling earth is beyond shuttle's orbit; 84 percent of known debris, circling earth since launching of Sputnik in 1957, lies more than 500 miles up, or twice as high as International Space Station; even though NASA and independent experts calculate as extremely remote chances of shuttle suffering fatal damage in collision with high-speed floating debris, evidence suggests shuttles regularly collide with space junk; most shuttle windows carry pockmarks of collisions with tiny objects floating in space; potency of threat lies in fact that at 21,000-mile-per-hour velocity, collision with piece of aluminum size of fingertip would have kinetic force of 400-pound safe at 60 miles per hour; graphs (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: SPACE HAZARDS
headline.main: Dating Back to Sputnik, Long-Forgotten Debris May Pose a Fatal Threat

stories.snippet: The domain of the space shuttle is relatively free of space junk, the flotsam from hundreds of satellite launches, but even so there is plenty to threaten the orbiters, and much of it escapes detection. So as investigators try to determine how the...
stories.lead_paragraph: The domain of the space shuttle is relatively free of space junk, the flotsam from hundreds of satellite launches, but even so there is plenty to threaten the orbiters, and much of it escapes detection. So as investigators try to determine how the shuttle Columbia was lost, space debris is a suspect. Some 84 percent of the known debris -- about 8,000 pieces of detritus left from every old satellite or used-up booster rocket launched since Sputnik in 1957 -- lies more than 500 miles up, twice as high as the orbit of the International Space Station, according to officials of the Air Force Space Command, which maps space debris. That is ordinarily the highest altitude the shuttles reach. On scientific missions like the Columbia's, the orbiter flies about 180 miles high.

stories.abstract: Clyde Haberman NYC column on 50th anniversary of launching of Sputnik 1 by Russia; says event led America to push for emphasis on study of science and engineering (M)

headline.main: What Sputnik Meant to a Kid Studying Science

stories.snippet: If you were a teenager in the late 1950s, and made it into a brainy place like the Bronx High School of Science through merit or dumb luck, you might have paid more attention than most to an anniversary yesterday. You might have remembered that 50...
stories.section_name: Technology; Science; Education; New York and Region
stories.lead_paragraph: If you were a teenager in the late 1950s, and made it into a brainy place like the Bronx High School of Science through merit or dumb luck, you might have paid more attention than most to an anniversary yesterday. You might have remembered that 50 years ago, your world changed. On Oct. 4, 1957, the Soviet Union launched the first artificial satellite, a 184-pound sphere called Sputnik 1. Moving at 18,000 miles per hour, it circled the Earth every 96 minutes, which, for a local perspective, is about how long it takes the A train to run from northern Manhattan to Far Rockaway.

stories.abstract: Vision of the future presented in 2001: A Space Odyssey, 1968 film by Stanley Kubrick and Arthur C Clarke, discussed in light of plans to release new version of film, with digital sound and light, next year; photo (M)

headline.main: On the Eve of 2001, the Future Is Not Quite What It Used to Be

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: TWO THOUSAND ONE: A SPACE ODYSSEY (MOVIE)

stories.snippet: Prediction is very hard, the quantum physicist Niels Bohr once said, especially regarding the future, but that is exactly the job and the predicament of the science fiction writer. Next week, the future arrives for one of the most famous prophecies...
stories.lead_paragraph: Prediction is very hard, the quantum physicist Niels Bohr once said, especially regarding the future, but that is exactly the job and the predicament of the science fiction writer. Next week, the future arrives for one of the most famous prophecies of all time, ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' Stanley Kubrick, who directed and produced the movie, died in 1999, but his partner Arthur C. Clarke, who wrote the book on which he and Mr. Kubrick based the screenplay, is alive and well in Sri Lanka and will be around for the release of a new version of ''2001'' with digital light and sound next year, as well as comparisons of the future then and now.

stories.abstract: Lights of Liberty is sound and light show blending modern technology with 200-year-old history to enhance visitors' experience of Philadelphia's Independence Historical National Park; exhibit first opened in 1999; Revolutionary-era scenes are projected on buildings and headsets provide accompanying narration; headsets, designed by Aeptec Microsystems, are equivalent of microprocessors that work with modified MP3 technology; photos (M)

headline.main: 1776, Relived Digitally: A Historic Square Sizzles

stories.snippet: ''COME join the Revolution!'' bellow three guides in Colonial garb just steps from Independence Hall. Their stentorian shouts could refer not only to the theme of the multimedia show about to begin, but to its underlying technology as well.     Five...
stories.lead_paragraph: ''COME join the Revolution!'' bellow three guides in Colonial garb just steps from Independence Hall. Their stentorian shouts could refer not only to the theme of the multimedia show about to begin, but to its underlying technology as well. Five nights a week through Labor Day, the production, the Lights of Liberty Show, will blend modern technology with 200-year-old history to take visitors on a six-block walking tour of Independence Historical National Park.

stories.abstract: Studies conducted by NASA over last four years concluded that damage to brittle, heat-dissipating material on leading edge of space shuttle Columbia's wings posed one of highest risks of catastrophic accident; focused largely on tremendous damage that could be caused by unlikely event that tiny meteoroid or orbital debris hit leading edge of wing, which is made of lightweight, reinforced carbon-carbon; impact has emerged as one of leading theories about cause of breakup of shuttle on reentry into earth's atmosphere on February 2 killing all seven astronauts on board; analysis by Boeing Co, shuttle contractor, concluded that underside of leading edge was probably hit, along with large swath of panels; engineers report comparatively little testing to determine if slower-moving debris posed similar hazard, hence saw little risk from debris dislodged from external fuel tank that struck left wing during launching from Cape Canaveral; diagram; photo (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE OVERVIEW
headline.main: SHUTTLE TESTING SUGGESTED WINGS WERE VULNERABLE

stories.snippet: Studies conducted by NASA over the last four years concluded that damage to the brittle, heat-shedding material on the leading edge of the space shuttle Columbia's wings posed one of the highest risks of a catastrophic accident.    The studies...
stories.lead_paragraph: Studies conducted by NASA over the last four years concluded that damage to the brittle, heat-shedding material on the leading edge of the space shuttle Columbia's wings posed one of the highest risks of a catastrophic accident. The studies focused largely on the tremendous damage that could be caused in the unlikely event that a tiny meteoroid or other bit of orbital debris hit the leading edge of a wing, which is made of a lightweight material called reinforced carbon-carbon. That is still one of the theories about what might have happened to the Columbia eight days ago.

stories.abstract: NASA officials express doubt that piece of foam insulation from external fuel tank that struck space shuttle Columbia during January 16 launching from Cape Canaveral could have led to destruction of ship during reentry into earth's atmosphere on February 1 killing all seven astronauts on board; shuttle program manager Ron Dittemore says material is too light to cause fatal damage and that investigators are seeking 'missing link' to explain disaster; dismisses speculation that piece of foam could have been saturated with water or encrusted with ice heavy enough to magnify damage it did to heat-dissipating tiles on underside of left wing; defends engineering study, conducted during 16-day mission, which concluded that damage from foam debris would not affect flight safety; says crew was involved in discussions about spacecraft being hit by debris and did not raise concerns about damage to craft; photos (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE OVERVIEW
headline.main: NASA NOW DOUBTS TANK FOAM DEBRIS DOOMED COLUMBIA

stories.snippet: NASA officials expressed doubt today that a piece of foam from the external fuel tank that struck the shuttle Columbia during its liftoff could have led to the destruction of the ship.    On Monday, officials identified damage caused by the impact...
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA officials expressed doubt today that a piece of foam from the external fuel tank that struck the shuttle Columbia during its liftoff could have led to the destruction of the ship. On Monday, officials identified damage caused by the impact during the launching on Jan. 16 as a prime suspect in the series of failures that led to the Columbia's breakup over Texas on Saturday.

stories.abstract: Observatory column: Researchers in Britain and Japan, in study published in journal Nature, find that parasitic wasps secrete long-lasting chemicals on parasitic butterfly larvae that make host ants more aggressive, first attracting them to caterpillar and then repelling them; ants then turn on each other, and, thus distracted, cannot defend themselves against egg-laying wasps; researchers from Montana State and Michigan Technological Universities, in study published in journal Conservation Biology, conclude that elk and wolves exposed to snowmobiles have higher levels of hormones caused by stress; photos from Galileo spacecraft's final flyby of Jupiter's moon Io show many new volcanoes, cliffs and plume vents; drawing (M)

headline.main: OBSERVATORY

stories.snippet: Ants' Demolition Derby      A community can be at its most vulnerable when its members quarrel among themselves, allowing an enemy to exploit the infighting to its own advantage. (There is a reason, after all, that the aphorism ''United we stand''...
stories.lead_paragraph: Ants' Demolition Derby A community can be at its most vulnerable when its members quarrel among themselves, allowing an enemy to exploit the infighting to its own advantage. (There is a reason, after all, that the aphorism ''United we stand'' starts springing up everywhere in times of trouble.) What is true for people is also true for ants, apparently, according to a study by researchers in Britain and Japan. Only with ants, the same enemy that exploits the infighting is causing it.

stories.abstract: Industrial powers that have contributed most to global warming are spending far more to limit their own risks than to limit climate and coastal hazards in world's most vulnerable regions, many of which are overwhelmingly poor; lack of climate aid persists even though nearly all industrialized nations including US pledged to help when they signed Framework Convention on Climate Change in 1992; some officials from US, Britain and Japan say foreign aid can be directed to easing risks; photo (L)

headline.main: POOREST NATIONS WILL BEAR BRUNT AS WORLD WARMS

stories.snippet: Wealthy countries spend far more to limit their own risks from global warming than to help the world’s most vulnerable regions.

multimedia.caption: The Climate Divide
multimedia.credit: Malawi, India, the Netherlands and Australia will experience global warming in very different ways.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Malawi, India, the Netherlands and Australia will experience global warming in very different ways.

stories.lead_paragraph: The world's richest countries, which have contributed by far the most to the atmospheric changes linked to global warming, are already spending billions of dollars to limit their own risks from its worst consequences, like drought and rising seas. But despite longstanding treaty commitments to help poor countries deal with warming, these industrial powers are spending just tens of millions of dollars on ways to limit climate and coastal hazards in the world's most vulnerable regions -- most of them close to the equator and overwhelmingly poor.

stories.abstract: Australian National University researchers report in journal Science that Iceman, alpine mummy, lived in valley region within 35 miles south of Tyrolean Alps site where he was found; gorgesaurus, being prepared for exhibit at Indianapolis Children's Museum, is found to have brain tumor; fossilized mass, which is first recognized evidence of brain tumor in dinosaur fossil, is confirmed by Black Hills Institute of Geological Research scientists with help of Indiana University radiologists; Columbia astronauts are added to astronaut memorial at Cape Canaveral; crew member Dr Kalpana Chawla's will donates $300,000 to establish Kalpana Chawla Fund for Environmental Stewardship through National Audubon Society; drawing (M)

headline.main: OBSERVATORY

keywords.value: BLACK HILLS INSTITUTE OF GEOLOGICAL RESEARCH

stories.snippet: An Iceman Close to Home      In 1991, when the world first encountered the Alpine mummy called the Iceman, he had melted out of the glacier that had encased him since the late Stone Age.    But if in death he had not gotten around much in 5,200...
stories.lead_paragraph: An Iceman Close to Home In 1991, when the world first encountered the Alpine mummy called the Iceman, he had melted out of the glacier that had encased him since the late Stone Age. But if in death he had not gotten around much in 5,200 years, in life the Iceman was no slouch. For one thing, when he died, roughly at age 46, he was traveling at 10,500 feet through a high pass in the Tyrolean Alps, near the current border between Italy and Austria.

stories.abstract: NASA officials say new crew will be sent to International Space Station on October 11 aboard Russian Soyuz spacecraft despite concerns about oxygen and supplies on space station; Dr Leroy Chiao and Salizhan S Sharipov will relieve Col Gennadi I Padalka and Lt Col Edward Mike Fincke; supplies will be replenished by deliveries in late December and February; balky oxygen generator is problem, but station has 160-day oxygen supply from other sources should it fail (M)

headline.main: New Crew to Leave for Space Station on Oct. 11, NASA Says

stories.snippet: A new crew will be sent to the International Space Station next month, even though there are concerns about adequate oxygen and other supplies.
stories.lead_paragraph: A new crew will be sent to the International Space Station next month, even though there are concerns about maintaining adequate oxygen and other supplies on the orbiting laboratory, NASA officials said Friday. The space station program manager, William H. Gerstenmaier, said two astronauts would be launched to the station on a Russian Soyuz spacecraft on Oct. 11 for an expected six-month tour of duty.

stories.abstract: Astronauts Col Gennadi I Padalka and Lt Col Edward Mike Fincke make excursion outside International Space Station to replace panel needed to control cooling pump and to install three antennas to help European automatic freighters rendezvous with station beginning next year (S)

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: 2 Floating Astronauts

stories.snippet: Two astronauts floated outside the International Space Station for 5 hours 20 minutes to carry out more improvement and maintenance work on their orbiting residence. For Col. Gennadi I. Padalka of the Russian Air Force and Lt. Col. Edward Mike Fincke...
stories.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts floated outside the International Space Station for 5 hours 20 minutes to carry out more improvement and maintenance work on their orbiting residence. For Col. Gennadi I. Padalka of the Russian Air Force and Lt. Col. Edward Mike Fincke of the United States Air Force, it was the fourth excursion outside the station since they took up residence there in April. Working on the Russian side of the complex, the two men first replaced a panel needed to control a cooling pump, then installed three antennas. The antennas will help European automatic freighters rendezvous with the station beginning late next year. The two men also remained motionless for 15 minutes so ground controllers could study why the station tends to tilt as astronauts are outside spacewalking. Stefano S. Coledan (NYT)

stories.abstract: Interview with Mark Shuttleworth, who made half a billion dollars from Internet bubble and paid $20 million for ride in space, on his plan to tour remote, rural schools in his native South Africa with models of space capsule and rockets in bid to stir in students interest in math and science that underpinned his own success; he has set up philanthropic foundation to promote desire for schooling in South Africa; photo (M)

headline.main: The First 'Afronaut' Plans a Mission Back Home

stories.snippet: PERHAPS the most obvious question to ask Mark Shuttleworth is this: after making half a billion dollars from the Internet bubble at the age of 26 and, two years later, buying a $20 million ride in space to become what Nelson Mandela called the first...
stories.lead_paragraph: PERHAPS the most obvious question to ask Mark Shuttleworth is this: after making half a billion dollars from the Internet bubble at the age of 26 and, two years later, buying a $20 million ride in space to become what Nelson Mandela called the first ''Afronaut,'' what do you do for an encore? The response from this unassuming, South African-born entrepreneur is unexpected. Having achieved in a few years what most would not achieve in a lifetime, Mr. Shuttleworth, 28, said he did not want to try to re-create the intensity of his experiences in space or in business, despite having the personal wealth to try almost anything.

stories.abstract: Lisa Guernsey article on ambiguity of math and science questions on increasingly important standardized tests; example (special section, Education Life) (M)

headline.main: None Of the Above

stories.snippet: TWO years ago, fifth graders taking Texas's annual standardized science test faced this multiple-choice question: ''Which two planets are closest to Earth?'' The four choices were ''Mercury and Saturn,'' ''Mars and Jupiter,'' ''Mercury and Venus''...
stories.lead_paragraph: TWO years ago, fifth graders taking Texas's annual standardized science test faced this multiple-choice question: ''Which two planets are closest to Earth?'' The four choices were ''Mercury and Saturn,'' ''Mars and Jupiter,'' ''Mercury and Venus'' and ''Venus and Mars.'' Simple, right? The Texas Education Agency thought so; every fifth grader should know that Venus and Mars orbit on either side of Earth's orbit (remember the mnemonic ''My Very Excellent Mother Just Sent Us Nine Pizzas''?). ''Venus and Mars,'' therefore, would have been a good pick.

stories.abstract: Some astronomers now think they have identified new class of explosive bursts of gamma rays in deep space; say more than 100 such gamma-ray bursts appear to have originated relatively nearby, within few hundred million light-years; say if that is correct, many of bursts could be caused by explosions of extremely massive stars called Supernovas Type Ib or Ic; such 'local' source could also explain existence of especially high-energy cosmic rays that bombard near space; findings are described by Dr Jay P Norris of NASA Goddard Space Flight Center at conference of American Astronomical Society (M)

headline.main: Some Bursts of Gamma Rays May Be in Nearby Galaxies

stories.snippet: Astronomers have recorded more than 3,000 explosive bursts of gamma rays in deep space over the last decade. As mysterious as they are powerful, the bursts are unpredictable and fade from view so quickly that their sources are hard to determine, but...
stories.lead_paragraph: Astronomers have recorded more than 3,000 explosive bursts of gamma rays in deep space over the last decade. As mysterious as they are powerful, the bursts are unpredictable and fade from view so quickly that their sources are hard to determine, but most have appeared to originate billions of light-years from Earth in what are the most tremendous known explosions in the universe. Some astronomers now think they have identified a new class of these gamma-ray bursts. To the surprise of many scientists, more than 100 of the previously detected bursts appear to have originated relatively nearby, within a few hundred million light-years.

stories.abstract: New observations of X-rays from young stars in constallation Orion reveal that Sun, when newly born, had repeated eruptions of storms of particles and radiation that may have influenced formation of planets and salted early solar system with radioactive particles; research is described by Dr Eric Feigelson, who led work using NASA's orbiting Chandra X-Ray Observatory (M)

headline.main: Star Study Suggests Sun Had a Violent Youth

stories.snippet: New observations have revealed that just after the Sun was born, it was almost certainly much more violent than previously believed, repeatedly erupting with storms of particles and radiation that may have influenced the formation of planets and...
stories.lead_paragraph: New observations have revealed that just after the Sun was born, it was almost certainly much more violent than previously believed, repeatedly erupting with storms of particles and radiation that may have influenced the formation of planets and salted the early solar system with radioactive particles. The observations, of X-rays streaming from young stars in the constellation Orion, add fuel to a longstanding controversy over exactly how the solar system and the planets formed. The new results may also help explain mysterious grains imbedded in some meteorites that contain the decay products of rare radioactive elements.

stories.abstract: Interview with Dr Sally K Ride, first woman in space, explores her personal involvement with both shuttle disaster investigations and her experience and knowledge of NASA; she explains how, with both Challenger and Columbia shuttles, reoccurring non-catastrophic defects came to be taken for granted and resulted in disaster; also contends NASA's shift in internal culture which resulted in NASA Adminstrator Dan Goldin's emphasis on going faster, better and cheaper from 1992 to 2001, also influenced personnel, enabling them to make assumptions rather than root out solutions to problems or underlying issues; photos (L)

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH/Sally Ride; Painful Questions From an Ex-Astronaut

stories.snippet: Though she is a true pioneer, Dr. Sally K. Ride, the first American woman in space, strode into a hotel lobby here this month and went unnoticed. Dr. Ride, 52, enjoys going about life with a degree of anonymity.     After her flights in 1983 and...
stories.lead_paragraph: Though she is a true pioneer, Dr. Sally K. Ride, the first American woman in space, strode into a hotel lobby here this month and went unnoticed. Dr. Ride, 52, enjoys going about life with a degree of anonymity. After her flights in 1983 and 1984, Dr. Ride, at the time one of the most famous women on earth, rejected most product endorsements, books and movie offers that came her way.

stories.abstract: Similarities between Challenger and Columbia disasters make it clear that NASA's culture was as much at fault for loss of two space shuttles as failing O-rings and insulating foam debris; Diane Vaughan, who wrote study of Challenger accident, sees flawed culture at NASA in which most participants gradually demote their concerns, causing major problems to devolve into lower-level issues; says making individuals accountable for mistakes can backfire by making it look as if problems have been cleared up while organizational problems that shaped individuals' decisions go unchecked; photo (M)

headline.main: Echoes of Challenger: Shuttle Panel Considers Longstanding Flaws in NASA's System

stories.snippet: ''I'm hearing a little bit of an echo here,'' said Dr. Sally Ride.    She was not talking about the acoustics of the hotel ballroom where she and other members of the independent board investigating the loss of the shuttle Columbia convened for two...

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ with MATTHEW L. WALD

stories.lead_paragraph: ''I'm hearing a little bit of an echo here,'' said Dr. Sally Ride. She was not talking about the acoustics of the hotel ballroom where she and other members of the independent board investigating the loss of the shuttle Columbia convened for two days of hearings this week. Dr. Ride, the first American woman in space, was talking about history repeating itself.

stories.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery is launched on mission to deliver fresh crew to International Space Station; photo (S)

headline.main: Space Shuttle Is Launched Ahead of Storm

stories.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery roared into orbit today on a mission to deliver a fresh crew to the International Space Station, leaving early to beat approaching storms.    The shuttle climbed into a clear but hazy sky at 5:10 p.m., carrying seven...
stories.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery roared into orbit today on a mission to deliver a fresh crew to the International Space Station, leaving early to beat approaching storms. The shuttle climbed into a clear but hazy sky at 5:10 p.m., carrying seven astronauts, three of whom will spend the next four months in space. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration launched the spaceship five minutes earlier than planned because of thunderstorms moving in from the south.

stories.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery is launched on mission to deliver $1 billion bus-size laboratory known as Kibo module to International Space Station; NASA officials are not concerned about danger from pieces of foam that video showed falling off shuttle's external fuel tank during launch; laboratory is second and largest of three shuttle payloads that will bring full Kibo assembly to space station; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Discovery Heads Toward the Space Station

stories.snippet: The shuttle blasted its way into orbit through wispy clouds against blue skies on its way to deliver a bus-size laboratory to the International Space Station.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Biographies of the astronauts on board the space shuttleDiscovery for its latest trip to the International Space Station.

stories.lead_paragraph: The shuttle Discovery blasted its way into orbit on Saturday through wispy clouds against blue skies on its way to deliver a bus-size laboratory to the International Space Station. The column of smoke, bright white against the brilliant day, cast a shadow to the east as the shuttle ascended, and the sound waves made the air shudder.

stories.abstract: Adm Harold W Gehman, chairman of board that investigated Columbia space shuttle disaster, agrees to examine NASA's decision to cancel any missions to extend life of Hubble Space Telescope; Sen Barbara A Mikulski questioned NASA's decision; Sean O'Keefe, NASA administrator, leads agencywide commemoration of lives that have been lost since beginning of space program and declares that last Thursday in every January will be set aside as Day of Remembrance to honor crews of shuttles Columbia and Challenger, as well as astronauts killed in Apollo 1 fire in 1967 (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Investigator Will Review Hubble Decision

stories.snippet: The head of the board that investigated the Columbia space shuttle disaster has agreed to examine NASA's decision to cancel any missions to extend the life of the Hubble Space Telescope, agency officials said on Thursday.    The chairman of the...
stories.lead_paragraph: The head of the board that investigated the Columbia space shuttle disaster has agreed to examine NASA's decision to cancel any missions to extend the life of the Hubble Space Telescope, agency officials said on Thursday. The chairman of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board, Adm. Harold W. Gehman Jr., is to review the safety of having shuttle astronauts refurbish the orbiting observatory.

stories.abstract: Entrepeneurs Hamid Ansari, his wife Anousheh and brother Amir join Space Adventures Ltd to develop passenger spacecraft for suborbital flight; Space Adventures announces it will build spaceport in United Arab Emirates for $30 million; developments are beginning of space tourism industry; president and chief executive Eric C Anderson draws parallel to early days of commercial aircraft industry; Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Galactic will compete with Space Adventures in rivalry Anderson sees as healthy for success; flights can begin as early as late 2008 (M)

headline.main: More Enter Race to Offer Space Tours

stories.snippet: Plans for a new rocket company and a spaceport in the United Arab Emirates are heating up the commercial space race.
stories.lead_paragraph: Now it's a space race. The space tourism industry, its millionaire would-be passengers impatiently tapping on their platinum credit cards, just got a little more crowded, with the announcements of a new rocket development company and of plans to build a $265 million spaceport in the United Arab Emirates.

stories.abstract: Rep Brad Miller and Sen Bill Nelson, leaders of Senate and House subcommittees overseeing NASA, call for removal of Inspector General Robert W Cobb; Cobb has been subject of investigation by President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency on charges that he retaliated against whistle-blowers and failed to look properly into safety and security issues (M)

headline.main: Lawmakers Call for Ouster Of Top Inspector At Space Agency

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PRESIDENT'S COUNCIL ON INTEGRITY AND EFFICIENCY

stories.snippet: Leaders of Senate and House subcommittees overseeing NASA said the agency’s inspector general had abused his authority and created a hostile workplace.
stories.lead_paragraph: Leaders of Senate and House subcommittees overseeing NASA called for removal of its inspector general on Monday, saying he had abused his authority and created a hostile workplace that interfered with his office's doing its job. In a letter to President Bush, Representative Brad Miller, a North Carolina Democrat who heads the Investigations and Oversight Subcommittee of the House Science and Technology Committee, and Senator Bill Nelson, a Florida Democrat who heads the Senate Subcommittee on Space, Aeronautics and Related Matters, called for removal of the NASA official, Robert W. Cobb.

stories.abstract: President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency is investigating NASA inspector general Robert W Cobb on charges that he retaliated against whistle-blowers and failed to look properly into safety and security issues at space agency (M)

headline.main: Investigator At NASA Faces Inquiry Over Safety

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PRESIDENT'S COUNCIL ON INTEGRITY AND EFFICIENCY

stories.snippet: NASA's chief investigator is being investigated by a federal watchdog agency on charges that he retaliated against whistle-blowers.
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA's chief investigator is being investigated by a federal watchdog agency on charges that he retaliated against whistle-blowers and failed to look properly into safety and security issues at the space agency, officials said Friday. NASA was notified by the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency that its Integrity Committee was looking into the actions of the official, Robert W. Cobb, a former White House ethics lawyer who was appointed the agency's inspector general in 2002.

headline.main: The World Is His Stage; Paul Dundes Wolfowitz

stories.snippet: Paul D. Wolfowitz said the World Bank was a logical extension of his longtime goal to spread human rights and political freedoms around the globe.
stories.lead_paragraph: After surveying the tsunami-pummeled coast of Indonesia from a Navy helicopter in January, Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz appeared shaken at the devastation. ''When you fly over in a helicopter you just begin to get a sense of how enormous this tragedy has been, and when people don't just lose a parent or a brother, but they lose their entire family, it gives a new horrible meaning to what it means to be a survivor,'' he told reporters in Banda Aceh.

stories.abstract: Man in the News article on New York City's new schools chancellor Joel Irwin Klein (M)

headline.kicker: THE NEW SCHOOLS CHANCELLOR: MAN IN THE NEWS
headline.main: A Path Back to School -- Joel Irwin Klein

stories.snippet: New York City's new schools chancellor is not an easy man to shop for. When he stepped down as assistant attorney general in charge of antitrust enforcement at the Justice Department in 2000, having led the government's prosecution of Microsoft, his...
stories.lead_paragraph: New York City's new schools chancellor is not an easy man to shop for. When he stepped down as assistant attorney general in charge of antitrust enforcement at the Justice Department in 2000, having led the government's prosecution of Microsoft, his senior staff members huddled about a farewell gift. Though their boss, Joel I. Klein, had spent almost his entire career in Washington, he never gave up a certain directness of manner that many associate with New York City. He is impatient, friends say, with the paraphernalia that surrounds powerful people in both cities.

stories.abstract: Federally-financed New York Climate and Health Project, released by Columbia University scientists, predicts that metropolitan area will be hotter, wetter and unhealthier place to live well before end of 21st century; sees air pollution and heat-related deaths increasing as global temperatures rise by 2.4 to 10.4 degrees by 2100 (M),

headline.main: Forecast for New York This Century: Hotter and Wetter

stories.snippet: It will not happen the day after tomorrow. Nor a decade from now.     But well before this century ends, global warming will make New York City and the metropolitan area that surrounds it a hotter, wetter and significantly less healthy place to live...
stories.lead_paragraph: It will not happen the day after tomorrow. Nor a decade from now. But well before this century ends, global warming will make New York City and the metropolitan area that surrounds it a hotter, wetter and significantly less healthy place to live and work, according to a federally financed study released on Friday by a group of scientists at Columbia University.

stories.abstract: Anthony Tommasini reviews concert version of Strauss opera Daphne, starring Renee Fleming and featuring WDR Symphony Orchestra conducted by Semyon Bychkov; photo (M)

headline.main: Soprano Taking Chances As a Feisty Wood Nymph

stories.snippet: Rene Fleming brought affecting sensitivity and sublime phrasing to the diaphanous music of Strauss's "Daphne" on Saturday at Carnegie Hall.
stories.lead_paragraph: For all her self-confidence and career success, Rene Fleming has mostly shied away from the touchstone roles of the operatic repertory, especially its Verdi and Puccini wing. She has said more than once that she has been hiding for years behind unfamiliar repertory. But by seeking out unfamiliar repertory, like the leading roles in Bellini's ''Pirata'' and Handel's ''Rodelinda,'' Ms. Fleming often takes admirable risks. This is certainly true of her latest venture, the title role of Strauss's ''Daphne,'' which she sang in a much-anticipated concert performance on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, with a strong cast and the WDR Symphony Orchestra of Cologne, conducted by Semyon Bychkov.

stories.abstract: Article on Richard Strauss's opera Daphne, which is enjoying modest renaissance; soprano Renee Fleming is starring in three-city concert-version mini-tour with WDR Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Semyon Bychkov; photos (M)

headline.main: Unsingable Maybe, Yet 'Daphne' Blooms

stories.snippet: With a new champion in Rene Fleming, Richard Strauss's striking opera, "Daphne," is enjoying a modest renaissance.
stories.lead_paragraph: ''Daphne'' is the story of a woman who turns into a tree. Dramatic? Indubitably. Operatic? It depends on your outlook. After all, what you're left with, after the coup de thtre, is a singing tree, which cannot but strike some listeners as a wee bit static. ''Aida'' it's not. And yet Richard Strauss's late opera (which had its first performance in 1938) is enjoying a modest renaissance. There have been recent productions in Venice, Essen, Berlin and Vienna; and last season, New York City Opera gave it its first American staging. Now, it has won a powerful new champion in the soprano Rene Fleming, who has recorded the work with Semyon Bychkov and the WDR Symphony Orchestra. Tomorrow, she and Mr. Bychkov bring it to Carnegie Hall in the course of a three-city minitour that will continue to the Kennedy Center.

stories.abstract: Distributed computing, in which a large problem or significant amount of data is parceled out to many--even millions--of computers to work on at once, is becoming viable substitute for once vaunted supercomputer; best-known distributed computing project is SETIatHome (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence), developed at University of California, Berkeley, which offers a screen saver program designed for home computers that also analyzes radio signals from cosmos for patterns of signs of alien life; most of SETIatHome users probably have never noticed computing time they have devoted to project because screen saver makes great use of each computer's idle time; other projects noted; distributed programming is also being looked at for its commercial potential, with computers possibly being able to rent out processing time; photo; chart on sites that offer information on distributed programming (L)

headline.main: The Secret Life of the Home Computer

stories.snippet: IDLE hands may be the devil's workshop, but an idle computer has the potential to seek out extraterrestrial life, crack encryption codes and maybe make a little extra cash for its owner.    Distributed computing, in which a large problem or daunting...
stories.lead_paragraph: IDLE hands may be the devil's workshop, but an idle computer has the potential to seek out extraterrestrial life, crack encryption codes and maybe make a little extra cash for its owner. Distributed computing, in which a large problem or daunting amount of data is parceled out to many -- even millions -- of computers to work on at once, is becoming a viable substitute for the once-almighty supercomputer. Even the humblest home machine can become a cog in a larger computational wheel, receiving data, churning through it at its own speed and returning the results. It's a digital-age illustration of the old adage about how to eat an elephant: one bite at a time.

stories.abstract: Distributed computing, which involves millions of Internet users, achieves tasks that would take the world's fastest supercomputer years to complete; projects utilize terminals' unused processing power to help analyze data and perform computer simulations for research; new and largest program is on behalf of SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence); program was developed at University of California and allows volunteers to take part in multiple projects; photo (M)

headline.main: Getting More From a PC's Spare Time

stories.snippet: SOME people talk, sometimes in jest, about leaving their brains to science. But others have found a more immediate way to help: lending their computers' brains.     Millions of PC users are volunteering their terminals' unused processing power to...
stories.lead_paragraph: SOME people talk, sometimes in jest, about leaving their brains to science. But others have found a more immediate way to help: lending their computers' brains. Millions of PC users are volunteering their terminals' unused processing power to help analyze data and perform computer simulations for research into an AIDS cure, climate prediction or the mysteries of biological proteins.

stories.abstract: Boeing vice president Michael I Mott defends reports by company's engineers, which concluded that space shuttle Columbia faced no catastrophic safety threat from damage caused by debris that struck its left wing during takeoff from Cape Canaveral on January 15; findings are under intense scrutiny by NASA and investigation board probing breakup of spacecraft on February 2 during reentry into earth's atmosphere; reports used computer modeling techniques to predict area of impact and potential damage to protective heat-resistant tiles; have been criticized by outside experts as incomplete and based on questionable assumptions (M)

headline.kicker: LOSS OF THE SHUTTLE: THE BUILDER
headline.main: Boeing Official Defends Reports Discounting Peril After Liftoff

stories.snippet: A senior Boeing executive today defended the work of his company's analysts who concluded that the space shuttle Columbia faced no catastrophic safety threat from damage caused by debris that struck its left wing some 81 seconds after liftoff.    ...
stories.lead_paragraph: A senior Boeing executive today defended the work of his company's analysts who concluded that the space shuttle Columbia faced no catastrophic safety threat from damage caused by debris that struck its left wing some 81 seconds after liftoff. NASA managers relied on two reports produced by analysts of the Boeing Company to help them decide whether the seven members of the Columbia's crew faced any peril upon re-entry into the atmosphere. Because the first signs of trouble came from sensor readings in Columbia's left wing, the Boeing reports are now under intense scrutiny by NASA and the accident investigation board.

stories.abstract: John Glenn, former senator who was first American to orbit Earth, says he opposes cutting money from International Space Station and basic scientific research to pay for Pres Bush's goal of sending astronauts to Moon and Mars (S)

headline.main: Former Senator-Astronaut Criticizes Space Plan

stories.snippet: John Glenn, the former senator who was the first American to orbit the Earth, said Thursday that he opposed cutting money from the International Space Station and basic scientific research to pay for President Bush's goal of sending astronauts to the...
stories.lead_paragraph: John Glenn, the former senator who was the first American to orbit the Earth, said Thursday that he opposed cutting money from the International Space Station and basic scientific research to pay for President Bush's goal of sending astronauts to the Moon and Mars. Testifying at a hearing of the new presidential commission on space exploration at the Air Force Museum in Dayton, Ohio, Mr. Glenn said it would be wrong to redirect space station research to make it applicable to human spaceflight to the Moon and Mars and to abandon the more expansive studies previously planned.

stories.abstract: John Glenn, first American to orbit Earth, visits Smithsonian exhibit of 1962 Friendship 7 space capsule in which he circled planet three times; Glenn, now 80, says he remembers whole flight; photo (M)

headline.main: Space Pioneer Glenn Recalls Old Glory

stories.snippet: Forty years ago today, America held its breath and found its heart as John Herschel Glenn Jr. became the first American to orbit Earth.    Mr. Glenn, who went around the globe three times on Feb. 20, 1962, and put the United States back into the...
stories.lead_paragraph: Forty years ago today, America held its breath and found its heart as John Herschel Glenn Jr. became the first American to orbit Earth. Mr. Glenn, who went around the globe three times on Feb. 20, 1962, and put the United States back into the space race with the former Soviet Union, said today that he still vividly recalled the details.
