stories.abstract: Highlights of pop and jazz festivals across US this summer; photos (M)

headline.main: POP/JAZZ

stories.snippet: California    ALL TOMORROW'S PARTIES -- Los Angeles, June 19-22. Begun in England four years ago, this occasional series has become one of the world's most innovative pop festivals by applying a simple principle: hand over the programming to a...
stories.lead_paragraph: California ALL TOMORROW'S PARTIES -- Los Angeles, June 19-22. Begun in England four years ago, this occasional series has become one of the world's most innovative pop festivals by applying a simple principle: hand over the programming to a well-connected artist or musician and allow every nepotistic indulgence. What results is more variety than you'd expect. After having the New York brahmins of Sonic Youth program a Los Angeles festival a year ago, the organizers have made a more local but still stranger curatorial choice: Matt Groening, the creator of ''The Simpsons,'' who was a rock critic early in his career and seems to have been paying a good deal of attention to alternative music. His highlights include Wire, the Boredoms, Coldcut, Johnny Dowd, the Melvins, Mission of Burma, Kool Keith, Fantomas, Melt-Banana, Yo La Tengo, Le Tigre and the Fall. Mr. Groening has also arranged the reunion of Captain Beefheart's Magic Band after more than 20 years, minus the captain, Don Van Vliet, who remains immovable in his new life as a painter. (Another A.T.P. festival, with Stephen Malkmus as the boss, was planned for the New York area in September but has been postponed.) www.atpfestival.com

stories.abstract: Researchers from Cornell University, University of Virginia and NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory report in journal Science findings that support theory that Titan, Saturn's largest moon, is covered in liquid oceans; Titan's surface temperature, estimated at minus 290 degrees, leads scientists to believe oceans are hydrocarbon based; some astronomers hypothesize that conditions on Titan are similar to those of early earth; data taken by Voyager spacecraft, Hubble Space Telescope and Arecibo radio telescope discussed; NASA's Cassini spacecraft, scheduled to arrive at Saturn in July 2004, carries probe that is to parachute onto Titan and hopefully assess landing surface; photo (M)

headline.main: Saturn's Biggest Moon Starts to Divulge Some of Its Secrets

stories.snippet: Something on Titan, Saturn's largest moon, is very flat, possibly as flat as the surface of an ocean.    Through an experiment involving radar on an interplanetary scale, astronomers have made the first observations that support a long-held suspicion...
stories.lead_paragraph: Something on Titan, Saturn's largest moon, is very flat, possibly as flat as the surface of an ocean. Through an experiment involving radar on an interplanetary scale, astronomers have made the first observations that support a long-held suspicion that liquid oceans cover much of Titan.

stories.abstract: Keck II telescope in Hawaii captures images of Uranus rings from unlighted side, which is clearer view; Imke de Pater, University of California, Berkeley, astronomer who led research, reports that rings have changed since 1986 images taken by Voyager 2; holds that widespread dust in possible reason; photos (M)

headline.main: In a Rare View, Rings on Uranus Show Their Changes

stories.snippet: It’s that time of year on the distant planet  when its ring system appears edge-on to observers on Earth.
stories.lead_paragraph: It's that time of year on Uranus -- time for the semiannual ring-plane crossing, when the planet's ring system appears edge-on to observers on Earth. (Unlike the other planets, Uranus spins on its side, making for extreme changes in viewing angles.) The crossing allows telescopes to take pictures of the rings from the unlighted side, free from the glare that can obscure faint parts of them. Of course, a year on Uranus is equivalent to 84 Earth years, so this semiannual event is happening for the first time since the planet's rings were discovered, in 1977. And it's causing some rethinking about the rings and their stability.

stories.abstract: Cassini, first spacecraft to orbit Saturn, swiftly turns its cameras on, transmitting striking pictures of planet's rings of ice and rock; Dr Carolyn C Porco, mission's chief photographic interpreter, calls beauty and clarity of black-and-white pictures 'mind-blowing'; they are far superior in number and close-up detail to any previous images of Saturn's most distinctive feature; photos and other scientific data are first payoffs of Cassini's 1.2-billion-mile journey of nearly 7 years; $3.3 billion mission is partnership of NASA, European Space Agency and Italian Space Agency; hope is that investigation of Saturn's rings will provide insight into how stars and planetary systems formed from disks of interstellar matter; Saturn's greatest moon, Titan, may hold clues to how life emerged on primitive Earth; photos; drawing (M)

headline.main: From Ringside, Dazzling Photos Show Saturn's Swirling Wreaths

stories.snippet: The first spacecraft to orbit Saturn, arriving late Wednesday, swiftly turned its cameras on the planet's rings of ice and rock, and transmitted striking pictures of the encircling luminous strands, some with scalloped edges, strawlike textures and...
stories.lead_paragraph: The first spacecraft to orbit Saturn, arriving late Wednesday, swiftly turned its cameras on the planet's rings of ice and rock, and transmitted striking pictures of the encircling luminous strands, some with scalloped edges, strawlike textures and rippling waves that spread across the shimmering disk. Scientists could not have been more delighted.

stories.abstract: Huygens probe, which is joint mission of National Aeronautics and Space Administration, European Space Agency and Italian Space Agency, is due to land on Titan, Saturn's largest moon; mission officials hope data collected will unmask moon's surface, which is shrouded by clouds of gases and difficult to view from space; Titan is thought to hold clues to origin of life on earth; probe, which will send data from moon for around two hours before losing power, is part of Cassini spacecraft mission; photo (M)

headline.main: Craft Closes In on a Saturn Moon, and on Clues to Life's Beginnings

stories.snippet: The spacecraft's plunge into Titan would be the first direct contact with the surface of a moon of another planet.
stories.lead_paragraph: A saucer-shaped spacecraft is fast approaching Saturn's dominant moon, Titan, and is on course to plunge into the atmosphere and descend by parachutes on Friday morning for the first direct contact with the surface of a moon of another planet. From afar, Titan has long intrigued astronomers. Bigger than the planets Mercury and Pluto and only slightly smaller than Mars, Titan is the only moon in the solar system with a substantial atmosphere, a place where conditions may hold clues to the origins of life on Earth.

stories.abstract: Ed Cogburn letter on Jack Hitt's August 5 article on drive to militarize space holds weapons could be acquired cheaply by US enemies through espionage

headline.main: Battlefield: Space

stories.snippet: This was a terrifying article. I can picture the huge sums expended to create these weapons, only to be acquired cheaply by our enemies through espionage.    Ed Cogburn  Houston
stories.lead_paragraph: This was a terrifying article. I can picture the huge sums expended to create these weapons, only to be acquired cheaply by our enemies through espionage. Ed Cogburn Houston

stories.abstract: Andrew Page letter on Jack Hitt's August 5 article on drive to militarize space holds technology can never be retained exclusively by US

headline.main: Battlefield: Space

stories.snippet: I appreciated Jack Hitt's (Aug. 5) frank investigation of the drive to militarize space. One thing that struck me was the quote from Col. James Rogers: ''The problem is not another superpower but a guy with a credit card.''    If that's the case,...
stories.lead_paragraph: I appreciated Jack Hitt's (Aug. 5) frank investigation of the drive to militarize space. One thing that struck me was the quote from Col. James Rogers: ''The problem is not another superpower but a guy with a credit card.'' If that's the case, then why is the Pentagon pushing to develop the sort of technology that ultimately gives that guy with a credit card so much lethal power? We should have learned by now that the United States may forge the path and set the pace for developing lethal technologies but that we never exclusively retain that knowledge. Andrew Page Berkeley, Calif.

stories.abstract: America's return to moon is part of Google Lunar X Prize, competition sponsored by Google with $30 million in prizes for first two teams to land robotic rover on moon and send images and other data back home; 10 teams from five countries announce their intention to participate in competition; Google will pay $20 million to first team that lands on moon, sends package of data back to Earth, then travels at least 500 meters and sends another data package; second team will receive $5 million; photo (M)

headline.main: A Google Competition, With a Robotic Moon Landing as a Goal

stories.snippet: Ten teams from five countries plan to compete for $30 million in prizes in the Google-sponsored race to the moon.
stories.lead_paragraph: More than three decades after the last Apollo astronauts roamed the lunar surface, disparate universities, open-source engineers and quixotic aerospace start-ups are planning to start their own robotic missions to the Earth's barren cousin. The return to the moon is part of the Google Lunar X Prize, a competition sponsored by Google with $30 million in prizes for the first two teams to land a robotic rover on the moon and send images and other data back home.

stories.abstract: Netflix plans to award $1 million to first person who can improve accuracy of its movie recommendations based on personal preferences; winning system must be at least 10 percent more accurate than current methods; Netflix employees are not eligible to enter contest; photo (M)

headline.main: And if You Liked the Movie, a Netflix Contest May Reward You Handsomely

stories.snippet: Netflix plans to award $1 million to the first person who can improve the accuracy of movie recommendations based on personal preferences.
stories.lead_paragraph: Netflix, the popular online movie rental service, is planning to award $1 million to the first person who can improve the accuracy of movie recommendations based on personal preferences. To win the prize, which is to be announced today, a contestant will have to devise a system that is more accurate than the company's current recommendation system by at least 10 percent. And to improve the quality of research, Netflix is making available to the public 100 million of its customers' movie ratings, a database the company says is the largest of its kind ever released.

stories.abstract: On Stage and Off column; industrywide plummet in box-office receipts leads to closing of Hollywood Arms and Proof, and spares only strongest productions, such as Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune with new stars Rosie Perez and Joe Pantoliano; producers turn to television ads, discount offers and 7PM Tuesday curtain to lure suburbanites; list of Off Broadway failures is even longer and costlier, including Tommy Tune debacle White Tie and Tails, Little Ham and even The Vagina Monologues; Circle in the Square announces 'final weeks' for Metamorphoses; New York City Opera will present Stephen Sondheim's A Little Night Music on Broadway, Scott Ellis directing and Jeremy Irons starring; photo (M)

headline.main: ON STAGE AND OFF

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: FRANKIE AND JOHNNY IN THE CLAIR DE LUNE (PLAY)

stories.snippet: A Box Office Like an Icebox      They knew it was coming. Ever since last summer, when it became apparent that Broadway ticketbuyers weren't buying as many seats in advance as they had in the past, Broadway producers have been girding themselves for...
stories.lead_paragraph: A Box Office Like an Icebox They knew it was coming. Ever since last summer, when it became apparent that Broadway ticketbuyers weren't buying as many seats in advance as they had in the past, Broadway producers have been girding themselves for the possibility of a harsher winter than usual. Sure enough, that moment arrived in force on Sunday with the closing of two productions -- ''Hollywood Arms'' and ''Proof'' -- and an industrywide post-holiday plummet in box-office receipts.

stories.abstract: Joan Jett discusses her bad-girl-of-rock reputation and role in Rocky Horror Show at Circle in the Square Theater; photo (Public Lives column) (S)

headline.main: A Determined Rocker Takes On Broadway

stories.snippet: STRIPPED down to the bare essentials -- tattoos and a tiger-stripe bikini thong -- between costume changes for a publicity shoot at the Circle in the Square Theater, Joan M. Jett seems less formidable than the sneering, snarling bad-girl-of-rock...
stories.lead_paragraph: STRIPPED down to the bare essentials -- tattoos and a tiger-stripe bikini thong -- between costume changes for a publicity shoot at the Circle in the Square Theater, Joan M. Jett seems less formidable than the sneering, snarling bad-girl-of-rock reputation that preceded her to Broadway. Her speaking voice is a tired contralto, and beneath a rainbow of lid-to-brow stage makeup, her left eye is flecked with blood: she spent the morning at the hospital having a piece of theater grit extracted by her favorite physician, the one she entrusts with her vocal cords. But Ms. Jett's ''Rocky Horror Show'' understudy won't inherit her dual roles as Columbia and Usherette, or that solo wail on guitar in ''The Time Warp,'' tonight. No one has ever called Ms. Jett a quitter. When 23 record companies declined to produce her first album, dismissing a leather-wrapped, guitar-slinging teenage girl as offensively unmarketable, she did it herself.

stories.abstract: Article on new Sundance Channel show Spectacle: Elvis Costello With...; program features mix of music and music-oriented talk with musician Elvis Costello serving as host, musical director and performer; photos (M)

headline.main: Is It a Talk Show if the Host Sings?

stories.snippet: ELVIS COSTELLO would be a natural on TV -- or so people kept telling him. For years he believed it, entertaining meetings with the BBC and others as far back as the late 1980s about developing his own show. But nothing stuck, even after he filled in...
stories.lead_paragraph: ELVIS COSTELLO would be a natural on TV -- or so people kept telling him. For years he believed it, entertaining meetings with the BBC and others as far back as the late 1980s about developing his own show. But nothing stuck, even after he filled in as a host of ''Late Show'' when David Letterman was recovering from shingles in 2003. Cue Elton John. Mr. John and David Furnish, his partner, are friends of Mr. Costello's through his wife, the jazz singer and pianist Diana Krall. (The two were married at Mr. John and Mr. Furnish's English castle in 2003.) So last year, when Mr. Furnish was approached by a Canadian production company about creating a music-oriented program, one frontman came to mind.

stories.abstract: Columbia, NASA's oldest space shuttle, had reputation among pilots as being easy to fly because it performed well in orbit, but was considered difficult to launch, and spent lots of time in shop for various leaks and quirks; first flight was Apr 12, 1981; made 28 flights, launching Chandra observatory and serving as host to dedicated science flights; photo (M)

headline.main: 'Easy to Fly' Reputation, But Shuttle Had Quirks

stories.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia was long considered a somewhat odd spacecraft by many of its crews. Pilots liked it because it performed very well in orbit, but it sometimes took extra efforts to get there.    ''Tough to launch, easy to fly'' became the...
stories.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia was long considered a somewhat odd spacecraft by many of its crews. Pilots liked it because it performed very well in orbit, but it sometimes took extra efforts to get there. ''Tough to launch, easy to fly'' became the mantra associated with the Columbia.

stories.abstract: List of major music and cultural festivals in Europe this spring, summer and fall; photos (L)

headline.main: Evolutionary Sounds

stories.snippet: MUSIC'S evolution -- from Bach to the present -- is the theme of many European festivals, which, in an attempt to attract younger audiences, are adding jazz, popular music and 20th-century classical pieces. The catalyst is Bach, who died in Leipzig...
stories.lead_paragraph: MUSIC'S evolution -- from Bach to the present -- is the theme of many European festivals, which, in an attempt to attract younger audiences, are adding jazz, popular music and 20th-century classical pieces. The catalyst is Bach, who died in Leipzig in 1750 and whose works are a staple of festival programs this year. Under Dresden's ''Baroque to Jazz'' theme, the Silbermann organ in the Court Catholic Church is used as a jazz instrument, and a program featuring the violinist Viktoria Mullova swings from Bach to the Bee Gees and Duke Ellington. Jazz goes classic at Helsinki, Schleswig-Holstein and elsewhere, while Amsterdam's free-wheeling festival highlights the anti-establishment rock performer and composer Frank Zappa.

stories.abstract: Investigators analyzing breakup of space shuttle Columbia say plasma gas probably vaporized part of aluminum frame of spacecraft, which may have exploded like a bomb; also look into whether workers created problem with fuel tank in summer and fall of 2002, when it had to be separated from orbiter and reattached with new rocket boosters; say they still face long investigation, but may be able to detect some problems in shuttles and make recommendations for changes before issuing report, making it easier for shuttle to return to flight; photo; drawing shows deterioration in reinforced carbon panel of leading edge of wing of shuttle Atlantis after flight from November 2002 (M)

headline.main: Investigators Looking at Whether Burning Aluminum Caused Explosion in Shuttle

stories.snippet: Investigators analyzing the breakup of the shuttle Columbia said today that plasma gas had probably vaporized part of the aluminum skeleton of the spacecraft, which may have exploded like a bomb.     Members of the board that is investigating the...

byline.original: By MATTHEW L. WALD and JOHN SCHWARTZ

stories.lead_paragraph: Investigators analyzing the breakup of the shuttle Columbia said today that plasma gas had probably vaporized part of the aluminum skeleton of the spacecraft, which may have exploded like a bomb. Members of the board that is investigating the accident said they were rethinking the model they had been using to understand it by focusing on the possibility that some of the aluminum in the shuttle's frame burned, rather than melted.

stories.abstract: Article on buying memory foam mattress, based on technology developed by NASA; H Thomas Bryant, president of North American operations at Tempur-Pedic, manufacturer of foam mattresses, says foam provides support that conventional mattresses cannot match; photo (M)

headline.main: The Sleep of Forgetfulness (And the Bed Remembers)

stories.snippet: Having trouble falling asleep? Mattresses promoting technology developed by NASA may help.
stories.lead_paragraph: IF you have flipped through a magazine or turned on the television or radio lately, you may have encountered advertisements for mattresses promoting technology developed by NASA. Most people don't associate spaceships with a good night's sleep. After all, who could doze off knowing that there was nothing but a thin layer of metal between them and oblivion?

stories.abstract: International Business Machines supercomputer overtakes NEC Corp machine as world's fastest supercomputer; is based on technology that takes radically different approach from that used in Japanese computer; is one-hundredth size of NEC rival and uses far less power; will have wide commercial applications (M)

headline.main: I.B.M. Supercomputer Sets World Record for Speed

stories.snippet: An I.B.M. machine has reclaimed the title of fastest supercomputer, overtaking a Japanese computer that had caused shock waves at United States government agencies when it set a computing speed record in 2002.
stories.lead_paragraph: An I.B.M. machine has reclaimed the title of world's fastest supercomputer, overtaking a Japanese computer that had caused shock waves at United States government agencies when it set a computing speed record in 2002. Supercomputing technologies were widely viewed as indicators of national industrial prowess in the 1980's and 1990's. They are used extensively in weapons design.

stories.abstract: Congressional hearings on space shuttle Columbia disaster will begin on February 12 with examination of both technical aspects of tragedy and broader issues about safety, costs and ultimate goals of nation's space program; myriad questions to be put to NASA administrator Sean O'Keefe, who will testify at joint hearings by Senate Commerce Science and Transportation Committee and House Science Committee, will go to heart of nation's manned space program; photo (M)

headline.main: Hearings Open at Capitol Today With Vast Range of Queries for NASA

stories.snippet: When lawmakers convene on Wednesday morning for a hearing on the space shuttle disaster, they will examine both the technical aspects of the tragedy and broader issues about safety, costs and the ultimate goals of the nation's space program.     The...
stories.lead_paragraph: When lawmakers convene on Wednesday morning for a hearing on the space shuttle disaster, they will examine both the technical aspects of the tragedy and broader issues about safety, costs and the ultimate goals of the nation's space program. The laundry list of questions to be put to NASA's administrator, Sean O'Keefe, will go to the heart of the manned space program.

stories.abstract: Senate Commerce Committee and House subcommittee on space and aeronautics will convene joint hearings on Feb 12 to begin their inquiries into space shuttle Columbia disaster (M)

headline.main: House and Senate Panels Will Hold Joint Hearing on Shuttle

stories.snippet: House and Senate committees with oversight of the space program will convene a joint hearing next Wednesday to begin their inquiries into what caused the breakup of the shuttle Columbia.     Members of the Senate Commerce Committee and the House...
stories.lead_paragraph: House and Senate committees with oversight of the space program will convene a joint hearing next Wednesday to begin their inquiries into what caused the breakup of the shuttle Columbia. Members of the Senate Commerce Committee and the House subcommittee on space and aeronautics will hear from the NASA administrator, Sean O'Keefe, in their first opportunity to raise questions in public about the loss of the shuttle and its seven astronauts on Saturday.

stories.abstract: Rep Brad Miller and Sen Bill Nelson, leaders of Senate and House subcommittees overseeing NASA, call for removal of Inspector General Robert W Cobb; Cobb has been subject of investigation by President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency on charges that he retaliated against whistle-blowers and failed to look properly into safety and security issues (M)

headline.main: Lawmakers Call for Ouster Of Top Inspector At Space Agency

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PRESIDENT'S COUNCIL ON INTEGRITY AND EFFICIENCY

stories.snippet: Leaders of Senate and House subcommittees overseeing NASA said the agency’s inspector general had abused his authority and created a hostile workplace.
stories.lead_paragraph: Leaders of Senate and House subcommittees overseeing NASA called for removal of its inspector general on Monday, saying he had abused his authority and created a hostile workplace that interfered with his office's doing its job. In a letter to President Bush, Representative Brad Miller, a North Carolina Democrat who heads the Investigations and Oversight Subcommittee of the House Science and Technology Committee, and Senator Bill Nelson, a Florida Democrat who heads the Senate Subcommittee on Space, Aeronautics and Related Matters, called for removal of the NASA official, Robert W. Cobb.

stories.abstract: President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency is investigating NASA inspector general Robert W Cobb on charges that he retaliated against whistle-blowers and failed to look properly into safety and security issues at space agency (M)

headline.main: Investigator At NASA Faces Inquiry Over Safety

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PRESIDENT'S COUNCIL ON INTEGRITY AND EFFICIENCY

stories.snippet: NASA's chief investigator is being investigated by a federal watchdog agency on charges that he retaliated against whistle-blowers.
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA's chief investigator is being investigated by a federal watchdog agency on charges that he retaliated against whistle-blowers and failed to look properly into safety and security issues at the space agency, officials said Friday. NASA was notified by the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency that its Integrity Committee was looking into the actions of the official, Robert W. Cobb, a former White House ethics lawyer who was appointed the agency's inspector general in 2002.

stories.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour lands in Mojave Desert of California because of wind and rain in Florida; crews aboard International Space Station enjoy relaxed workload while entertaining first space tourist, Dennis Tito (S)

headline.main: As Shuttle Returns to Earth, Tourist Adjusts to Space Station

stories.snippet: avoiding rain and wind in Florida, the space shuttle Endeavour landed today in the Mojave Desert of California as crews aboard the International Space Station enjoyed a relaxed workload while entertaining the first space tourist.    The Endeavour,...
stories.lead_paragraph: avoiding rain and wind in Florida, the space shuttle Endeavour landed today in the Mojave Desert of California as crews aboard the International Space Station enjoyed a relaxed workload while entertaining the first space tourist. The Endeavour, with its crew of seven, landed at Edwards Air Force Base at 12:10 p.m. eastern time, completing a successful 12-day mission to the station. Rain and wind at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida prevented a landing there, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration opted to bring the ship down at Edwards, where skies were sunny and clear.

stories.abstract: Wind and rain at emergency landing sites in Spain and Morocco force NASA to call off launching of space shuttle Atlantis on mission to fix International Space Station (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; Shuttle Delayed Till May

stories.snippet: Wind and rain at emergency landing sites in Spain and Morocco forced NASA to call off today's launching of the space shuttle Atlantis on a mission to fix the International Space Station.
stories.lead_paragraph: Wind and rain at emergency landing sites in Spain and Morocco forced NASA to call off today's launching of the space shuttle Atlantis on a mission to fix the International Space Station.

stories.abstract: Gregg and Evan Spiridellis of Web-based JibJab Media create two-minute animated film ridiculing Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry, keeping it light and avoiding partisan nastiness that is typical of much of political discourse on Web; photo (M)

headline.main: A Duet That Straddles the Political Divide

stories.snippet: It was not supposed to be that way, but the tone of political discourse on the Web is often intensely partisan. After all, the Internet can be a medium of infinite narrowness, where the like-minded can visit the same Web sites, blogs and mailing...
stories.lead_paragraph: It was not supposed to be that way, but the tone of political discourse on the Web is often intensely partisan. After all, the Internet can be a medium of infinite narrowness, where the like-minded can visit the same Web sites, blogs and mailing lists, confirming their shared beliefs and prejudices. But in a refreshing break with form, one of the big new hits on the Web is a silly, two-minute satire of the current Republican-Democrat bun fight, starring President Bush and Senator John Kerry as animated cutout figures.

stories.abstract: Relatives of troops who have died in Iraq are far from agreement about war, Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry; many remain supportive of Bush, believing that in ousting Saddam Hussein he struck important blow against tyranny and terrorism; significant number of families have become bitterly disillusioned by war and president who led country into it, calling his actions impetuous, ill conceived or part of personal vendetta; it is not clear whether such anger will translate into political action, because many who oppose war seem unsure about Kerry (M)

headline.main: United in Their Grief, but Divided on What to Do on Election Day

stories.snippet: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 - His only child, Pfc. Tim R. Brown Jr., died in Iraq last year. But Tim R. Brown Sr. supports the war more strongly than ever. And he intends to cast an enthusiastic vote for President Bush in November.
stories.lead_paragraph: His only child, Pfc. Tim R. Brown Jr., died in Iraq last year. But Tim R. Brown Sr. supports the war more strongly than ever. And he intends to cast an enthusiastic vote for President Bush in November. Mr. Brown's former wife, Pam Lois, has serious doubts about the war and questions whether her stepson's death was necessary. A lifelong Republican, she says she is likely to vote for the Democrat, Senator John Kerry, if only to defeat Mr. Bush.

stories.abstract: Barbara R Morgan is about to fulfill two-decade-old dream by becoming first 'educator astronaut' when she and six fellow astronauts blast off in space shuttle Endeavour on Aug 8 on mission to International Space Station; she was backup to first teacher in space, Christa McAuliffe, who died in Challenger explosion in 1986; photo (M)

headline.main: Teacher-Astronaut to Fly Decades After Challenger

stories.snippet: Barbara R. Morgan, a former teacher, is about to fulfill a two-decade-old dream by becoming the first “educator astronaut.”
stories.lead_paragraph: Barbara R. Morgan is now an astronaut by profession, heading into space this week for the first time on the space shuttle. But she said she would be approaching her mission ''with the mind, eyes, ears and heart of a teacher.'' ''That's what I am, a teacher,'' Ms. Morgan said, ''That's what I am at my core.''

stories.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour leaves on 11-day mission to International Space Station; Endeavour astronaut Barbara R Morgan was backup to first teacher in space Christa McAuliffe who died in 1986 Challenger explosion; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Endeavour, With Challenger Legacy, Takes Off

stories.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour lifted off, carrying pieces of the International Space Station and a living reminder of the loss of the shuttle Challenger two decades ago.
stories.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour lifted off into humid skies on Wednesday evening, carrying pieces of the International Space Station and a living reminder of the loss of the shuttle Challenger two decades ago. One of the Endeavour's astronauts, Barbara R. Morgan, was the backup to Christa McAuliffe for the teacher-in-space program in 1986. Ms. Morgan was one of the spectators at the Kennedy Space Center when the Challenger exploded 73 seconds into flight on Jan. 28, 1986, killing Ms. McAuliffe and the other six astronauts.

stories.abstract: Jonathan James, 16, is sentenced in federal court in Miami to six months in juvenile detention for repeatedly hacking into Defense Department and NASA computer systems; photo; he would have served ten years or more had he been an adult; Justice Department says James is first youth to serve time; Atty Gen Janet Reno and US Atty Guy A Lewis issue statements warning of tougher policy on youthful hackers (M)

headline.main: Youth Sentenced in Government Hacking Case

stories.snippet: A 16-year-old from Miami who repeatedly penetrated computer systems of the Defense Department and the space agency has been sentenced to six months in juvenile detention. The Justice Department said he is the first juvenile hacker to be sentenced to...
stories.lead_paragraph: A 16-year-old from Miami who repeatedly penetrated computer systems of the Defense Department and the space agency has been sentenced to six months in juvenile detention. The Justice Department said he is the first juvenile hacker to be sentenced to serve time. The youth, Jonathan James, pleaded guilty in federal court in Miami on Thursday to two counts of juvenile delinquency. Had his crimes been committed by an adult, they would have constituted felonies and drawn a sentence of 10 years or more, said Assistant United States Attorney Richard Boscovich.

stories.abstract: Transportation Sec Norman Mineta calls for tripling US air traffic capacity in next 15-25 years to make room for more jet taxis, private jets, airliner traffic and unmanned government aerial surveillance craft; reports air traffic recovering from Sept 11 terrorist attacks because of improved security and rebounding economy; names former Pentagon official John J Hamre to lead research committee as FAA tries to improve coordination with military, Commerce Department and NASA (M)

headline.main: Tripling of Capacity for Air Traffic Is Sought

stories.snippet: The secretary of transportation called Tuesday for tripling the air traffic capacity of the United States in the next 15 to 20 years to make room for more jet taxis, private jets, airliner traffic and the use of unmanned aerial vehicles.      The...
stories.lead_paragraph: The secretary of transportation called Tuesday for tripling the air traffic capacity of the United States in the next 15 to 20 years to make room for more jet taxis, private jets, airliner traffic and the use of unmanned aerial vehicles. The secretary, Norman Y. Mineta, said that air travel was recovering from the terrorist attacks of 2001 because of improved security and a rebounding economy and that new runways, control towers, air traffic computers and other improvements were being added. But, Mr. Mineta said, ''the changes that are coming are too big, too fundamental for incremental adaptations of the infrastructure.''

stories.abstract: New York Yankees pitcher Roger Clemens, months away from turning 40-years-old, approaches every pitch and every game with same attention to detail that he would in world series game; photo (M)

headline.main: There Are No Such Things As Small Games to Clemens

stories.snippet: Roger Clemens looked in at home plate at the Metrodome on Friday night. He considered all the variables and made his decision. There was much at stake. For Clemens, there always is.    But Clemens was not preparing to pitch. He was not on the mound....
stories.lead_paragraph: Roger Clemens looked in at home plate at the Metrodome on Friday night. He considered all the variables and made his decision. There was much at stake. For Clemens, there always is. But Clemens was not preparing to pitch. He was not on the mound. He was in center field with a golf club in his hand, the celebrity among an eager cluster of fans taking part in a pregame contest sponsored by a local golf-supply store.

stories.abstract: Edward Rothstein Connections column compares past notions of exploration with present, pointing to vast differences between harrowing land and sea expeditions centuries ago and ventures into space today; Columbia shuttle disaster is particularly incomprehensible because exploration today is lacking heroic mythology present in past, and is grounded by attention to detail and routine; linking two extremes, however, is common thread of risk, which ultimately includes death; photos (M)

headline.main: In Any Test of Human Limits, Death Is Among the Judges

stories.snippet: Too much money, too much risk, too much death. In the week since the shuttle disaster, these have been some of the judgments offered as the space program has come under scrutiny. But when have such verdicts not been plausible for journeys of...
stories.lead_paragraph: Too much money, too much risk, too much death. In the week since the shuttle disaster, these have been some of the judgments offered as the space program has come under scrutiny. But when have such verdicts not been plausible for journeys of exploration? In 1848 the British admiral John Franklin sailed with two ships and 129 men to discover a Northwest Passage through the Arctic and disappeared; in 1859, after 30 rescue missions had failed with further loss of life, the wrecks of his ominously named ships, the Erebus and the Terror, were finally found crushed by ice, the skeletons of the crew testifying to untold horrors and suffering.

stories.abstract: Effort is under way to use space shuttle to develop drug to treat Chagas disease, parasitic illness that kills about 45,000 people a year, mostly in Latin America; drugs made through crystallization can be made more uniformly in microgravity of space; Dr Franklin Chang-Diaz, astronaut and physicist, and Dr Lawrence J DeLucas, biochemistry professor on leave to NASA, began string of Chagas experiments on space shuttle in 1996; photo (M)

headline.main: From Jungle to Space in Pursuit of New Drugs

stories.snippet: Dr. Franklin Chang-Diaz, a NASA astronaut with roots in Costa Rica, and Dr. Jose Zaglul, president of a university that specializes in agricultural courses for the humid tropics,  were driving onto Dr. Zaglul's campus in Mercedes, Costa Rica, one day...
stories.lead_paragraph: Dr. Franklin Chang-Diaz, a NASA astronaut with roots in Costa Rica, and Dr. Jose Zaglul, president of a university that specializes in agricultural courses for the humid tropics, were driving onto Dr. Zaglul's campus in Mercedes, Costa Rica, one day in 1991 when they had a short conversation that has turned into a big idea. Dr. Chang-Diaz, who was in Costa Rica to foster greater Latin American participation in space projects, had just met some Chilean scientists who were trying to cure Chagas' disease, a parasitic illness that kills about 45,000 people a year, mostly in Latin America. As leader of Earth University, or Escuela de Agricultura de la Region Tropical Humeda, Dr. Zaglul was passionate about teaching the importance of biodiversity and sustainable development of natural resources.

stories.abstract: NASA officials say they will not be able to give space shuttle ability to repair damage to its heat-protection system in orbit, as recommended by board that investigated loss of Columbia; say that astronauts on Atlantis will carry repair kits when they resume shuttle program, but that kits will allow them to work only on small breaches in heat-shielding tiles and carbon composite on wings' leading edges, not on gashes the size of one believed to have doomed Columbia; push back date for Atlantis mission to at least middle of summer of 2004 from earlier estimate of March or April; studies are under way to use International Space Station as emergency base for astronauts stranded by damaged shuttle (M)

headline.main: NASA Says It Can't Meet Investigation Board's Goals

stories.snippet: NASA officials said today that they would be unable to comply fully with a critical recommendation from the board that investigated the loss of the Columbia and its crew, giving the space shuttle the ability to repair damage to its heat-protection...
stories.lead_paragraph: NASA officials said today that they would be unable to comply fully with a critical recommendation from the board that investigated the loss of the Columbia and its crew, giving the space shuttle the ability to repair damage to its heat-protection system in orbit. The manager of the shuttle engineering office, Steve M. Poulos Jr., told reporters that when the shuttle Atlantis lifted off on the mission that resumes the program, it will carry repair kits so spacewalking astronauts can mend heat-shielding tiles and the carbon composite that protects the wings' leading edges from the fierce heat of re-entry.

stories.abstract: Expert panel from National Academy of Sciences says Hubble Space Telescope is too valuable to be allowed to die in orbit and that NASA should commit to servicing mission, perhaps using astronauts from space shuttle; letter to Admr Sean O'Keefe calls for replacing two major instruments and upgrading batteries and gyroscopes (M)

headline.main: Panel Urges NASA to Save Hubble Space Telescope

stories.snippet: An expert panel from the National Academy of Sciences said Tuesday that the Hubble Space Telescope was too valuable to be allowed to die in orbit and that NASA should commit itself to a servicing mission to extend its life, perhaps with astronauts in...
stories.lead_paragraph: An expert panel from the National Academy of Sciences said Tuesday that the Hubble Space Telescope was too valuable to be allowed to die in orbit and that NASA should commit itself to a servicing mission to extend its life, perhaps with astronauts in a space shuttle. ''NASA should take no actions that would preclude a space shuttle servicing mission to the Hubble Space Telescope,'' the panel said in a letter to Sean O'Keefe, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

stories.abstract: House committee leaders Reps Sherwood Boehlert and Ralph M Hall ask NASA to postpone plans for Orbital Space Plane program because of uncertainties about its role and costs, letter to Admr Sean O'Keefe; holds it is mistake to proceed until national consensus develops about future of human spaceflight; NASA wants plane to serve as lifeboat for astronauts aboard International Space Station and as vehicle to transfer crews to and from space station; craft, in early design stages, would not replace larger, cargo-carrying space shuttle (M)

headline.main: Not So Fast, Lawmakers Say Of NASA Plans For Space Plane

stories.snippet: The leaders of the House Science Committee have asked NASA to postpone plans for a new astronaut-carrying space vehicle because of uncertainties about its role and costs.    In a letter to the NASA administrator, Sean O'Keefe, released on Monday, the...
stories.lead_paragraph: The leaders of the House Science Committee have asked NASA to postpone plans for a new astronaut-carrying space vehicle because of uncertainties about its role and costs. In a letter to the NASA administrator, Sean O'Keefe, released on Monday, the lawmakers said it was a mistake to proceed with the Orbital Space Plane program before the country developed a consensus about the future of human spaceflight.

stories.abstract: Einstein's theory of relativity and speculation about time travel discussed in light of Gen Wesley Clark's remark that he hopes spaceships might one day be engineered to go faster than speed of light, staple of science fiction; drawing (S)

headline.main: The Nation; Beam Us Up, General Clark

stories.snippet: WEIRD things certainly happen during election season, but it's doubtful that even the most hardened seen-it-all pundit would have dreamed that Einstein's theory of relativity would turn up as an issue in an American presidential campaign.    Yet last...
stories.lead_paragraph: WEIRD things certainly happen during election season, but it's doubtful that even the most hardened seen-it-all pundit would have dreamed that Einstein's theory of relativity would turn up as an issue in an American presidential campaign. Yet last week a leading Democratic candidate, Gen. Wesley Clark, expressed the hope that spaceships might one day be engineered to go faster than the speed of light, a staple of science fiction.

stories.abstract: Vision of the future presented in 2001: A Space Odyssey, 1968 film by Stanley Kubrick and Arthur C Clarke, discussed in light of plans to release new version of film, with digital sound and light, next year; photo (M)

headline.main: On the Eve of 2001, the Future Is Not Quite What It Used to Be

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: TWO THOUSAND ONE: A SPACE ODYSSEY (MOVIE)

stories.snippet: Prediction is very hard, the quantum physicist Niels Bohr once said, especially regarding the future, but that is exactly the job and the predicament of the science fiction writer. Next week, the future arrives for one of the most famous prophecies...
stories.lead_paragraph: Prediction is very hard, the quantum physicist Niels Bohr once said, especially regarding the future, but that is exactly the job and the predicament of the science fiction writer. Next week, the future arrives for one of the most famous prophecies of all time, ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' Stanley Kubrick, who directed and produced the movie, died in 1999, but his partner Arthur C. Clarke, who wrote the book on which he and Mr. Kubrick based the screenplay, is alive and well in Sri Lanka and will be around for the release of a new version of ''2001'' with digital light and sound next year, as well as comparisons of the future then and now.

stories.abstract: A O Scott reviews movie Spider-Man 2, directed by Sam Raimi and starring Tobey Maguire; photo (M)

headline.main: Putting Action After Feelings Of a Superhero

stories.snippet: On the way out of the advance screening of ''Spider-Man 2,'' which opens tomorrow nationwide, I asked my son, who is nearly 8 and whom I had brought along for some unscientific audience research, what he thought of the movie.    As he usually does,...
stories.lead_paragraph: On the way out of the advance screening of ''Spider-Man 2,'' which opens tomorrow nationwide, I asked my son, who is nearly 8 and whom I had brought along for some unscientific audience research, what he thought of the movie. As he usually does, he mentioned the scary parts and the cool parts, of which there are many. ''But there was one part,'' he said, ''that I really didn't like.'' That was when Peter Parker threw his costume in the trash and declared that he was ''Spider-Man no more.''

stories.abstract: A O Scott reviews movie Jarhead, directed by Sam Mendes and starring Jake Gyllenhaal, Jamie Foxx and Peter Sarsgaard; photos (M)

headline.main: Soldiers in the Desert, Antsy and Apolitical

stories.snippet: "Jarhead" is a movie that walks up to some of the most urgent and painful issues of our present circumstance, clears its throat loudly and says nothing.
stories.lead_paragraph: ''Are we ever going to get to kill anyone?'' asks a young marine toward the end of ''Jarhead.'' It may be a strange question to hear in a war movie, but ''Jarhead,'' about an unusual war, the first gulf war, is a curious example of the genre. Adapted from Anthony Swofford's best-selling memoir of the same title -- a profane, scabrous prose poem alive with wit and anger -- the film tries to convey not only the terror and thrill of military life, but also the frustration and tedium. This is something of a challenge: how to evoke a jittery, anxious state of boredom without inducing it in the audience.

stories.abstract: Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer, NASA satellite designed to measure X-ray sources, detects previously unknown, oscillating X-ray signals from three dense chunks of matter called neutron stars; ringing signals may be generated by space being spun in circle, lending support to prediction of Einstein's theory of relativity that gravity of spinning object should tug slightly on surrounding space and slowly drag it around in circles; diagram (M)

headline.main: X-Rays From Afar Bolster Theory Of a Whirlpool in Empty Space

stories.snippet: Can empty space be stirred like pancake batter? According to Einstein's theory of relativity, the gravity of a spinning object should tug slightly on the surrounding space and slowly drag it around in circles. Any matter would be pulled along, even...
stories.lead_paragraph: Can empty space be stirred like pancake batter? According to Einstein's theory of relativity, the gravity of a spinning object should tug slightly on the surrounding space and slowly drag it around in circles. Any matter would be pulled along, even though ordinary gravity can only attract matter, not push it sideways. Observational astronomers have remained skeptical of that supremely bizarre prediction, since they have never found clear, direct proof that the phenomenon exists. But with the discovery of a strange new signal by the Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer, a NASA satellite designed to measure X-ray sources in deep space, a few more astronomers may be ready to get on board.

stories.abstract: University of Sydney researchers conduct study on impact of toxic cane toads on red-bellied black snakes in northeastern Australia; research, which is published in Proceedings of the Royal Society B, finds that snakes in toad areas are adapting and becoming more resistant to poison from toad; Christophe Barbraud and Henri Weimerskirch of Center for Biological Studies of Chize, France, find that although warming climate has caused northern hemisphere birds to nest early, Antarctica birds are breeding later than in past decandes; hold that various factors have made foraging for food more difficult; research is published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences; Markus Harting of University of Utrecht, Netherlands, leads research that suggests that Chicxulub crater, generated by space rock impact 65 million years ago, was actually created in much earlier collision; holds that event could not have been cause of mass extinctions around globe; Jean-Marc Ame and Jose Halloy of Free University of Brussels conduct study that shows cockroaches use collective decision-making; research is published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences; drawing (M)

headline.main: OBSERVATORY

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PROCEEDINGS OF THE ROYAL SOCIETY B

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PROCEEDINGS OF THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCES

stories.snippet: The decision-making skills of cockroaches, snakes taking on toads in Australia, the effects of climate change and more.
stories.lead_paragraph: Rapid Response in Snakes There is more news from the cane toad war in northeastern Australia. A recent study had shown that the toads, introduced to that continent about 70 years ago, were spreading ever faster as long-leggedness evolved as a trait. The toads are considered an invasive pest because they are toxic to many creatures that try to eat them, including snakes.

stories.abstract: NASA is scheduled to launch New Horizons spacecraft on Jan 17; craft will journey to and get first close-up look at Pluto; spacecraft will reach Jupiter in just 13 months, where gravity assist will speed it on its way to Pluto in so-called Kuiper Belt for arrival in 2015; compact robot craft will be in hibernation for most of flight to conserve energy; once New Horizons completes its study of ice dwarf Pluto and its moons, it will be redirected toward other Kuiper Belt objects; photo; diagrams (M)

headline.main: NASA Mission Will Explore Solar System's Frozen Edge

stories.snippet: A spacecraft called New Horizons is set to be launched on a nine-and-a-half-year journey to Pluto, the last planet left to be visited by human spacecraft.
stories.lead_paragraph: For more than four decades, humans have been sending out spacecraft to explore the known planets of the solar system. At long last, it is time to visit the last planet. On Tuesday, a powerful Lockheed Martin Atlas 5 rocket is scheduled to send a spacecraft called New Horizons on a journey to the dim outer reaches of the Sun's realm for the first close-up look at Pluto. If successful, the mission will complete the initial exploration of the nine planets that defined the solar system at the beginning of the space age.

stories.abstract: New Horizons, NASA spacecraft on way to Pluto, has discovered lightning in polar regions of Jupiter; also finds that volcanically active moon Io belches out tons of material that travels hundreds of millions of miles down Jupiter's long magnetic trail; spacecraft made close pass to Jupiter to get sling-shot gravity boost designed to cut at least three years off its trip to Pluto; scientists took advantage of trip around planet to test craft's seven scientific instruments and operational procedures in trial run (M)

headline.main: En Route to Pluto, Discoveries About Jupiter

stories.snippet: The NASA spacecraft on the way to Pluto has discovered lightning in the polar regions of Jupiter, scientists said Tuesday.
stories.lead_paragraph: The NASA spacecraft on the way to Pluto has discovered lightning in the polar regions of Jupiter, scientists said Tuesday. It also found that the volcanically active moon Io belches out tons of material that travels hundreds of millions of miles down Jupiter's long magnetic tail. The spacecraft, New Horizons, was launched in January 2006 and made a close pass to Jupiter on Feb. 28 of this year to get a slingshot-like gravity boost designed to cut three years off its trip to Pluto, which it is to reach in July 2015.

stories.abstract: Television and film executives say that in wake of attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon, movies involving terrorism, explosions, hijackings and kind of jokey violence popular in films of 1990's will be rapidly replaced by patriotic stories, family dramas touching on parents and children and escapist comedies; photo (M)

headline.main: For Now, Film Industry Scratches Violence in Favor of Family Fare and Patriotism

stories.snippet: In response to the terrorist attacks in New York and at the Pentagon on Tuesday, television and film executives say movies involving terrorism, explosions, hijackings and the kind of jokey violence popular in the films of the 1990's will be rapidly...
stories.lead_paragraph: In response to the terrorist attacks in New York and at the Pentagon on Tuesday, television and film executives say movies involving terrorism, explosions, hijackings and the kind of jokey violence popular in the films of the 1990's will be rapidly replaced by patriotic stories, family dramas touching on parents and children and escapist comedies. ''You don't want to hear anything right now that's a dark, gritty drama,'' said Dana Walden, president of 20th Century Fox Television, which produces 24 series, more than any other studio. ''A lot of people will be looking for blue skies and escapist dramas and programs as an alternative to the realities that all of us are dealing with now and for years to come.''

stories.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of workers in government buildings and prominent office towers across US are sent home early, leaving downtown areas large and small in wake of terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon (M)

headline.kicker: A DAY OF TERROR: TERRORIST VIGIL
headline.main: Security Alerts Go Into Effect Across Nation

stories.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of workers in government buildings and prominent office towers streamed home early today, deserting downtowns large and small across the country in an orderly but fearful precaution against further terrorist attacks. At the same...
stories.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of workers in government buildings and prominent office towers streamed home early today, deserting downtowns large and small across the country in an orderly but fearful precaution against further terrorist attacks. At the same time, military bases were on the highest level of alert everywhere, and several governors prepared to mobilize state national guards. At the sprawling Eglin Air Force Base in the Florida panhandle, which handles all of the Air Force's covert activities, security was increased, many visitors were turned away and even authorized guests had cars carefully searched.

stories.abstract: Correction of spelling of name in March 28 article about efforts to analyze wreckage from space shuttle Columbia

headline.main: Corrections

stories.snippet: An article yesterday about efforts to analyze wreckage from the space shuttle Columbia misspelled the surname of the NASA official in charge of the work. He is Michael D. Leinbach, not Leimbach.
stories.lead_paragraph: An article yesterday about efforts to analyze wreckage from the space shuttle Columbia misspelled the surname of the NASA official in charge of the work. He is Michael D. Leinbach, not Leimbach.
